description: The Linux Security Techniques series introduces the viewers to the various security features found in modern Linux distributions. Topics covered include data encryption, auditing access, SELinux and firewall configuration among others. The series also lightly covers penetration testing to ensure that each security technique is implemented properly.

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover what we need to do to enable syslog, what we need to configure & maintain it, modifying/tampering with/deleting the logs, and other considerations for syslog including RELP.
episodes.title: Managing Logs with syslog
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.767
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host, Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.767 --> 00:00:11.956
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.956 --> 00:00:14.348
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

4
00:00:14.348 --> 00:00:16.350
helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:16.350 --> 00:00:20.590
I'm your host, Zach Memos, as we continue
on with Linux Security techniques.

6
00:00:20.590 --> 00:00:23.790
We're gonna be looking at
managing logs with syslog.

7
00:00:23.790 --> 00:00:27.839
And our very own Don Pezet is bringing us
all the information we need because he

8
00:00:27.839 --> 00:00:29.533
knows it, he knows this stuff.

9
00:00:29.533 --> 00:00:31.142
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yes he does.

10
00:00:31.142 --> 00:00:33.622
>> All right, well in this episode
we're going to be tackling syslog.

11
00:00:33.622 --> 00:00:36.718
And hopefully, if you're watching
a Linux security technique show,

12
00:00:36.718 --> 00:00:38.117
you already know about syslog.

13
00:00:38.117 --> 00:00:40.091
And you know what it is,
and you know what it does,

14
00:00:40.091 --> 00:00:41.561
because it is so important, right?

15
00:00:41.561 --> 00:00:46.330
It is that kind of core logging
subsystem found in most Linux distros.

16
00:00:46.330 --> 00:00:50.590
And as a security professional we
need to know about it because one,

17
00:00:50.590 --> 00:00:52.730
that's how we're gonna find out
what's going on in our system, right?

18
00:00:52.730 --> 00:00:56.440
We need to know when inappropriate
access or unusual behavior is occurring,

19
00:00:56.440 --> 00:00:58.050
anything that might cause an outage.

20
00:00:58.050 --> 00:00:59.560
We need to know that's occurring.

21
00:00:59.560 --> 00:01:03.700
And two, we need to be protecting
those logs, because for

22
00:01:03.700 --> 00:01:07.850
a hacker, their number one
goal is to damage your logs.

23
00:01:07.850 --> 00:01:11.180
Their number two goal is to
then gain access to your data.

24
00:01:11.180 --> 00:01:14.188
They need to damage the logs first so
they can hide their tracks,

25
00:01:14.188 --> 00:01:15.478
then they get at your data.

26
00:01:15.478 --> 00:01:18.662
If they go straight for the data, you'll
have logs, you'll be able to track that.

27
00:01:18.662 --> 00:01:19.976
You'll be able to see what happens and

28
00:01:19.976 --> 00:01:21.980
that's how you'll be able
to build a court case.

29
00:01:21.980 --> 00:01:23.880
So they target the logs first.

30
00:01:23.880 --> 00:01:28.960
This is a very high priority target,
I guess, for an attacker.

31
00:01:28.960 --> 00:01:31.760
So we wanna make sure that we're doing
what we can to ensure that these logs

32
00:01:31.760 --> 00:01:36.450
are working properly, that we don't
lose our logs and that we've got them

33
00:01:36.450 --> 00:01:39.800
protected in the event that somebody
does manage to find a way to erase them.

34
00:01:39.800 --> 00:01:41.930
And that's all the stuff that we're
gonna be taking a look at right here

35
00:01:41.930 --> 00:01:42.840
in this episode.

36
00:01:42.840 --> 00:01:46.260
>> So Don,
what do we need to do to enable syslog?

37
00:01:46.260 --> 00:01:48.990
>> Well,
this is one of those services that is

38
00:01:48.990 --> 00:01:53.380
installed by default in every
distro that's worth its salt today,

39
00:01:53.380 --> 00:01:56.610
and really has a default
configuration that's pretty good.

40
00:01:56.610 --> 00:02:00.020
So technically,
you don't have to do anything, right?

41
00:02:00.020 --> 00:02:03.880
And that's a bit of a double edged sword,
because on one hand it's super easy.

42
00:02:03.880 --> 00:02:05.074
Hey syslog's already running,
it's doing its thing.

43
00:02:05.074 --> 00:02:06.161
>> It's already doing it, right.

44
00:02:06.161 --> 00:02:10.794
>> But on the other hand, the default
configuration is not as ideal as

45
00:02:10.794 --> 00:02:15.670
we'd like to see it for
a security focused environment, right?

46
00:02:15.670 --> 00:02:19.680
So it's good enough for basic trouble
shooting, and simple auditing,

47
00:02:19.680 --> 00:02:20.750
and things like that.

48
00:02:20.750 --> 00:02:22.640
But it's not quite where we want it to be.

49
00:02:22.640 --> 00:02:25.180
So there are somethings that we
wanna get in there and change.

50
00:02:25.180 --> 00:02:28.799
But pretty much every distro
that's out there has syslog.

51
00:02:28.799 --> 00:02:30.050
I mean, syslog's been around a long time.

52
00:02:30.050 --> 00:02:33.818
It was developed in the 1970s
it's been around with Unix and

53
00:02:33.818 --> 00:02:37.601
imported into Linux and it does its job,
it does it really well.

54
00:02:37.601 --> 00:02:44.299
Some of you may know that syslog,
its time is ticking, right?

55
00:02:44.299 --> 00:02:49.889
That Journald is replacing syslog,
and so we know that's happening.

56
00:02:49.889 --> 00:02:54.040
But even the distros that have switched
to Journald, still run syslog.

57
00:02:54.040 --> 00:02:54.900
They run them together.

58
00:02:54.900 --> 00:02:58.450
I don't know a single distro
that has abandoned syslog yet.

59
00:02:58.450 --> 00:02:59.990
I can't think of a single one.

60
00:02:59.990 --> 00:03:02.080
All the commercially supported
ones still use syslog.

61
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:06.540
So it's the one we want,
it's configured and enabled by default.

62
00:03:06.540 --> 00:03:10.030
We can verify if you don't know, right?

63
00:03:10.030 --> 00:03:14.550
When syslog runs,
it is logging to /var/log, right?

64
00:03:14.550 --> 00:03:16.610
That's the folder that it logs to.

65
00:03:16.610 --> 00:03:21.260
And if I wanna get into that folder,
cd /var/ log,

66
00:03:21.260 --> 00:03:25.170
well this folder has logs for
a lot of different things.

67
00:03:25.170 --> 00:03:29.902
And if you are running a syslog it'll
usually be this guy right here,

68
00:03:29.902 --> 00:03:31.706
/var/log/messages.

69
00:03:31.706 --> 00:03:33.779
That is where our message
are getting dumped to.

70
00:03:33.779 --> 00:03:37.667
Now if you have messed with the
configuration, then it may not be there or

71
00:03:37.667 --> 00:03:41.685
I have seen some distros which they
actually name the file syslog instead of

72
00:03:41.685 --> 00:03:43.180
naming it messages.

73
00:03:43.180 --> 00:03:46.860
But that's where it's logging to and
all of the various server activity that's

74
00:03:46.860 --> 00:03:49.870
occurring is being dumped
right into that file.

75
00:03:49.870 --> 00:03:53.590
So I know the syslog is kinda there and
doing its job.

76
00:03:53.590 --> 00:03:56.280
But I can also hunt down its
process if I want, right?

77
00:03:56.280 --> 00:04:02.870
It starts pretty early in the system if
we come in and hunt down that process.

78
00:04:02.870 --> 00:04:07.420
So I'm just doing a ps aux to view my
process list and grepping for syslog.

79
00:04:07.420 --> 00:04:14.810
And I can see it right here, process ID
790/user/sbin/rsyslogd -n is running.

80
00:04:14.810 --> 00:04:16.400
So, it's running in the background,

81
00:04:16.400 --> 00:04:21.070
it's doing its job, and we don't
necessarily need to worry about it.

82
00:04:21.070 --> 00:04:23.720
I can verify that the logs
are actually growing.

83
00:04:23.720 --> 00:04:26.980
Usually when I'm watching the logs,
I don't just go and

84
00:04:26.980 --> 00:04:28.830
open the messages file
itself cuz it's pretty big.

85
00:04:28.830 --> 00:04:30.470
I normally tail it, right?

86
00:04:30.470 --> 00:04:33.210
And say just show me the last
ten lines which is the default.

87
00:04:33.210 --> 00:04:40.090
So I'll say tail/var/log/messages and
we can go in and look at it.

88
00:04:40.090 --> 00:04:44.540
Now I get Permission denied, and
this is part of the default configuration.

89
00:04:44.540 --> 00:04:47.090
I'm logged in as a regular user.

90
00:04:47.090 --> 00:04:48.460
I'm just logged in as dpezet.

91
00:04:48.460 --> 00:04:51.830
And a regular user doesn't
have access to the syslog.

92
00:04:51.830 --> 00:04:53.210
Why is that?

93
00:04:53.210 --> 00:04:55.710
Well a regular user
shouldn't need access to it.

94
00:04:55.710 --> 00:04:58.410
And if they could, if they could
get in there and tamper with it,

95
00:04:58.410 --> 00:04:59.662
then they could hide things.

96
00:04:59.662 --> 00:05:01.399
Or they could run some tests to see,
all right,

97
00:05:01.399 --> 00:05:03.630
what's gonna show up in the logs and
what isn't.

98
00:05:03.630 --> 00:05:04.670
We don't want that.

99
00:05:04.670 --> 00:05:08.000
So there are some basic permissions
that are assigned to this if we

100
00:05:09.690 --> 00:05:11.750
look at that file.

101
00:05:11.750 --> 00:05:16.408
You'll see where it's owned by root,
and the root user has read and

102
00:05:16.408 --> 00:05:18.550
write, nobody else, right?

103
00:05:18.550 --> 00:05:19.930
Not even the root group.

104
00:05:19.930 --> 00:05:22.200
So if I have a user like my dpezet user,

105
00:05:22.200 --> 00:05:26.840
if I put myself in the admin group, I add
myself to adm, I can use the sudo command,

106
00:05:26.840 --> 00:05:30.790
and I can use other things, but
I can't edit this file, right?

107
00:05:30.790 --> 00:05:32.050
I don't have that permission.

108
00:05:32.050 --> 00:05:34.220
Only the root user does.

109
00:05:34.220 --> 00:05:40.010
And as we saw up here,
syslogd is running as root, okay?

110
00:05:40.010 --> 00:05:42.600
This is why when you read about
security vulnerabilities and exploits,

111
00:05:42.600 --> 00:05:47.520
any time there's a privilege escalation
exploit, those are a big deal.

112
00:05:47.520 --> 00:05:51.590
Because that means a hacker is able to
get in under one set of credentials and

113
00:05:51.590 --> 00:05:54.770
then escalate their
privileges up to root level.

114
00:05:54.770 --> 00:05:58.350
Because once they can do that,
once they can act on behalf of root,

115
00:05:58.350 --> 00:06:02.780
now they can modify this file,
and that's a real problem.

116
00:06:02.780 --> 00:06:04.510
So it is limited down just like that.

117
00:06:04.510 --> 00:06:08.150
If I wanna look at this,
I need to step up to a root.

118
00:06:08.150 --> 00:06:09.720
I can either sudo my commands or

119
00:06:09.720 --> 00:06:13.060
do a sudo -s, that's what I'm
gonna do to get a root shell.

120
00:06:13.060 --> 00:06:17.662
And then that way, I can come in and
I can tail /var/log/messages and

121
00:06:17.662 --> 00:06:19.361
see those last ten lines.

122
00:06:19.361 --> 00:06:21.159
And so there's those entries.

123
00:06:21.159 --> 00:06:24.820
If I was troubleshooting something,
I would do a tail- f to follow it.

124
00:06:24.820 --> 00:06:28.000
And then that way as new entries were
created, they would just start to kind of

125
00:06:28.000 --> 00:06:30.720
appear here on the screen and I could
watch it while I was doing something.

126
00:06:30.720 --> 00:06:32.774
But I can see the log messages are there.

127
00:06:32.774 --> 00:06:38.857
I've got entries from 10:54:09 and looking
at my watch, it is 10:54 right now.

128
00:06:38.857 --> 00:06:40.670
So I know it's currently logging.

129
00:06:40.670 --> 00:06:43.870
It is doing its job and
I didn't really configure anything,

130
00:06:43.870 --> 00:06:46.550
I just powered on my system and
there it goes.

131
00:06:46.550 --> 00:06:51.220
So as far as getting configured,
there's not too much to it.

132
00:06:51.220 --> 00:06:55.478
Do be aware that not everything
logs to that messages file.

133
00:06:55.478 --> 00:06:59.040
Notice how there's a MariaDB folder
here from when I had a database server

134
00:06:59.040 --> 00:07:03.050
installed or
some other entries like the audit folder.

135
00:07:03.050 --> 00:07:06.080
There are other logs that
are just as important, but

136
00:07:06.080 --> 00:07:10.070
the syslog is gonna contain the general
information about our system that is

137
00:07:10.070 --> 00:07:12.720
typically really useful
when we're troubleshooting.

138
00:07:12.720 --> 00:07:17.270
So all the logs are important, but
the message one especially so,

139
00:07:17.270 --> 00:07:22.115
because that's kind of our core logging
system when the system fires up.

140
00:07:22.115 --> 00:07:26.260
>> Don, is there anything we
need to maintain or configure?

141
00:07:26.260 --> 00:07:28.310
>> Yeah, so I mentioned in
the beginning of the episode,

142
00:07:28.310 --> 00:07:30.290
as a security administrator,

143
00:07:30.290 --> 00:07:33.710
one of the things that we need to be
aware of is log retention, right?

144
00:07:33.710 --> 00:07:39.232
We need to keep logs for a certain period
of time, and how long is up to you.

145
00:07:39.232 --> 00:07:43.270
Now the default configuration is
using what's called log rotation.

146
00:07:43.270 --> 00:07:45.478
And log rotation says every so

147
00:07:45.478 --> 00:07:49.726
often I"m gonna close one log file and
open another one.

148
00:07:49.726 --> 00:07:51.130
And you can see mine has done that.

149
00:07:51.130 --> 00:07:53.392
I've got messages, that's my current file.

150
00:07:53.392 --> 00:07:58.100
But then I've got messages-20170807, and

151
00:07:58.100 --> 00:08:03.224
messages-2017-0815 It
looks like once a week.

152
00:08:03.224 --> 00:08:07.280
Once a week it's splitting
these off into a separate file.

153
00:08:07.280 --> 00:08:10.197
So this would be the week of August 15th.

154
00:08:10.197 --> 00:08:12.370
This other one would be
the week of August 7th.

155
00:08:12.370 --> 00:08:16.040
And then I've got this one,
which is my current week that I'm in.

156
00:08:16.040 --> 00:08:17.400
So it's splitting these off.

157
00:08:17.400 --> 00:08:19.710
Well it's gonna keep these.

158
00:08:19.710 --> 00:08:21.290
How long is it gonna keep them?

159
00:08:21.290 --> 00:08:24.460
Not forever, If it keeps them forever
the log files grow grow and grow and

160
00:08:24.460 --> 00:08:25.800
eventually they fill the hard drive.

161
00:08:25.800 --> 00:08:26.990
And then what happens?

162
00:08:26.990 --> 00:08:30.381
Well usually your system freezes or
something bad happens when it gets full.

163
00:08:30.381 --> 00:08:31.665
It depends on how your
partitioning is set up.

164
00:08:31.665 --> 00:08:34.259
But we don't want that to happen and so

165
00:08:34.259 --> 00:08:39.287
the log rotation will oftentimes have
a maximum interval, like a maximum

166
00:08:39.287 --> 00:08:43.933
amount of logs it'll maintain,
and then it starts deleting logs.

167
00:08:43.933 --> 00:08:46.024
Now, you need to look at
your security policy and

168
00:08:46.024 --> 00:08:48.760
say how long do I actually
have to retain this?

169
00:08:48.760 --> 00:08:50.110
In high security environments,

170
00:08:50.110 --> 00:08:53.300
environments where you're handling
things like patient medical records or

171
00:08:53.300 --> 00:08:57.620
financial records, you might be
required to retain data for ten years.

172
00:08:57.620 --> 00:08:58.950
And so, if that's the case,

173
00:08:58.950 --> 00:09:02.400
I can't have log rotate deleting
logs after eight weeks.

174
00:09:02.400 --> 00:09:04.060
I need to customize that.

175
00:09:04.060 --> 00:09:05.780
So this is one of the first
things that I'll jump in and

176
00:09:05.780 --> 00:09:09.920
customize on a server deployment,
is how log rotation is being handled.

177
00:09:09.920 --> 00:09:13.970
And it's all kind of tucked
away in a simple file.

178
00:09:13.970 --> 00:09:18.668
If you go into slash etc and look you'll
find two things of interest, one is

179
00:09:18.668 --> 00:09:23.215
Logrotate.com, and the other one was
Logrotate.d, which is actually a folder.

180
00:09:23.215 --> 00:09:27.640
All right, Logrotate.com it used to
be that this one file controlled

181
00:09:27.640 --> 00:09:31.363
log rotational all by itself,
now it includes configuration files from

182
00:09:31.363 --> 00:09:34.455
inside of LogRotate.D
in that folder as well.

183
00:09:34.455 --> 00:09:38.005
But if we take a look at that
LogRotate.com,I'm just gonna edit that,

184
00:09:39.491 --> 00:09:44.246
And pull that up, okay, right here I
can see the standard log rotation,and

185
00:09:44.246 --> 00:09:48.615
remember how I guessed mine was set for
weekly cuz of those dates?

186
00:09:48.615 --> 00:09:52.580
Sure enough, right here, I want to
rotate these log files weekly and

187
00:09:52.580 --> 00:09:54.300
you can change this,
it actually takes plain English.

188
00:09:54.300 --> 00:09:56.568
You can say daily, monthly, yearly.

189
00:09:56.568 --> 00:09:58.536
You can actually just put
those values in here.

190
00:09:58.536 --> 00:10:01.462
And they're telling you to pull up
the log rotate manual command for

191
00:10:01.462 --> 00:10:04.670
details on all this,
cuz there are a lot of other options, too.

192
00:10:04.670 --> 00:10:09.760
But right now, the default is weekly and
then keep four week's worth of backlogs.

193
00:10:09.760 --> 00:10:13.260
So what's gonna happen in four weeks?

194
00:10:13.260 --> 00:10:18.550
In four weeks it's gonna delete the old
list backlog to make room for a new one.

195
00:10:18.550 --> 00:10:22.408
So I've only got only four weeks of Sys
log if my security policy says I need

196
00:10:22.408 --> 00:10:24.349
to maintain this data for ten years.

197
00:10:24.349 --> 00:10:28.792
I've got two options, okay,
option one is to increase this right,

198
00:10:28.792 --> 00:10:31.870
increase it to a higher
number maybe ten years.

199
00:10:31.870 --> 00:10:33.319
But again,
I don't wanna fill up my hard drive.

200
00:10:33.319 --> 00:10:35.970
But whatever it needs to be,
I can increase it.

201
00:10:35.970 --> 00:10:38.990
Or, option two, I can set up

202
00:10:38.990 --> 00:10:43.890
a manual backup plan that says I'm gonna
back up these log files somewhere else.

203
00:10:43.890 --> 00:10:46.630
And that way, I don't care if they get
deleted here after only four weeks cuz

204
00:10:46.630 --> 00:10:48.200
I've got them backed up somewhere else.

205
00:10:48.200 --> 00:10:51.620
So we need to be aware of
that kind of balance, of

206
00:10:51.620 --> 00:10:55.730
how many logs I wanna keep on the server
versus backing them up somewhere else.

207
00:10:55.730 --> 00:10:57.560
And you really wanna back then
up somewhere else anyway,

208
00:10:57.560 --> 00:10:59.620
so that's often times what we're gonna do.

209
00:10:59.620 --> 00:11:03.683
But you can set that value right here
just by modifying these two values,

210
00:11:03.683 --> 00:11:08.097
whether it's gonna be weekly, and
how many you'll store as far as rotation.

211
00:11:08.097 --> 00:11:12.790
Those are kinda two important
things to get set in there.

212
00:11:12.790 --> 00:11:17.995
If you set rotate to zero
then it will never maintain

213
00:11:17.995 --> 00:11:23.091
secondary logs,
it will just keep them forever.

214
00:11:23.091 --> 00:11:25.918
And you might want that you might
want to keep them forever but

215
00:11:25.918 --> 00:11:28.868
it's really difficult to back that up and
start over and so on.

216
00:11:28.868 --> 00:11:31.912
If you're doing that so you usually
want to have that at least be rotate

00:23:30.880 --> 00:23:34.040
secured it properly and
applied proper practices there.

442
00:23:34.040 --> 00:23:39.580
But otherwise, that one's in business and
it is up and doing shop.

443
00:23:39.580 --> 00:23:43.310
Now, I do need to restart our syslog for
it to read all that and kick in, but

444
00:23:43.310 --> 00:23:45.440
now it's sending that traffic over and

445
00:23:45.440 --> 00:23:49.270
I've got a secure logging facility
set up that is nice and centralized.

446
00:23:49.270 --> 00:23:52.765
>> Well, are there any other
things to consider with syslog?

447
00:23:52.765 --> 00:23:55.840
There's a couple of things we definitely
need to set up a backup strategy.

448
00:23:55.840 --> 00:23:58.820
I've got this great
centralized server now, and

449
00:23:58.820 --> 00:24:01.430
I'm letting my nodes age
out logs after four weeks.

450
00:24:01.430 --> 00:24:04.240
So my nodes only go back four weeks,
that's probably not long enough.

451
00:24:04.240 --> 00:24:05.360
On my centralized server,

452
00:24:05.360 --> 00:24:08.340
I need a backup regimen put in
place to be able to contain that.

453
00:24:08.340 --> 00:24:09.800
So that's one thing to think about.

454
00:24:09.800 --> 00:24:10.890
The other thing is,

455
00:24:10.890 --> 00:24:16.090
the more nodes you have, the harder it
gets to find records in these messages.

456
00:24:16.090 --> 00:24:18.002
The messages files are just text files.

457
00:24:18.002 --> 00:24:21.890
If it's millions of lines long and
you've gotta search through it for

458
00:24:21.890 --> 00:24:26.205
entries, you have to load the file into
memory, and it really is kind of a pain.

459
00:24:26.205 --> 00:24:29.255
So if you go out there and
dig through the documentation,

460
00:24:29.255 --> 00:24:33.930
you'll actually find where syslog
doesn't have to log to a text file.

461
00:24:33.930 --> 00:24:38.020
You can set it up to log to a MySQL or
MariaDB Server.

462
00:24:38.020 --> 00:24:41.520
And if you do that,
if you have it log into a database server,

463
00:24:41.520 --> 00:24:44.920
then it becomes trivial to go in and
find records.

464
00:24:44.920 --> 00:24:48.740
I could just say take
a look at my whole network.

465
00:24:48.740 --> 00:24:51.010
I might have thousands of servers.

466
00:24:51.010 --> 00:24:54.560
And say, show me every time
this IP address connected or

467
00:24:54.560 --> 00:24:58.810
a IP address in the logs and it could
scan that database very quickly and

468
00:24:58.810 --> 00:25:01.810
return it, and now you get that data,
the much more manageable environment.

469
00:25:01.810 --> 00:25:04.020
So the larger a network you have,

470
00:25:04.020 --> 00:25:07.050
the more likely you'll want to switch
to doing database backed storage.

471
00:25:07.050 --> 00:25:08.820
So that's something you can look up and

472
00:25:08.820 --> 00:25:11.180
see, maybe one day we'll
film an episode on that one.

473
00:25:11.180 --> 00:25:12.790
It's actually not that hard to get set up.

474
00:25:12.790 --> 00:25:13.970
>> We should.

475
00:25:13.970 --> 00:25:17.134
>> But for most of us, the log
messages don't get that big, and so

476
00:25:17.134 --> 00:25:19.000
you can kind of manage it right here.

477
00:25:19.000 --> 00:25:21.086
But when you've got thousands
of servers it does.

478
00:25:21.086 --> 00:25:24.700
So you need some kind of centralized
solution, that's a database backed.

479
00:25:24.700 --> 00:25:27.240
>> Fantastic, managing logs with syslog.

480
00:25:27.240 --> 00:25:29.850
Great information, final thoughts, Don?

481
00:25:29.850 --> 00:25:32.510
>> Main thing here is syslog is
not going anywhere anytime soon.

482
00:25:32.510 --> 00:25:33.920
So you definitely wanna learn it.

483
00:25:33.920 --> 00:25:34.662
You definitely wanna know it.

484
00:25:34.662 --> 00:25:36.360
You definitely want to secure it.

485
00:25:36.360 --> 00:25:40.130
Remember, it's target number one for
any hacker that's not an idiot.

486
00:25:40.130 --> 00:25:44.440
That if they know what they're doing, they
know they've gotta to cover their tracks.

487
00:25:44.440 --> 00:25:46.290
They'll target the logs first and

488
00:25:46.290 --> 00:25:49.940
after they get past that, then they
start going after everything else.

489
00:25:49.940 --> 00:25:54.580
So if we keep our logs secure, a lot of
times that'll stop the attack right there

490
00:25:54.580 --> 00:25:57.020
and they don't progress to
the rest of the payload.

491
00:25:57.020 --> 00:25:59.791
>> Now, we gotta watch for
the bad actors and that's why we're doing

492
00:25:59.791 --> 00:26:02.530
this episode and all the episodes
of Linux security techniques.

493
00:26:02.530 --> 00:26:05.370
Make sure you watch all of them and
you'll be glad you did.

494
00:26:05.370 --> 00:26:09.510
And thank you for watching ITProTV,
remember a good IT pro is always learning.

495
00:26:09.510 --> 00:26:10.590
I'm Zack Memos.

496
00:26:10.590 --> 00:26:13.495
>> And
I'm Don the bad actor Pezet [LAUGH].

497
00:26:13.495 --> 00:26:18.993
>> Sometime, and we'll see you soon.

498
00:26:18.993 --> 00:26:22.789
[MUSIC]

499
00:26:22.789 --> 00:26:25.289
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover the similarities and differences of syslog & journald, journald designed as replacement for syslog, how we interact with journald, where the journald logs are stored, who is allowed access to the logs, journald equivalent to rsyslog, and using rsyslog in production.
episodes.title: Managing Logs with journald
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.733
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.733 --> 00:00:05.810
>> We're coming at you live
from San Francisco, California.

3
00:00:05.810 --> 00:00:06.469
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.469 --> 00:00:08.413
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.413 --> 00:00:12.260
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.260 --> 00:00:14.720
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.720 --> 00:00:16.480
Helping you learn wherever you go.

8
00:00:16.480 --> 00:00:18.060
I'm your host Zach Memos.

9
00:00:18.060 --> 00:00:20.786
As we continue with
Linux Security Techniques,

10
00:00:20.786 --> 00:00:25.446
we're gonna manage logs with journald and
Don Pezet is gonna tell us how to do that.

11
00:00:25.446 --> 00:00:26.510
Don, good morning, Sir.

12
00:00:26.510 --> 00:00:27.435
>> Hi, good morning, Zach.

13
00:00:27.435 --> 00:00:30.547
And we're ready to dive back into
the world of Linux security techniques.

14
00:00:30.547 --> 00:00:33.327
And one thing that I know I've
mentioned in other episodes

15
00:00:33.327 --> 00:00:36.333
is that one of our key security
techniques is having log files,

16
00:00:36.333 --> 00:00:39.410
being able to reference log files,
read them, view them.

17
00:00:39.410 --> 00:00:40.920
That's a really critical piece.

18
00:00:40.920 --> 00:00:44.270
And in another episode,
we took a look at syslog and the syslogd,

19
00:00:44.270 --> 00:00:48.036
which is the standard login subsystem
found in almost every Linux system that

20
00:00:48.036 --> 00:00:53.922
are out there, but a lot of systems
are now moving over to journald.

21
00:00:53.922 --> 00:00:55.847
Journald is the replacement for syslog and

22
00:00:55.847 --> 00:00:58.474
it's a part of the system D
package that we're seeing it.

23
00:00:58.474 --> 00:01:01.750
We're seeing it in Ubuntu,
Red Hat, Fedora, Debian,

24
00:01:01.750 --> 00:01:05.600
all these different distros have
moved kinda in that direction.

25
00:01:05.600 --> 00:01:09.252
So I wanted to make sure we took a little
bit of time in this series to talk about

26
00:01:09.252 --> 00:01:10.850
journald and how it impacts us and

27
00:01:10.850 --> 00:01:14.126
how we need to maintain it to make
sure that our system stays secure.

28
00:01:14.126 --> 00:01:16.440
So that's what we're gonna be looking
at right here in this episode.

29
00:01:16.440 --> 00:01:19.890
>> Well, Don, at the end of the day,
isn't it the same with syslog?

30
00:01:19.890 --> 00:01:21.215
>> It's pretty darn close, right?

31
00:01:21.215 --> 00:01:25.791
So whenever they develop a new technology,
the first goal is to make it replicate

32
00:01:25.791 --> 00:01:30.350
the functionality of the old technology,
and then you add new stuff to it.

33
00:01:30.350 --> 00:01:33.610
So basically, they said, look,
syslog was designed in the 1970s.

34
00:01:33.610 --> 00:01:38.403
It's been around well over 30 years,
almost 40 years, probably over 40 years,

35
00:01:38.403 --> 00:01:38.935
I guess.

36
00:01:38.935 --> 00:01:41.360
[LAUGH] And so,
it's been around a long time, and

37
00:01:41.360 --> 00:01:44.188
there's things that it
just doesn't do well.

38
00:01:44.188 --> 00:01:49.420
And so journald, which the official
name of it is the System D Journal,

39
00:01:49.420 --> 00:01:52.550
but journald is the service,
the journal daemon,

40
00:01:52.550 --> 00:01:56.780
that it tries to fix a lot of
the problems that syslog had.

41
00:01:56.780 --> 00:01:59.677
And when it first came out,
journald was not very feature rich.

42
00:01:59.677 --> 00:02:02.990
It did not completely replicate
the features in syslog.

43
00:02:02.990 --> 00:02:06.006
And so what happened is a lot
of distros said, you know what,

44
00:02:06.006 --> 00:02:07.257
journald is the future.

45
00:02:07.257 --> 00:02:11.280
We want to go that route,
but it's not quite there.

46
00:02:11.280 --> 00:02:12.800
So let's run both.

47
00:02:12.800 --> 00:02:17.782
And if you install Fedora 24 or
25 or 26, 26 is the current one,

48
00:02:17.782 --> 00:02:22.682
if you install Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7,
if you install CentOS 7,

49
00:02:22.682 --> 00:02:25.191
if you install Ubuntu 16.04.

50
00:02:25.191 --> 00:02:28.045
I'm just trying to rattle off what's
current and supported right now,

51
00:02:28.045 --> 00:02:29.710
as of the filming of this episode.

52
00:02:29.710 --> 00:02:34.500
If you install any of those that I just
named, they're all running syslog and

53
00:02:34.500 --> 00:02:35.983
journald side by side.

54
00:02:35.983 --> 00:02:37.140
They're running both.

55
00:02:37.140 --> 00:02:41.530
And so when I wanna look at the logs
of a system, I can look at either one.

56
00:02:41.530 --> 00:02:44.420
I can go to the syslog messages file and
parse through it and try and

57
00:02:44.420 --> 00:02:46.940
find things or I can go to journald.

58
00:02:46.940 --> 00:02:50.213
And I'll tell you, for me personally,
I go to journald because we've got command

59
00:02:50.213 --> 00:02:52.861
line utilities that allow us to
search through it and find things.

60
00:02:52.861 --> 00:02:56.190
It's a little bit easier to work with and
you get more detailed information in it.

61
00:02:56.190 --> 00:03:00.210
But there are sometimes where
we still need syslog hanging in

62
00:03:00.210 --> 00:03:03.340
there cuz there are some features
that haven't been fully recreated.

63
00:03:03.340 --> 00:03:06.927
But as soon as we get to that point where
there's feature parity between the two,

64
00:03:06.927 --> 00:03:10.328
we'll see distros starting to move over
to it and we'll see syslog go away.

65
00:03:10.328 --> 00:03:11.561
But that hasn't really happened.

66
00:03:11.561 --> 00:03:16.070
And so, as of this very moment,
yeah, they are practically the same.

67
00:03:16.070 --> 00:03:17.234
They are very, very close.

68
00:03:17.234 --> 00:03:20.231
But there are some features that have
changed in journald that are nice to have.

69
00:03:20.231 --> 00:03:23.130
And we'll get a chance to see some
of those here in this episode.

70
00:03:23.130 --> 00:03:27.580
But, one of the main features that I
wanna point out, is that, in syslog,

71
00:03:27.580 --> 00:03:33.190
all the log messages were stored
in a text file, /var/log/messages.

72
00:03:33.190 --> 00:03:36.110
And that file, it's just a text file.

73
00:03:36.110 --> 00:03:37.810
So if somebody could get root privileges,

74
00:03:37.810 --> 00:03:39.780
they could edit it very
easy with any text editor.

75
00:03:39.780 --> 00:03:41.769
Go in there and change whatever they want.

76
00:03:41.769 --> 00:03:46.050
With journald,
it stores logs as a binary file.

77
00:03:46.050 --> 00:03:46.570
It's a binary.

78
00:03:46.570 --> 00:03:47.740
It's compiled.

79
00:03:47.740 --> 00:03:49.400
Not compiled like programming language,

80
00:03:49.400 --> 00:03:51.440
but just kind of compiled
in their own file format.

81
00:03:51.440 --> 00:03:53.860
And that way, it can't be modified.

82
00:03:53.860 --> 00:03:56.900
You can't go in and
just edit an entry inside of this file.

83
00:03:56.900 --> 00:03:57.870
You can clear it.

84
00:03:57.870 --> 00:04:01.720
You can erase it, but you can't tamper
with it and that's really nice.

85
00:04:01.720 --> 00:04:04.190
That gives us an extra layer
of security and improve, but

86
00:04:04.190 --> 00:04:06.260
it also gives us improved performance.

87
00:04:06.260 --> 00:04:09.900
Because it is stored in this different
format, we have search utilities that can

88
00:04:09.900 --> 00:04:12.180
parse right through it and
get us the information we want.

89
00:04:12.180 --> 00:04:15.180
We can take actions based on
what comes into the logs,

90
00:04:15.180 --> 00:04:16.390
and other advanced features.

91
00:04:16.390 --> 00:04:18.685
Those are all reasons why we
would want to go to journald.

92
00:04:19.710 --> 00:04:23.926
If you say, I hate journald and I'm gonna
stick with syslog, you will be fine.

93
00:04:23.926 --> 00:04:27.847
Syslog is not gonna go anywhere any time
soon, it's gonna be around probably for

94
00:04:27.847 --> 00:04:29.241
at least another ten years.

95
00:04:29.241 --> 00:04:32.538
I mean, this is a big transition to make,
changing your logging sub system.

96
00:04:32.538 --> 00:04:35.290
So you're not gonna hurt yourself
by just staying with syslog.

97
00:04:35.290 --> 00:04:39.141
But there are new features in journald
that l think you'll appreciate and

98
00:04:39.141 --> 00:04:41.635
so a lot of will start
moving in that direction.

99
00:04:41.635 --> 00:04:44.987
l already find that l go to journald more
than l do to sysog when I'm going and

100
00:04:44.987 --> 00:04:46.063
looking for messages.

101
00:04:46.063 --> 00:04:48.433
So just bear that in mind as
we go through this episode,

102
00:04:48.433 --> 00:04:51.633
that it might not be right for everybody
but if you choose to use journald,

103
00:04:51.633 --> 00:04:53.970
there's just a few things
that we need to be aware of.

104
00:04:53.970 --> 00:04:59.000
>> So Don, how do we interact with
journald if it's in a binary format?

105
00:04:59.000 --> 00:05:02.235
>> All right yeah, so
since we can't just go and view a file,

106
00:05:02.235 --> 00:05:04.295
right, we don't have that option.

107
00:05:04.295 --> 00:05:06.315
We have to use Journalctl, right?

108
00:05:06.315 --> 00:05:10.130
Journalctl is the interface and
here, I'll pull it up on my system.

109
00:05:10.130 --> 00:05:12.573
This is a Red Hat Enterprise Linux
7.4 system.

110
00:05:12.573 --> 00:05:16.069
And actually, I'm gonna switch to
a root shell real quick just so

111
00:05:16.069 --> 00:05:18.770
that I don't have to sudo every command.

112
00:05:18.770 --> 00:05:21.070
In order to have access to the logs,
you need to be an administrator.

113
00:05:21.070 --> 00:05:22.350
And I was logged in as a regular user.

114
00:05:22.350 --> 00:05:26.119
So if I pseudo everything, that would
work or I can just move to a root shell.

115
00:05:26.119 --> 00:05:29.658
But [COUGH] if I want to
take a look at the logs,

116
00:05:29.658 --> 00:05:33.220
I can just type journalctl, that command.

117
00:05:33.220 --> 00:05:36.040
We've got a systemctl for
interacting with system D.

118
00:05:36.040 --> 00:05:40.940
Then journalctl for interacting with
the journald, which is system Ds logs.

119
00:05:40.940 --> 00:05:43.470
So when I run that,
if I just run it by itself.

120
00:05:43.470 --> 00:05:45.096
There's my logs, right?

121
00:05:45.096 --> 00:05:47.690
And if you look at what's in here,

122
00:05:47.690 --> 00:05:53.270
it's actually gonna look really similar
to what we would have in syslog.

123
00:05:53.270 --> 00:05:58.970
So for example, let's say I open up
another terminal window here and

124
00:05:58.970 --> 00:06:02.224
let me get into that server real quick.

125
00:06:02.224 --> 00:06:07.319
I'm just gonna open up another session,
and get in here.

126
00:06:07.319 --> 00:06:10.332
In the syslog days, I would say, whoops,

127
00:06:10.332 --> 00:06:13.780
I would punch in my password,
is what I would do.

128
00:06:15.350 --> 00:06:15.890
Once I'm in here.

129
00:06:17.890 --> 00:06:23.047
Apparently my big challenge is knowing my
password so let me try this one more time.

130
00:06:23.047 --> 00:06:27.727
There we go, and I would do something
like less/var/log/messages and

131
00:06:27.727 --> 00:06:31.285
I would go in and
I'd take a look at my messages, right?

132
00:06:31.285 --> 00:06:34.500
And I could go through and
scroll in here and look at the logs.

133
00:06:34.500 --> 00:06:36.492
Now, as I look through here,

134
00:06:36.492 --> 00:06:41.458
the majority of what's stored in syslog
will also be stored in journald.

135
00:06:41.458 --> 00:06:47.431
And in fact, journald will often have
more in it than the syslog does.

136
00:06:47.431 --> 00:06:51.350
So for example, dmesg,
when the system boots up, right?

137
00:06:51.350 --> 00:06:53.670
We get all this hardware
detection that's happening.

138
00:06:53.670 --> 00:06:55.080
That's what I'm seeing right here.

139
00:06:55.080 --> 00:06:57.607
This is all the dmesg output.

140
00:06:57.607 --> 00:07:01.592
I don't see that in the old syslog
because it's not stored here.

141
00:07:01.592 --> 00:07:04.260
It's stored in /var/log/dmesg instead.

142
00:07:04.260 --> 00:07:05.281
It's stored in a different file.

143
00:07:05.281 --> 00:07:08.580
Journald puts it all together because
we can parse and search on it.

144
00:07:08.580 --> 00:07:12.300
The other thing is if you look here,
we see the date, the host name, and

145
00:07:12.300 --> 00:07:16.654
the service that generated the message,
followed by the actual message, right?

146
00:07:16.654 --> 00:07:20.010
As we kinda scroll through, you'll see
that kind of set on each of these.

147
00:07:20.010 --> 00:07:22.540
When I look over here, it's similar.

148
00:07:22.540 --> 00:07:23.760
I get the date, and

149
00:07:23.760 --> 00:07:27.780
I get the fully qualified host name,
followed by the service.

150
00:07:27.780 --> 00:07:30.710
So we get a little bit more information
there as far as identifying where this

151
00:07:30.710 --> 00:07:32.070
data is coming from.

152
00:07:32.070 --> 00:07:33.994
And then after that, we see the messages.

153
00:07:33.994 --> 00:07:40.000
And this file will grow and grow and grow
as more and more data gets pumped into it.

154
00:07:40.000 --> 00:07:42.610
And as I kinda scroll through here,
all the way to the end,

155
00:07:42.610 --> 00:07:47.820
I get where I had three incorrect password
attempts when I was trying to sudo, right?

156
00:07:47.820 --> 00:07:52.303
And if I were to do the same thing over
here and kinda sift through all the way to

157
00:07:52.303 --> 00:07:56.107
the end, I should have just tailed
this file, cuz it's so big.

158
00:07:56.107 --> 00:07:57.221
Again, all the way down to
the end of these messages.

159
00:07:57.221 --> 00:07:59.334
In fact, I'm gonna change that and
just tail it.

160
00:07:59.334 --> 00:08:00.720
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

161
00:08:00.720 --> 00:08:03.002
>> So we can kinda see the end of that one

162
00:08:03.002 --> 00:08:07.950
There we go, and I can see right here
where session 3 for user D Pezet came in,

163
00:08:07.950 --> 00:08:09.568
I created a new session.

164

00:32:46.630 --> 00:32:47.560
I didn't mention.

599
00:32:47.560 --> 00:32:49.920
When I had my text that was
running off the screen,

600
00:32:49.920 --> 00:32:53.190
I could've used my arrow keys to scroll
over instead of stretching my window,

601
00:32:53.190 --> 00:32:55.700
that's important if it's a really,
really message, you can do that.

602
00:32:55.700 --> 00:32:58.950
So, when you're using journalctl and
looking at it,

603
00:32:58.950 --> 00:33:03.250
it's really using the less command which
lets you scroll up and down, left and

604
00:33:03.250 --> 00:33:05.490
right, and you can search forward and
backwards.

605
00:33:05.490 --> 00:33:08.066
Forward slash to search forward,
question mark to search backwards.

606
00:33:08.066 --> 00:33:10.636
All that functionality is there
just like in the less command.

607
00:33:10.636 --> 00:33:13.090
So it's very easy to work with.

608
00:33:13.090 --> 00:33:15.440
A lot easier than kinda like
having to fuss with text files.

609
00:33:15.440 --> 00:33:17.370
But mess around with it.

610
00:33:17.370 --> 00:33:18.500
Don't hate journald.

611
00:33:18.500 --> 00:33:20.817
There are people out there
that hate systemd, and

612
00:33:20.817 --> 00:33:22.702
they hate journald because of systemd.

613
00:33:22.702 --> 00:33:24.080
I'll tell you, they're great systems.

614
00:33:24.080 --> 00:33:24.670
I like them.

615
00:33:24.670 --> 00:33:26.446
I enjoy working with them.

616
00:33:26.446 --> 00:33:29.970
And they're production ready
as far as collecting logs.

617
00:33:29.970 --> 00:33:32.500
But there's certain areas that
are just not production ready,

618
00:33:32.500 --> 00:33:34.210
and remote log shipping is one of those.

619
00:33:34.210 --> 00:33:36.960
So just be aware of
the limitations of journald, and

620
00:33:36.960 --> 00:33:39.740
don't go whole hog into it right now.

621
00:33:39.740 --> 00:33:41.789
It takes time to sift into this stuff.

622
00:33:41.789 --> 00:33:43.735
And your logs are not something
you wanna jeopardize.

623
00:33:43.735 --> 00:33:45.085
>> Great presentation as usual, Don.

624
00:33:45.085 --> 00:33:46.638
And thank you, Chris, for the questions.

625
00:33:46.638 --> 00:33:50.415
And there's a lot of episodes in
the Linux Security Techniques series.

626
00:33:50.415 --> 00:33:53.228
Make sure you watch them all
because you'll be glad you did.

627
00:33:53.228 --> 00:33:56.065
And thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

628
00:33:56.065 --> 00:33:58.355
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

629
00:33:58.355 --> 00:33:59.345
I'm Zach Memos.

630
00:33:59.345 --> 00:34:00.195
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

631
00:34:00.195 --> 00:34:02.996
>> And we will see you soon.

632
00:34:02.996 --> 00:34:08.809
[MUSIC]

633
00:34:08.809 --> 00:34:12.711
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss how we set a password policy for users, how all users can be affected by password policy, requiring a complex password, how we can know if our users are using a strong password, and passwords stored as non-reversible hashes.
episodes.title: Auditing User Passwords
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:05.909
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:05.909 --> 00:00:08.249
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.249 --> 00:00:12.140
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.140 --> 00:00:14.220
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

5
00:00:14.220 --> 00:00:16.220
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.220 --> 00:00:17.640
I'm your host Zach Memos.

7
00:00:17.640 --> 00:00:20.920
As we continue with Linux
security techniques.

8
00:00:20.920 --> 00:00:24.550
And our topic right now is
auditing user passwords.

9
00:00:24.550 --> 00:00:28.360
And the only person I know who can tell
us how to do that is Don Pezet, and

10
00:00:28.360 --> 00:00:28.955
he's right here.

11
00:00:28.955 --> 00:00:30.520
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hey Don, good morning.

12
00:00:30.520 --> 00:00:31.230
>> Good morning, Zach.

13
00:00:31.230 --> 00:00:34.062
And I'm the only person cuz you
just don't know a lot of people.

14
00:00:34.062 --> 00:00:34.680
>> [LAUGH] I live in a shell.

15
00:00:34.680 --> 00:00:39.370
>> Auditing user passwords,
it is a really important task.

16
00:00:39.370 --> 00:00:42.887
That we need before network administrators
and system administrators, server admins

17
00:00:42.887 --> 00:00:45.750
and really if you're in any kind of
security role inside of Linux role.

18
00:00:45.750 --> 00:00:49.654
This is something you gotta pay attention
to and really not even just Linux,

19
00:00:49.654 --> 00:00:54.610
Windows, Mac, whatever, users are really
bad about maintaining secure passwords.

20
00:00:54.610 --> 00:00:56.550
So, there's steps that we need to take.

21
00:00:56.550 --> 00:00:59.898
One, to make sure that people have secure
passwords in the first place and then two,

22
00:00:59.898 --> 00:01:03.165
to be able to double check and make sure
they actually are using strong passwords.

23
00:01:03.165 --> 00:01:05.863
So, that's what we're gonna
take a look at right here

24
00:01:05.863 --> 00:01:09.103
in this episode is how we can kinda
manage that security concern.

25
00:01:09.103 --> 00:01:12.536
How we can make sure people have secure
passwords, and how we can test and

26
00:01:12.536 --> 00:01:15.030
verify, all right here in this episode.

27
00:01:15.030 --> 00:01:17.300
>> So it makes sense, doesn't it?

28
00:01:17.300 --> 00:01:20.330
It really does.
How can we set a policy about setting

29
00:01:20.330 --> 00:01:23.090
a password that is secure for our users?

30
00:01:23.090 --> 00:01:24.690
>> And
that's really where we need to start.

31
00:01:24.690 --> 00:01:28.090
Because a user can pick whatever
password they want, and

32
00:01:28.090 --> 00:01:31.250
a lot of Linux distros either
don't stop them, right?

33
00:01:31.250 --> 00:01:33.850
It'll let you set even a weak password,
if you want.

34
00:01:33.850 --> 00:01:38.300
Or it'll do a dictionary check, but beyond
that won't enforce any kind of complexity.

35
00:01:38.300 --> 00:01:41.370
So you end up with this very,
very simple security policy.

36
00:01:41.370 --> 00:01:43.470
In fact,
if you've been watching this series,

37
00:01:43.470 --> 00:01:45.380
the whole Linux series
that we've been doing.

38
00:01:45.380 --> 00:01:47.930
In the installation shows,
I kept putting in weak passwords.

39
00:01:47.930 --> 00:01:51.140
And it would complain but it would let me
do it anyway if you just click Done twice.

40
00:01:51.140 --> 00:01:53.500
Or whatever,
it would let you use these weak passwords.

41
00:01:53.500 --> 00:01:57.690
So I do that in a lab because
it's fine but in production,

42
00:01:57.690 --> 00:02:01.340
in a commercial environment,
in an enterprise, that's not fine.

43
00:02:01.340 --> 00:02:02.860
We need to put a rule in place.

44
00:02:02.860 --> 00:02:04.740
We need this put our foot down and

45
00:02:04.740 --> 00:02:08.160
say look, this is how you're
gonna manage your password.

46
00:02:08.160 --> 00:02:12.720
One of the things we want to enforce on
the password policy is a password age.

47
00:02:12.720 --> 00:02:16.190
We don't want people to use the same
password for years on end, right?

48
00:02:16.190 --> 00:02:20.444
Passwords, even strong ones, can be brute
forced, and the more time an attacker has

49
00:02:20.444 --> 00:02:24.010
to brute force your password,
the more likely it is they'll succeed.

50
00:02:24.010 --> 00:02:26.910
So we want to enforce time limitations.

51
00:02:26.910 --> 00:02:29.543
And say you gotta change your
password after a certain period.

52
00:02:29.543 --> 00:02:34.940
And we can do that pretty easily using the
chage command, which is the change age.

53
00:02:34.940 --> 00:02:37.270
And so
I've got my RedHat box fired up here, and

54
00:02:37.270 --> 00:02:40.980
actually I'm gonna switch to
an admin Shell real quick.

55
00:02:40.980 --> 00:02:43.670
And what I can do is I can come in and
I can take the user.

56
00:02:43.670 --> 00:02:45.610
So, maybe I'll add a user here.

57
00:02:45.610 --> 00:02:47.219
Which I will just call user1.

58
00:02:47.219 --> 00:02:50.880
And I want to assign
a password to that user.

59
00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:54.050
So I can say passwd user1.

60
00:02:54.050 --> 00:02:56.320
And it's gonna ask me to pick a password.

61
00:02:56.320 --> 00:02:59.260
Now I'm gonna put in the word password,
all lower case.

62
00:03:00.320 --> 00:03:01.810
And I get bad password.

63
00:03:01.810 --> 00:03:05.110
The password fails a dictionary check,
right?

64
00:03:05.110 --> 00:03:07.294
So this password is not complex enough.

65
00:03:07.294 --> 00:03:09.680
It's just too easy to guess.

66
00:03:09.680 --> 00:03:14.204
It's a word straight out of
the dictionary and that's it, right?

67
00:03:14.204 --> 00:03:19.315
If I would've put in something
like 12345678 right well,

68
00:03:19.315 --> 00:03:21.509
I get password's unmatched.

69
00:03:21.509 --> 00:03:24.960
So if I punch in 12345678,
I get that it fails the dictionary test.

70
00:03:24.960 --> 00:03:28.860
It's not that it's a dictionary word,
I just did one through eight, right,

71
00:03:28.860 --> 00:03:32.090
it's just that it's too simplistic, and
you can see that little note right there.

72
00:03:32.090 --> 00:03:33.290
Or it's systematic.

73
00:03:33.290 --> 00:03:35.970
It follows some kind of
easily recognizable pattern.

74
00:03:35.970 --> 00:03:38.880
So the distro is kinda
protecting me from this.

75
00:03:38.880 --> 00:03:43.430
Protecting me from you know using
this weak password in the system.

76
00:03:43.430 --> 00:03:47.860
But it doesn't take much, to navigate
a way from a dictionary attack.

77
00:03:47.860 --> 00:03:54.350
And in fact, if i go in and
type 12345678 again, see what I did?

78
00:03:54.350 --> 00:03:57.070
It let me assign it so it's

79
00:03:57.070 --> 00:04:00.940
letting me put in this weak password even
though it's warning me that it's weak.

80
00:04:00.940 --> 00:04:02.970
It let me do it anyway.

81
00:04:02.970 --> 00:04:05.950
And that's what happens with a lot
of distros that are out there.

82
00:04:05.950 --> 00:04:08.710
They don't enforce
the password restrictions.

83
00:04:08.710 --> 00:04:14.230
Now I just created a user and
that user has a weak password and

84
00:04:14.230 --> 00:04:16.460
I don't necessarily know that
as an administrator right?

85
00:04:16.460 --> 00:04:21.670
So I need to create a policy that kind
of teaches them to become more secure.

86
00:04:21.670 --> 00:04:23.410
And I'm gonna start with password age.

87
00:04:23.410 --> 00:04:28.280
The chage command is the first step
in creating a good security policy.

88
00:04:28.280 --> 00:04:30.010
I can apply restrictions on to that user.

89
00:04:30.010 --> 00:04:33.449
They say your password can only be so
many days old and it has to be reset.

90
00:04:33.449 --> 00:04:35.200
>> Mm-hm.

91
00:04:35.200 --> 00:04:37.630
>> If you pull up the main page, there's
a lot of good information in there but

92
00:04:37.630 --> 00:04:39.580
the basics of the command work like this.

93
00:04:39.580 --> 00:04:43.480
I can say chage -l followed by a user.

94
00:04:43.480 --> 00:04:48.117
So I'll do user1 and it's gonna show
me what they're currently set at.

95
00:04:48.117 --> 00:04:52.150
Here's where I can see how long it's been
since the user changed their password.

96
00:04:52.150 --> 00:04:56.120
And when I look at this user, password
never expires, right, so that means they

97
00:04:56.120 --> 00:05:00.340
can have the same password as long as
they want and it's never going to expire.

98
00:05:00.340 --> 00:05:02.160
Number of days between password change, 0.

99
00:05:02.160 --> 00:05:08.063
Number of days between, or maximum number
of days between password change 99999.

100
00:05:08.063 --> 00:05:11.778
This is set to several decades right?

101
00:05:11.778 --> 00:05:13.750
>> Good.
>> So the user is not going to be required

102
00:05:13.750 --> 00:05:15.134
to change that password.

103
00:05:15.134 --> 00:05:20.030
Never going to expire and number of
days of warning before expire, 7 days.

104
00:05:20.030 --> 00:05:21.973
Before 100,000 days from now.

105
00:05:21.973 --> 00:05:23.135
[LAUGH] So 999,990 days.

106
00:05:23.135 --> 00:05:27.998
>> We do have a magic elixir by then,
so you'll be fine.

107
00:05:27.998 --> 00:05:32.902
>> Yeah, so they'll get a warning so
I can see right here this is just

108
00:05:32.902 --> 00:05:36.751
not really enforcing
anything great on this user.

109
00:05:36.751 --> 00:05:39.910
They got a weak password and
they can use it forever now.

110
00:05:39.910 --> 00:05:45.260
So I can say chage and
then I can specify a minimum day and

111
00:05:45.260 --> 00:05:47.380
a maximum day that I want
this password to survive.

112
00:05:47.380 --> 00:05:50.010
Now the maximum days is what
we normally think of right?

113
00:05:50.010 --> 00:05:52.480
I want them to change their
passwords every 90 days.

114
00:05:52.480 --> 00:05:55.670
Every three months, you've got to change
your password that's not too bad.

115
00:05:55.670 --> 00:05:58.530
You do it every one month you'll really
annoy the users that they'll start writing

116
00:05:58.530 --> 00:06:01.720
it on post-it notes, if you do it too
long you start to lose the effectiveness.

117
00:06:01.720 --> 00:06:03.175
So you've got to find a happy medium.

118
00:06:03.175 --> 00:06:05.240
I'm gonna say 90 days, right.

119
00:06:05.240 --> 00:06:09.201
Now a capital M is the maximum days,
you can do a lower case m,

120
00:06:09.201 --> 00:06:13.420
which is the minimum days and
I'm gonna set my minimum day to 1.

121
00:06:13.420 --> 00:06:16.980
If they change their password,
they have to use that password for

122
00:06:16.980 --> 00:06:19.061
at least 24 hours, right, 1 day.

123
00:06:19.061 --> 00:06:22.110
Now, why would I set a minimum?

124
00:06:22.110 --> 00:06:25.320
Well, you don't want somebody
rapidly changing their password,

125
00:06:25.320 --> 00:06:27.720
we might set a password reuse policy,

126
00:06:27.720 --> 00:06:33.410
this is you can't re-use the password for
five iterations, right?

127
00:06:33.410 --> 00:06:37.125
So they have to use five different
passwords before they can go back and

128
00:06:37.125 --> 00:06:38.460
re-use the first one.

129
00:06:38.460 --> 00:06:42.502
Well, if I've got a 90 day password
expiration, three months, and they can't

130
00:06:42.502 --> 00:06:46.508
reuse the password for five iterations,
that means 50 months for that to go by.

131
00:06:46.508 --> 00:06:51.380
Or a little over a year before they can
go back and reuse that first password.

132
00:06:51.380 --> 00:06:54.747
But if I don't set a minimum password
interval here, they could just say,

133
00:06:54.747 --> 00:06:56.838
all right,
it's time to change my password.

134
00:06:56.838 --> 00:07:00.899
I'm gonna change it five times, and
just change it over and over and over,

135
00:07:00.899 --> 00:07:05.110
until they can get back to their original
password to beat that reuse policy.

136
00:07:05.110 --> 00:07:08.580
So by setting a minimum of one day,
they would have to reset it once a day for

137
00:07:08.580 --> 00:07:10.350
five days to be able to
get all the way back and

138
00:07:10.350 --> 00:07:13.550
that would annoy them as much as
anything so that's not gonna happen.

139
00:07:13.550 --> 00:07:18.390
So I'm setting a minimum of 1 day and
a maximum of 90 days.

140
00:07:18.390 --> 00:07:20.690
I can set an expiration day and

141
00:07:20.690 --> 00:07:25.040
this is really handy cuz in this case,
I made up this user's password.

142
00:07:25.040 --> 00:07:28.010
And if I'm gonna give this account
to the user, and I say hey,

143
00:07:28.010 --> 00:07:33.010
your password's 12345678, then they
might use that password for 90 days.

144
00:07:33.010 --> 00:07:33.970
And I might not want that.

145
00:07:33.970 --> 00:07:36.920
I could say -e and
expire the password tomorrow.

146
00:07:36.920 --> 00:07:38.730
And so nope,
that password's gonna expire tomorrow.

147
00:07:38.730 --> 00:07:41.130
You've got to change it by
the end of the day tomorrow.

148
00:07:41.130 --> 00:07:43.830
And you would just say -e and
then specify a date.

149
00:07:43.830 --> 00:07:47.090
And you kinda see how that
date format is up there.

150
00:07:47.090 --> 00:07:49.360
But you can put the date in
in several different formats.

151
00:07:49.360 --> 00:07:53.479
I'll just say August 22, 2017.

152
00:07:53.479 --> 00:07:56.295
And I don't think this one needs the time
interval, so I'll leave that out.

153
00:07:56.295 --> 00:07:59.879
Sometimes they need the hour,
minute, second interval as well.

154
00:07:59.879 --> 00:08:03.101
And then lastly, I can set the warn days.

155
00:08:03.101 --> 00:08:06.380
I want to warn the user,
after a certain period of time has passed,

156
00:08:06.380 --> 00:08:08.440
that they need to change their password.

157
00:08:08.440 --> 00:08:09.750
And I'll stick with seven days,
that's fine.

158
00:08:09.750 --> 00:08:13.740
So if their password normally
would expire in 90 days,

159
00:08:13.740 --> 00:08:17.720
in 83 days they'll start getting a warning
every time they log in that it's about

160
00:08:17.720 --> 00:08:18.890
time to change their password.

161
00:08:18.890 --> 00:08:21.170
Hopefully we encourage them
to change the password early.

162
00:08:21.170 --> 00:08:25.853
And then after that I just specify the
user, and then I'll reach in and do it.

163
00:08:25.853 --> 00:08:28.053
It looks like I messed up
the date on this one, so

164
00:08:28.053 --> 00:08:30.538
it's complaining a little
bit about my option here.

165
00:08:30.538 --> 00:08:37.480
Invalid date Aug, so let me just put
that in as just a standard date.

166
00:08:37.480 --> 00:08:42.297
I'll do 09/22/2017, there we go,
that'll make it happy.

167
00:08:42.297 --> 00:08:46.020
All right,
now that I've got that assigned,

168
00:08:46.020 --> 00:08:49.950
I can verify it with that chage-l user1.

169
00:08:49.950 --> 00:08:54.530
And I can look, and now I can see
the last password change was today.

170
00:08:54.530 --> 00:08:56.815
I can see the password
expires November 19th, so

171
00:08:56.815 --> 00:09:01.400
that's 90 days from now,
the password has never been inactive.

172
00:09:01.400 --> 00:09:03.730
I can see the account
expires September 22nd.

173
00:09:03.730 --> 00:09:08.270
Shoot, I put in 9/22 instead of 8/22,
I forgot what month I was in.

174
00:09:08.270 --> 00:09:11.570
So it's gonna expire a month from now,
but we can fix that easy enough.

175
00:09:11.570 --> 00:09:13.000
Let me go back in here and change.

176
00:09:14.550 --> 00:09:17.421
See, if I paid more attention in
elementary school and learned my months.

177
00:09:17.421 --> 00:09:19.160
>> I thought you were testing us,
actually [LAUGH].

178
00:09:19.160 --> 00:09:20.970
>> Well, let's do it that way.

179
00:09:20.970 --> 00:09:25.005
We always wanna do chage-l
to verify our changes.

180
00:09:25.005 --> 00:09:26.290
[LAUGH] There we go.

181
00:09:26.290 --> 00:09:29.550
So now I can see it does expire
tomorrow like I wanted it to expire.

182
00:09:29.550 --> 00:09:33.210
And then the number of days between
changes has been set the way I want.

183
00:09:33.210 --> 00:09:36.382
So now I've got that password policy,
I've got it put in place.

184
00:09:36.382 --> 00:09:42.190
And I know that User1 will be changing
their password every 90 days, like I want.

185
00:09:42.190 --> 00:09:44.850
>> Now Don,
actually a couple of questions for you.

186
00:09:44.850 --> 00:09:47.260
I worked for a company that
they had that password change,

187
00:09:47.260 --> 00:09:48.960
it was every three months.

188
00:09:48.960 --> 00:09:52.740
