Audit the passwords.

546
00:26:28.020 --> 00:26:31.310
Everything I've done here is focused
really on local Linux user accounts,

547
00:26:31.310 --> 00:26:35.170
which is great cuz these are what we use,
but if you've got a directory service

548
00:26:35.170 --> 00:26:37.550
be aware that we're not going
to catch them this way.

549
00:26:37.550 --> 00:26:40.270
We need to get the data out
of the directory service.

550
00:26:40.270 --> 00:26:40.970
And you can use the same tool.

551
00:26:40.970 --> 00:26:42.820
It 's just that you get the data
from a different place.

552
00:26:42.820 --> 00:26:46.301
So, remember that we focused on local
passwords, there are other passwords that

553
00:26:46.301 --> 00:26:48.770
are out there you need to
be concerned about as well.

554
00:26:48.770 --> 00:26:49.700
>> Fantastic Don.

555
00:26:49.700 --> 00:26:53.330
I really have enjoyed these couple
of episodes.they were amazing.

556
00:26:53.330 --> 00:26:54.150
Well, they're all amazing!

557
00:26:54.150 --> 00:26:58.110
In fact you should watch every
episode of Linux Security Techniques,

558
00:26:58.110 --> 00:27:00.070
cuz you'll be very glad you did.

559
00:27:00.070 --> 00:27:01.540
And thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

560
00:27:01.540 --> 00:27:03.910
Remember, a good IT Pro
is always learning.

561
00:27:03.910 --> 00:27:04.960
I'm Zach Memos.

562
00:27:04.960 --> 00:27:05.470
>> I'm Don Pezet.

563
00:27:05.470 --> 00:27:06.460
>> And we will see you soon.

564
00:27:06.460 --> 00:27:13.650
[MUSIC]

565
00:27:13.650 --> 00:27:17.088
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover how we get our system setup to audit file access, how we can see if it is already running (auditd), auditctl, audit folders for access, how to make the rules persistent, and how we review the audit logs.
episodes.title: Auditing the Filesystem
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.515
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:06.515 --> 00:00:08.141
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.141 --> 00:00:10.591
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

4
00:00:12.420 --> 00:00:13.260
>> Hello, and thanking for

5
00:00:13.260 --> 00:00:17.940
watching ITProTV, helping you learn
wherever you go, I'm your host Zach Memos.

6
00:00:17.940 --> 00:00:20.860
As we continue with Linux
security techniques we're

7
00:00:20.860 --> 00:00:25.490
gonna be auditing the file system today,
who's gonna show us how to do that?

8
00:00:25.490 --> 00:00:28.120
Who's gonna do that, I know,
Don Pezet, he's right over here.

9
00:00:28.120 --> 00:00:29.800
Don, good to see you again, sir.

10
00:00:29.800 --> 00:00:30.830
>> Thanks for having me back, Zach.

11
00:00:30.830 --> 00:00:34.340
And in this episode we are gonna be taking
a look at auditing the file system,

12
00:00:34.340 --> 00:00:38.470
this is a really important technique that
we can use to help secure our systems.

13
00:00:38.470 --> 00:00:42.280
A lot of security, it kinda falls into
two camps, either being proactive or

14
00:00:42.280 --> 00:00:43.640
being reactive.

15
00:00:43.640 --> 00:00:46.696
And being proactive is where we try and
stop attacks, and exploits, and

16
00:00:46.696 --> 00:00:48.313
things like that before they happen.

17
00:00:48.313 --> 00:00:51.171
Reactive is, well,
reacting after the attack and

18
00:00:51.171 --> 00:00:53.633
taking some kind of
response to correct it.

19
00:00:53.633 --> 00:00:58.593
Well in order for us to be reactive we
need to know that an attack happened,

20
00:00:58.593 --> 00:01:02.833
and the way we can know an attack
happened is we are proactive and

21
00:01:02.833 --> 00:01:05.380
set up some kind of monitoring.

22
00:01:05.380 --> 00:01:09.240
We need to be monitoring our file system,
monitoring the accesses occurring on our

23
00:01:09.240 --> 00:01:12.630
system, so that we have a record so
that we can tell whether or

24
00:01:12.630 --> 00:01:16.530
not somebody has gotten into resources
they shouldn't have been able to get into.

25
00:01:16.530 --> 00:01:20.610
Or if you find out you've been hacked,
let's go worst case scenario,

26
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:24.410
that an attacker defaces your website.

27
00:01:24.410 --> 00:01:28.832
So you come into work one day and your
website, your homepage for your company,

28
00:01:28.832 --> 00:01:30.945
now has all sorts of crazy stuff on it.

29
00:01:30.945 --> 00:01:33.640
Well you know you've been compromised so
you don't really need an alert system for

30
00:01:33.640 --> 00:01:35.462
that, you can kind of see it
right there on the webpage.

31
00:01:35.462 --> 00:01:38.255
You know it's been compromised,
well how do you clean it up,

32
00:01:38.255 --> 00:01:40.040
how do you recover from that?

33
00:01:40.040 --> 00:01:41.180
You need to find out what's been changed,

34
00:01:41.180 --> 00:01:44.800
you need to find out what files have been
accessed, what files have been changed.

35
00:01:44.800 --> 00:01:48.190
Has your customer data been leaked,
has somebody gained access to that?

36
00:01:48.190 --> 00:01:53.037
You need a record, and unfortunately a lot
of Linux distributions don't create that

37
00:01:53.037 --> 00:01:55.863
record, they just don't
have that available and

38
00:01:55.863 --> 00:02:00.662
as a result you're left guessing was my
customer data compromised, I don't know.

39
00:02:00.662 --> 00:02:04.658
So in this episode what I wanna do is I
wanna show you guys a technique that we

40
00:02:04.658 --> 00:02:08.719
can use inside of pretty much every
Linux distro to actually audit that file

41
00:02:08.719 --> 00:02:13.231
system access to keep track of who touched
what file when, and that way we know these

42
00:02:13.231 --> 00:02:17.253
are the files that were affected by
a particular compromise or whatever.

43
00:02:17.253 --> 00:02:19.511
So that's what we're gonna take
a look at right here in this episode.

44
00:02:19.511 --> 00:02:21.001
>> So you have me very intrigued.

45
00:02:21.001 --> 00:02:23.764
So how do we get our system
set up to audit file access?

46
00:02:23.764 --> 00:02:24.328
>> All right,

47
00:02:24.328 --> 00:02:28.116
the main thing that we need is a simple
service that's called the audit daemon.

48
00:02:28.116 --> 00:02:31.613
The audit daemon runs in the background
and it tracks file access, and

49
00:02:31.613 --> 00:02:35.108
when people access those files,
it can actually do more than files but

50
00:02:35.108 --> 00:02:37.833
we're gonna use it here for
files in this episode, but

51
00:02:37.833 --> 00:02:41.233
when it tracks that file access it
logs it through the audit system.

52
00:02:41.233 --> 00:02:42.884
Just like SELinux has an audit log,

53
00:02:42.884 --> 00:02:46.380
here we have the file system log
that the audit daemon is powering.

54
00:02:46.380 --> 00:02:48.820
So you may already have it,

55
00:02:48.820 --> 00:02:52.200
this could be one of those super
easy simple ones to get configured.

56
00:02:52.200 --> 00:02:55.800
So for example if you have Red Hat
Enterprise Linux, what I'm using for

57
00:02:55.800 --> 00:02:57.870
my servers, it's already got it,

58
00:02:57.870 --> 00:03:01.520
the auto daemon is installed and
enabled by default.

59
00:03:01.520 --> 00:03:04.571
But on a lot of distros it isn't and so
you'll need to get it installed, and

60
00:03:04.571 --> 00:03:06.763
fortunately it's really easy
to get it up and going.

61
00:03:06.763 --> 00:03:11.388
So for example if you're on a Red Hat
based system like Cintas you

62
00:03:11.388 --> 00:03:14.729
would say yum install audit,
just like that,

63
00:03:14.729 --> 00:03:18.667
if I was on Fedora I would make
that a DNF instead of yum,

64
00:03:18.667 --> 00:03:23.632
if I was on a Ubuntu or Debian system
I would say apt get install audit,

65
00:03:23.632 --> 00:03:27.946
the name of the package is
pretty much the same everywhere.

66
00:03:27.946 --> 00:03:32.783
I have seen some versions of Ubuntu
where for whatever reason they called it

67
00:03:32.783 --> 00:03:37.157
the audit-service, so if you try and
do an install of just audit and

68
00:03:37.157 --> 00:03:41.991
it doesn't pick it up maybe try adding
-service to the end or just do a quick

69
00:03:41.991 --> 00:03:47.710
search like an app-get-list-audit-* and
just see kinda what's out there.

70
00:03:47.710 --> 00:03:50.129
But for the most part its
usually just called audit and

71
00:03:50.129 --> 00:03:52.134
you can have that
installed in a heartbeat.

72
00:03:52.134 --> 00:03:55.074
My system I've already got it so
if I try and install that,

73
00:03:55.074 --> 00:03:57.234
which actually I need to sudo this anyway,

74
00:03:57.234 --> 00:04:00.775
then when I go to install it's just
gonna tell me it's already there.

75
00:04:00.775 --> 00:04:04.800
It's already there, and
is it already running?

76
00:04:04.800 --> 00:04:07.567
Well it actually is in Red Hat but
it may not be on yours, so

77
00:04:07.567 --> 00:04:09.021
we need to double check that.

78
00:04:09.021 --> 00:04:14.301
And you can double check that pretty easy
just by doing a quick system ctl status

79
00:04:14.301 --> 00:04:19.683
auditd, and so I'm gonna check for
that audit daemon and see if it's running.

80
00:04:19.683 --> 00:04:21.365
I can see mine's active and running, and

81
00:04:21.365 --> 00:04:23.767
this is a pretty clean install
of Red Hat Enterprise Linux,

82
00:04:23.767 --> 00:04:26.987
if you've been watching this show then
you've seen everything that I've done

83
00:04:26.987 --> 00:04:30.210
to this particular server cuz I've
been using it throughout the show.

84
00:04:30.210 --> 00:04:34.060
But auditd is already up and running,
and the main reason is because we've got

85
00:04:34.060 --> 00:04:38.920
SELinux and SELinux needs to use auto logs
and so it's all tied into the same system.

86
00:04:38.920 --> 00:04:41.390
If you're using Ubuntu though
you don't have SELinux, and

87
00:04:41.390 --> 00:04:45.870
so you don't have audit except in
certain installation packages.

88
00:04:45.870 --> 00:04:47.630
So getting it installed not a big deal,

89
00:04:47.630 --> 00:04:52.476
getting it turned on is like any other
service we can say system ctl and

90
00:04:52.476 --> 00:04:57.410
then just enable auditd to enable it and
then start,

91
00:04:57.410 --> 00:05:02.750
or you can do a --now to go ahead enable
and start it all at the same time and

92
00:05:02.750 --> 00:05:05.140
that's gonna get that up and
going and get us in business.

93
00:05:05.140 --> 00:05:08.077
So once that's done now we're up and
running auditd and

94
00:05:08.077 --> 00:05:11.370
we're ready to actually
start auditing access.

95
00:05:11.370 --> 00:05:14.090
It has a default configuration
file that's read which I

96
00:05:14.090 --> 00:05:14.990
haven't really looked at here.

97
00:05:14.990 --> 00:05:19.360
If I go into /etc/audit I get permission
denied, and that's because auditing

98
00:05:19.360 --> 00:05:24.177
is very critical infrastructure, right, we
don't want just regular end users going in

99
00:05:24.177 --> 00:05:27.904
and seeing what's being monitored or
even trying to modify that, so

100
00:05:27.904 --> 00:05:31.722
I will need to be an administrator
to see that default configuration.

101
00:05:31.722 --> 00:05:34.417
I'm gonna just bump up my whole shell,
I'd do a sudo-s.

102
00:05:34.417 --> 00:05:35.441
>> That's what I was gonna say do a sudo,
yeah.

103
00:05:35.441 --> 00:05:37.837
>> Yeah, cuz otherwise I'm gonna have
to sudo every single command for

104
00:05:37.837 --> 00:05:39.320
the rest of the show.

105
00:05:39.320 --> 00:05:43.720
But I'm gonna do that and
just jump into /etc/audit, and

106
00:05:43.720 --> 00:05:48.850
right in there you'll see this auditd.com,
that's the default configuration.

107
00:05:48.850 --> 00:05:52.350
And you may actually be fine with the
default configuration, the odds are you

108
00:05:52.350 --> 00:05:55.260
won't be though, that you'll want
to add custom rules and things.

109
00:05:55.260 --> 00:06:00.510
But if we take a look at what's
in there you'll see that it's

110
00:06:00.510 --> 00:06:05.870
got a lot of options, a lot of things that
we can tweak, and change, and configure.

111
00:06:05.870 --> 00:06:09.820
You might be okay with the defaults but
you, again, might not.

112
00:06:09.820 --> 00:06:11.980
Some of the things that you might
wanna change, if you look around,

113
00:06:11.980 --> 00:06:14.270
are things like where
the log file is stored.

114
00:06:14.270 --> 00:06:17.110
And the default is
/var/log/audit/audit.log,

115
00:06:17.110 --> 00:06:21.130
and if you watched our
SELinux episode you know

116
00:06:21.130 --> 00:06:23.630
we dug into that file quite a bit
to find our SELinux entries.

117
00:06:23.630 --> 00:06:26.580
So that's where it's stored by default,
you could move it somewhere else, or

118
00:06:26.580 --> 00:06:28.030
you could give it a different name,

119
00:06:28.030 --> 00:06:31.430
you can specify the group that
log is gonna be owned by.

120
00:06:31.430 --> 00:06:35.280
Whether you write a log at all, you don't
have to, not a whole lot of point in doing

121
00:06:35.280 --> 00:06:38.150
this if you're not gonna write
the logs but you can choose not to.

122
00:06:38.150 --> 00:06:41.530
The log format, the way that it's
gonna store the file format,

123
00:06:41.530 --> 00:06:44.740
these are all things that you can
kind of tailor and customize.

124
00:06:44.740 --> 00:06:47.920
But the main ones that I usually pay
attention to are these guys right here,

125
00:06:47.920 --> 00:06:51.960
the maximum log file, right, how many log
files we can create, cuz if we have log

126
00:06:51.960 --> 00:06:54.910
rotate it's gonna be rotating out logs so
they don't get too big.

127
00:06:54.910 --> 00:06:58.330
Well these are security logs,
you may wanna maintain them for a long,

128
00:06:58.330 --> 00:07:02.050
long time, so you may need to get in
here and tweak how many maximum logs you

129
00:07:02.050 --> 00:07:05.800
keep to set that data retention for
you as you need.

130
00:07:05.800 --> 00:07:09.250
And down here we'll see
the max log file action,

131
00:07:09.250 --> 00:07:13.750
if the log file gets full what does it do,
it rotates and it's gonna rotate

132
00:07:13.750 --> 00:07:17.070
eight times before it starts overwriting
with this default configuration.

133
00:07:17.070 --> 00:07:18.500
So you may need to tweak these or

134
00:07:18.500 --> 00:07:22.582
change them, each of these options in
here is really kind of built around that.

135
00:07:22.582 --> 00:07:25.945
If you're just trying to get
basic auditing in place and

136
00:07:25.945 --> 00:07:30.170
you're sending to a remote syslog server
you may be storing data forever on

137
00:07:30.170 --> 00:07:32.820
the remote syslog server so
only having eight days of activity, or

138
00:07:32.820 --> 00:07:36.320
eight logs of activity,
right here is probably enough, and so

139
00:07:36.320 --> 00:07:39.580
you may just stick with this default
configuration and let it run.

140
00:07:39.580 --> 00:07:42.500
But just be aware that each of
these can kinda be tweaked and

141
00:07:42.500 --> 00:07:45.852
tailored to dictate how the audit
daemon is gonna handle that log.

142
00:07:45.852 --> 00:07:49.390
Now nothing in here actually has
to deal with what's being audited,

143
00:07:49.390 --> 00:07:53.182
right, that's something that we're
absolutely gonna have to change.

144
00:07:53.182 --> 00:07:56.313
Everybody is gonna pick and
choose what's gonna be audited.

145
00:07:56.313 --> 00:08:01.620
This is really just how the daemon is
working, how it's tracking it's logs.

146
00:08:01.620 --> 00:08:04.910
So, most people do leave this
at the default, and then go and

147
00:08:04.910 --> 00:08:06.910
customize what you're
actually tracking afterwards.

148
00:08:06.910 --> 00:08:07.910
So there's a lot more work to do.

149
00:08:07.910 --> 00:08:11.330
But as far as the basic configuration,
this is pretty good.

150
00:08:11.330 --> 00:08:12.530
It's already up and running.

151
00:08:12.530 --> 00:08:14.850
In my case,
I don't really have to do much.

152
00:08:14.850 --> 00:08:18.200
So the daemon is done and
now I'm able to track access.

153
00:08:18.200 --> 00:08:21.470
So once again,
how can we see if it's still running?

154
00:08:21.470 --> 00:08:24.530
>> So the main way,
kinda what I did a moment ago,

155
00:08:24.530 --> 00:08:29.000
was systemctl status and
then pulled up the audit d.

156
00:08:29.000 --> 00:08:30.870
So I can see that it's up and
it's running.

157
00:08:30.870 --> 00:08:32.110
>> Right.
>> But there's other ways that I

158
00:08:32.110 --> 00:08:32.670
could have done this.

159
00:08:32.670 --> 00:08:35.910
So for example, when we interact
with the audit command, or

160
00:08:35.910 --> 00:08:40.580
the audit daemon, I don't normally
go directly to the log file.

161
00:08:40.580 --> 00:08:42.780
We actually have a collection
of utilities we can use,

162
00:08:42.780 --> 00:08:45.780
and I haven't used these in the other
shows to try to keep things simple,

163
00:08:45.780 --> 00:08:47.760
but now is the time to
take a look at them.

164
00:08:47.760 --> 00:08:48.440
>> Yeah.

165
00:08:48.440 --> 00:08:51.604
>> So we have a utility called auditctl.

166
00:08:51.604 --> 00:08:54.176
Like you have systemctl,
and journalctl, and

167
00:08:54.176 --> 00:08:58.292
all these other commands that kind of
came along with the system D movement,

168
00:08:58.292 --> 00:09:02.103
we have auditctl and that let'sus talk and
control the audit daemon.

169
00:09:02.103 --> 00:09:07.660
And you can run auditctl-S
to get a quick status.

170
00:09:07.660 --> 00:09:11.340
And if I only clear that out so
we can see it kinda clean here.

171
00:09:11.340 --> 00:09:14.260
What we can see right here is real quick,
is it enabled?

172
00:09:14.260 --> 00:09:15.020
Yes or no.

173
00:09:15.020 --> 00:09:18.400
Is it turned on and
do I have a rate limit assigned?

174
00:09:18.400 --> 00:09:19.630
Is there a backlog?

175
00:09:19.630 --> 00:09:21.030
Is it healthy?

176
00:09:21.030 --> 00:09:22.950
And what I'm seeing right
here is healthy information.

177
00:09:22.950 --> 00:09:26.250
I can see that audit d is
running its process Id 733.

178
00:09:26.250 --> 00:09:30.310
It's enabled, it's up and it's running,
and there's currently no back log with no

179
00:09:30.310 --> 00:09:33.600
lost values, everything's up and
running healthy.

180
00:09:33.600 --> 00:09:37.340
So that's another way we kinda quickly
take a look and see if it's running.

181
00:09:37.340 --> 00:09:41.240
If you run auditctl and you get command
not found, that's a good indicator that

182
00:09:41.240 --> 00:09:44.478
you haven't installed the audit daemon or
that it's not a part of your.

183
00:09:44.478 --> 00:09:46.129
So you need to get that installed.

184
00:09:46.129 --> 00:09:47.367
But I can see that status.

185
00:09:47.367 --> 00:09:52.090
I can go a little bit further and
say auditctl-l to get a list of the rules.

186
00:09:52.090 --> 00:09:54.140
Now, we haven't see the rules yet.

187
00:09:54.140 --> 00:09:57.410
That config file,
it just had tweaks for the daemon.

188
00:09:57.410 --> 00:10:01.140
Little knobs to adjust how much
log information we retain and

189
00:10:01.140 --> 00:10:02.650
things like that.

190
00:10:02.650 --> 00:10:05.980
But -l will show me
the actual audit rules.

191
00:10:05.980 --> 00:10:10.620
And the rules are what it's
actually keeping track of.

192
00:10:10.620 --> 00:10:13.030
And I get no rules.

193
00:10:13.030 --> 00:10:17.330
So this is how I know that auditd is
running, but it hasn't been set up.

194
00:10:18.330 --> 00:10:20.410
And that's not entirely true.

195
00:10:20.410 --> 00:10:22.255
auditd can monitor a lot of stuff.

196
00:10:22.255 --> 00:10:25.240
It's being used for SELinux's reporting.

197
00:10:25.240 --> 00:10:30.210
You can use it to monitor user changes, so
if a user account gets put into a group,

198
00:10:30.210 --> 00:10:32.080
we can audit and we can track that.

199
00:10:32.080 --> 00:10:36.380
But on the file system, we need to tell

had a hard time actually finding that

423
00:22:11.152 --> 00:22:11.980
audit log file.

424
00:22:11.980 --> 00:22:15.258
And that's because I don't normally go
right to the audit log file like this.

425
00:22:15.258 --> 00:22:18.880
If we wanna look in and
find these logs, and actually,

426
00:22:18.880 --> 00:22:23.830
retrieve information, I usually use
another command called ausearch,

427
00:22:23.830 --> 00:22:25.450
which is the audit search command.

428
00:22:25.450 --> 00:22:28.153
It lets us search that log, you don't
have to know where the audit logs are.

429
00:22:28.153 --> 00:22:32.354
You can just run this and find the
information that you're looking to pull

430
00:22:32.354 --> 00:22:35.030
that back and not have to sift through it.

431
00:22:35.030 --> 00:22:38.612
And see how you can do a -k to search for
a key.

432
00:22:38.612 --> 00:22:43.778
And so I can say, if I suspect somebody
changed the website, let me go in and

433
00:22:43.778 --> 00:22:49.390
do an audit search with -k and specify
that I'm looking for website_changes.

434
00:22:49.390 --> 00:22:52.358
Or I'm looking for employees_csv.

435
00:22:52.358 --> 00:22:56.860
And now, I can search by that key and
find exactly what I'm looking for.

436
00:22:56.860 --> 00:23:01.053
And If I forget the key,
I can always do auditctl -l.

437
00:23:01.053 --> 00:23:03.930
I can look at the rules and
I can find the key right there.

438
00:23:03.930 --> 00:23:06.540
I need to find out who changed
this website, all right?

439
00:23:06.540 --> 00:23:11.300
I've got a key called website writes, and
so I can use that to look in and find it.

440
00:23:11.300 --> 00:23:15.170
I can say that I wanna do a ausearch and

441
00:23:18.025 --> 00:23:21.425
I'll do a -k website writes.

442
00:23:21.425 --> 00:23:24.825
And it's gonna look through, and
it's gonna give me just those records.

443
00:23:24.825 --> 00:23:27.495
So now, I don't have to sift through
the log files or even know where it is.

444
00:23:27.495 --> 00:23:28.985
Now, I do need to be
an administrator to do this.

445
00:23:28.985 --> 00:23:31.491
Remember, I elevated
the privileges of my shell, so

446
00:23:31.491 --> 00:23:33.283
you'd need to pseudo this normally.

447
00:23:33.283 --> 00:23:35.491
But I can see the entries in here.

448
00:23:35.491 --> 00:23:38.529
I've got a date and a time, so
I know exactly when this access happened.

449
00:23:38.529 --> 00:23:41.665
And then after that,
I can see what it did.

450
00:23:41.665 --> 00:23:43.669
What exactly occurred?

451
00:23:43.669 --> 00:23:48.853
I'm seeing that this is an audit
message The file that was accessed

452
00:23:48.853 --> 00:23:53.680
was /var/www/html, and
then I've got a couple of files.

453
00:23:53.680 --> 00:23:56.377
This one is .index.html.swp.

454
00:23:56.377 --> 00:23:58.010
.swp.
What's that?

455
00:23:58.010 --> 00:24:02.340
Well, I used Vi as my text editor,
and Vi creates a temporary file, so

456
00:24:02.340 --> 00:24:03.620
it created a temporary file.

457
00:24:03.620 --> 00:24:06.555
Now, if I didn't know that,
I know that, but if I didn't,

458
00:24:06.555 --> 00:24:09.147
you can actually figure it
out cuz if you look in here,

459
00:24:09.147 --> 00:24:11.762
right down here I can see
the command that was issued.

460
00:24:11.762 --> 00:24:17.090
I used /usr/bin/vi,
I can see that that was done.

461
00:24:17.090 --> 00:24:21.211
And you can see other things in here
like the user ID that executed it,

462
00:24:21.211 --> 00:24:24.340
this was done by uid0,
which was the root user.

463
00:24:24.340 --> 00:24:28.150
I have a sudo shell right now so
I'm running as root, so

464
00:24:28.150 --> 00:24:29.460
it shows that I did that.

465
00:24:29.460 --> 00:24:33.040
If I were to look at that employ csv,

466
00:24:33.040 --> 00:24:37.360
on the other hand,
that one I did as a regular old Dpezet.

467
00:24:37.360 --> 00:24:41.850
So if I go and look for that key and
find it, and look in here,

468
00:24:41.850 --> 00:24:44.910
we can go ahead and find out that
it was done by a regular user.

469
00:24:44.910 --> 00:24:47.190
In this case UID1000, right?

470
00:24:47.190 --> 00:24:50.555
And so, if I go into PASSWD and
lookup UID1000,

471
00:24:50.555 --> 00:24:53.010
I'll see that's my User ID, right?

472
00:24:53.010 --> 00:24:56.924
If I do a, I'll pull up /etc/password,

473
00:24:56.924 --> 00:25:00.855
and I'll just scrap that for 1,000.

474
00:25:00.855 --> 00:25:02.115
And there it is, Dpezet.

475
00:25:02.115 --> 00:25:05.480
So I know that I am the one
who accessed that file.

476
00:25:05.480 --> 00:25:07.880
I'm the one who cracked it open and
took a look at it.

477
00:25:07.880 --> 00:25:11.420
And this was off of
that key employees CSV.

478
00:25:11.420 --> 00:25:13.130
So I've got that record.

479
00:25:13.130 --> 00:25:16.110
I now have an audit log of that entry,
and I can see it.

480
00:25:16.110 --> 00:25:19.500
So AU search really makes that handy.

481
00:25:19.500 --> 00:25:22.970
The only problem, I shouldn't call
it a problem, the only challenge

482
00:25:22.970 --> 00:25:25.555
that we face with AU search-
>> Yeah, it's always a challenge.

483
00:25:25.555 --> 00:25:28.720
>> [LAUGH] Is it can give you
a little too much information, right?

484
00:25:28.720 --> 00:25:31.210
And so there's actually another
utility I want to show you.

485
00:25:31.210 --> 00:25:34.580
It's not critical, everything I've showed
you up to this point is really all you

486
00:25:34.580 --> 00:25:36.650
need to really get good
auditing put in place.

487
00:25:36.650 --> 00:25:39.855
But there's another
utility called AUreport.

488
00:25:39.855 --> 00:25:44.430
And AUreport lets you kind
of summarize the data.

489
00:25:44.430 --> 00:25:48.800
And remember that the audit logs can
collect a lot more than just file access.

490
00:25:48.800 --> 00:25:53.520
So when I run aureport, I'm getting
a summary of all sort of different things

491
00:25:53.520 --> 00:25:57.990
like executables that were run, files that
were accessed, and so on, a ton of data.

492
00:25:57.990 --> 00:26:02.580
But I can manipulate aureport to kinda
filter and show me different information.

493
00:26:02.580 --> 00:26:04.400
And I can do the same thing with ausearch.

494
00:26:04.400 --> 00:26:06.870
I just showed you ausearch-k, right?

495
00:26:06.870 --> 00:26:08.940
But you can go way beyond that.

496
00:26:08.940 --> 00:26:14.050
You can say ausearch -- start today.

497
00:26:14.050 --> 00:26:18.580
I could say just search today's entries,
don't go back yesterday or whatever and

498
00:26:18.580 --> 00:26:20.310
then -K whatever.

499
00:26:20.310 --> 00:26:25.570
I could say --start and
specify a date, right?

500
00:26:25.570 --> 00:26:28.870
So maybe I just wanna search for
January 1st of this

501
00:26:28.870 --> 00:26:33.460
year, and then it would go
from there forward, right?

502
00:26:33.460 --> 00:26:35.290
So this is looking back all
the way to January 1st.

503
00:26:35.290 --> 00:26:36.370
Or I could even set and end.

504
00:26:36.370 --> 00:26:43.209
I could say --end, and
then maybe I end on 01, 02, 2017.

505
00:26:43.209 --> 00:26:45.829
And, actually I think I think if
I remember right, you do have to

506
00:26:45.829 --> 00:26:49.560
put the hours, minutes and seconds on
that date in order for it to be happy.

507
00:26:49.560 --> 00:26:51.300
So I'll add that.
There we go.

508
00:26:51.300 --> 00:26:53.940
So now I'm setting a search
range on that AU search, and

509
00:26:53.940 --> 00:26:55.490
limiting it to this particular day.

510
00:26:55.490 --> 00:26:57.030
Look at this day, or this time.

511
00:26:57.030 --> 00:27:02.260
And I can continue to add dash K,
website changes, or whatever.

512
00:27:02.260 --> 00:27:04.620
And it'll start to filter and
return back that data.

513
00:27:04.620 --> 00:27:07.900
I got no changes here, so I know that
the page wasn't changed during this time.

514
00:27:07.900 --> 00:27:09.050
You start to get that information.

515
00:27:09.050 --> 00:27:10.860
AUsearch is very powerful.

516
00:27:10.860 --> 00:27:13.300
Aureport is very powerful also.

517
00:27:13.300 --> 00:27:16.660
We can do things like aureport-u.

518
00:27:16.660 --> 00:27:20.731
I want to see user data,
and I'll say --failed.

519
00:27:20.731 --> 00:27:23.115
I want to see when users
did something that failed,

520
00:27:23.115 --> 00:27:26.170
when somebody tried to do something
they weren't allowed to do.

521
00:27:26.170 --> 00:27:30.580
And then I can tell it to give me
a summary of that information.

522
00:27:30.580 --> 00:27:34.410
And so it spits it out here, and
I can see the user ID1000 did

523
00:27:34.410 --> 00:27:38.910
something 14 times apparently
that resulted in a failure.

524
00:27:40.192 --> 00:27:43.539
So Aureport, if you run auroport --help,

525
00:27:43.539 --> 00:27:48.020
you'll see there a lot of other
options in here that kind of tweak and

526
00:27:48.020 --> 00:27:52.150
change that data, like dash I for
interpretive mode.

527
00:27:52.150 --> 00:27:55.670
When I ran this command,
I'm getting back user IDs and so on.

528
00:27:55.670 --> 00:28:00.350
If I add a little -i to it, it actually
resolves the user ID to a name for me.

529
00:28:00.350 --> 00:28:06.500
And so now, I can see that it was dpezet
that's got 14 failures that are in here.

530
00:28:06.500 --> 00:28:08.770
That's another powerful one for us.

531
00:28:08.770 --> 00:28:13.440
And so we can really, you can really
get complex and get fancy with this.

532
00:28:13.440 --> 00:28:17.090
Let me just show you a more complex
example, and then we'll wrap it up.

533
00:28:17.090 --> 00:28:21.150
I might do an AU search and
limit it to just today.

534
00:28:21.150 --> 00:28:24.270
So I do a start today, right?

535
00:28:24.270 --> 00:28:29.300
And I might limit it to log in ID,
login new ID 1000.

536
00:28:29.300 --> 00:28:32.520
I just want to see entries for Dpezet.

537
00:28:32.520 --> 00:28:35.038
Maybe we just fired me.

538
00:28:35.038 --> 00:28:38.130
>> [LAUGH]
>> And you're like I wonder if

539
00:28:38.130 --> 00:28:41.390
that guy got in there and did anything
>> I don't know if that's possible.

540
00:28:41.390 --> 00:28:42.790
>> So you wonder,
did they get in there and

541
00:28:42.790 --> 00:28:44.230
do anything before they left the building?

542
00:28:44.230 --> 00:28:45.220
Let's go and find out, right?

543
00:28:45.220 --> 00:28:46.812
So I'm going to search all of the logs for
today.

544
00:28:46.812 --> 00:28:49.970
I'm going to look for that User ID, right?

545
00:28:49.970 --> 00:28:52.320
And I'm gonna output this in a raw format.

546
00:28:52.320 --> 00:28:55.916
And the reason I'm gonna output it in
a raw format is that I wanna pipe it and

547
00:28:55.916 --> 00:28:57.940
send that over to aureport, right?

548
00:28:57.940 --> 00:28:59.220
Cuz I'm gonna get a bunch of data back.

549
00:28:59.220 --> 00:29:00.920
So let's filter that through aureport and

550
00:29:00.920 --> 00:29:03.490
see if we even need to
do a detailed analysis.

551
00:29:03.490 --> 00:29:07.130
And so I can come in and
I can look for those failures.

552
00:29:07.130 --> 00:29:10.710
And pull up a summary and pull it up,
ops, apparently got a typo in there.

553
00:29:10.710 --> 00:29:14.790
And so I can look for
that data in here and basically say,

554
00:29:14.790 --> 00:29:16.720
give me just a second while I
figure out what my typo is.

555
00:29:16.720 --> 00:29:17.500
I spelled summary wrong.

556
00:29:17.500 --> 00:29:21.270
It turns out there is like extra
vowels and things, there we go.

557
00:29:21.270 --> 00:29:23.740
And so now I can pull that
information up and I can say, no,

558
00:29:23.740 --> 00:29:25.550
this user didn't access anything.

559
00:29:25.550 --> 00:29:30.190
Or I go on and like say man, they got
on and they messed with this CSV or

560
00:29:30.190 --> 00:29:32.050
some other file or wherever.

561
00:29:32.050 --> 00:29:33.930
We get an idea of what they accessed.

562
00:29:33.930 --> 00:29:37.195
I've got a record here, and I know
that command's a little bit alongside.

563
00:29:37.195 --> 00:29:41.200
But I've got a record of all
the things that user did today.

564
00:29:41.200 --> 00:29:42.050
And here it is.

565
00:29:42.050 --> 00:29:42.810
I can see it.

566
00:29:42.810 --> 00:29:45.550
Let me stretch this out so
it, kind of, there you go.

567
00:29:45.550 --> 00:29:47.580
So you see kind of the whole
command on one line there.

568
00:29:47.580 --> 00:29:50.158
I can see everything that dpezet
did today as far as file access,

569
00:29:50.158 --> 00:29:51.870
as far as what we're auditing, right?

570
00:29:51.870 --> 00:29:54.420
If you haven't turned on auditing,
then this doesn't work, right?

571
00:29:54.420 --> 00:29:59.190
But now I can see it so I know what that
user's been doing, what they've touched.

572
00:29:59.190 --> 00:29:59.870
And you can filter that.

573
00:29:59.870 --> 00:30:01.390
You can do the same thing in reverse.

574
00:30:01.390 --> 00:30:03.710
I can look at a particular
file instead of a user, and

575
00:30:03.710 --> 00:30:05.760
say show me everything that
happened to this file.

576
00:30:05.760 --> 00:30:10.180
And then, do a summary, interpret it and
lay out so it's a way that I can read it.

577
00:30:10.180 --> 00:30:11.810
That's the power of this.

578
00:30:11.810 --> 00:30:17.030
But you've gotta turn it on
before you need it, right?

579
00:30:17.030 --> 00:30:19.380
It's not like one of those things
where you say my website got hacked,

580
00:30:19.380 --> 00:30:22.320
let me go see what files they changed,
I'll turn on auditing.

581
00:30:22.320 --> 00:30:22.850
It's too late.

582
00:30:22.850 --> 00:30:23.480
>> Right.

583
00:30:23.480 --> 00:30:26.810
>> Auditing has to be on
before the compromise.

584
00:30:26.810 --> 00:30:30.950
So get this turned on, get it set up,
get familiarized with it, and

585
00:30:30.950 --> 00:30:34.030
make sure that you know how to use it so
that you can pull

586
00:30:34.030 --> 00:30:36.860
that information when you actually do need
it when you hit that critical moment.

587
00:30:36.860 --> 00:30:39.280
>> Awesome information as usual,
Don, thank you so very much.

588
00:30:39.280 --> 00:30:41.420
Auditing the file system.

589
00:30:41.420 --> 00:30:44.080
And before we move on,
any last words, sir?

590
00:30:44.080 --> 00:30:45.690
>> One quick word of caution.

591
00:30:45.690 --> 00:30:47.796
Make sure you backup your audit logs.

592
00:30:47.796 --> 00:30:49.440
Your audit logs are really important.

593
00:30:49.440 --> 00:30:51.360
And if a hacker, a good hacker,

594
00:30:51.360 --> 00:30:55.810
breaks into your system, their job number
one is to compromising your audit log.

595
00:30:55.810 --> 00:30:59.940
Because if they can compromise he audit
logs, they can hide whatever they did.

596
00:30:59.940 --> 00:31:02.530
So you need to make sure that your audit
logs are protected, which they already

597
00:31:02.530 --> 00:31:06.300
are, but that you're backing them
up to another system somewhere.

598
00:31:06.300 --> 00:31:07.350
If you haven't watched it,

599
00:31:07.350 --> 00:31:11.890
check our our RSS log show where we'll
talk about how to log to a remote system,

600
00:31:11.890 --> 00:31:15.420
and then that way your logs are stored
somewhere else as well as right here.

601
00:31:15.420 --> 00:31:17.470
So even if these get erased you
still have a copy somewhere else.

602
00:31:17.470 --> 00:31:20.350
But definitely make sure you back up
those audit logs and keep them safe.

603
00:31:20.350 --> 00:31:22.400
>> Back up, back up, back up.

604
00:31:22.400 --> 00:31:23.560
Linux Security Techniques.

605
00:31:23.560 --> 00:31:25.500
There's a lot of episodes to watch.

606
00:31:25.500 --> 00:31:28.070
Make sure you watch them all
because you'll be glad you did now.

607
00:31:28.070 --> 00:31:29.320
Help you out too.

608
00:31:29.320 --> 00:31:29.861
Thanks, Don.

609
00:31:29.861 --> 00:31:31.510
And thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

610
00:31:31.510 --> 00:31:34.340
Remember, good ITPRO is always learning.

611
00:31:34.340 --> 00:31:35.260
I'm Zach Memos.

612
00:31:35.260 --> 00:31:35.930
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

613
00:31:35.930 --> 00:31:38.734
>> And we will see you very soon.

00:21:49.657 --> 00:21:52.650
I can start spewing at various
servers trying to rude account and

463
00:21:52.650 --> 00:21:55.434
seeing if I can get in and
you'd be surprised what happens.

464
00:21:55.434 --> 00:21:58.939
So now I'll gonna comeback and
I'll do hydra,

465
00:21:58.939 --> 00:22:01.928
I'm going to use a login user of dpezet.

466
00:22:01.928 --> 00:22:05.658
I'll do 2 simultaneous tracks,
I'll say -P and

467
00:22:05.658 --> 00:22:09.315
I'm gonna point to that passlist.txt,
right?

468
00:22:09.315 --> 00:22:11.210
That's the file that I'm gonna use.

469
00:22:11.210 --> 00:22:14.443
And then lastly, I need a point to
the server that I'm gonna be attacking.

470
00:22:14.443 --> 00:22:20.843
I'm gonna attack 172.16.0.237,
and it's ssh that I'm using.

471
00:22:20.843 --> 00:22:23.954
And actually I'm still in the server,
aren't I?

472
00:22:23.954 --> 00:22:29.602
Let me copy that, and
I will get out of the server.

473
00:22:29.602 --> 00:22:31.164
There we go,
now I'm actually out of the server.

474
00:22:31.164 --> 00:22:32.998
And I'm gonna perform that attack, right?

475
00:22:32.998 --> 00:22:34.452
So let me go ahead and hit that server.

476
00:22:34.452 --> 00:22:35.756
So now hydra fires up.

477
00:22:35.756 --> 00:22:37.788
>> Right.
>> It is sending two simultaneous text.

478
00:22:37.788 --> 00:22:40.328
It's trying to long in,
it's running down that password list,

479
00:22:40.328 --> 00:22:41.396
trying to log in as dpezet.

480
00:22:41.396 --> 00:22:45.640
And what's happening, well every
three log ins, it gets disconnected.

481
00:22:45.640 --> 00:22:47.788
Hydra just reconnects, tries again, right?

482
00:22:47.788 --> 00:22:50.600
And keeps going and going and going.

483
00:22:50.600 --> 00:22:53.760
And eventually, they get to the end of
the list when it hits my actual password.

484
00:22:53.760 --> 00:22:56.192
And it'll win, it'll pop up right here
on the screen and it'll say, hey,

485
00:22:56.192 --> 00:22:57.347
we found that person's password.

486
00:22:57.347 --> 00:22:58.935
And now I can go login whenever I want.

487
00:22:58.935 --> 00:23:01.600
Well what does the user see?

488
00:23:01.600 --> 00:23:05.750
If I cancel this and
I connect back into that server,

489
00:23:05.750 --> 00:23:09.090
when I go to log in,
I'll see a message, look at this.

490
00:23:09.090 --> 00:23:12.432
There were 20 failed login attempts
since the last successful login-

491
00:23:12.432 --> 00:23:12.945
>> [LAUGH]

492
00:23:12.945 --> 00:23:13.584
>> Right?

493
00:23:13.584 --> 00:23:18.581
So in the amount of time Hydra was
running, it logged in 20 times.

494
00:23:18.581 --> 00:23:20.209
They were all failures, right?

495
00:23:20.209 --> 00:23:23.227
But it could going and going and
it wouldn't stop, right?

496
00:23:23.227 --> 00:23:25.850
Now let's try that again with,

497
00:23:25.850 --> 00:23:31.601
actually this run you a seperate tab,
cuz I'm gonna ban myself.

498
00:23:31.601 --> 00:23:32.123
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

499
00:23:32.123 --> 00:23:36.978
let's try that again and this time, we're
gonna do it with failed to ban on, right?

500
00:23:36.978 --> 00:23:39.289
So we're gonna test it to make
sure it's actually working.

501
00:23:39.289 --> 00:23:44.778
So I'm gonna get in and
I will do a systems ctl start

502
00:23:44.778 --> 00:23:49.768
fail2ban which we've configured for ssh.

503
00:23:49.768 --> 00:23:53.086
I'm gonna jump back over
to my other tab here, and

504
00:23:53.086 --> 00:23:56.171
I'm gonna fire up that attack again,
right?

505
00:23:56.171 --> 00:24:00.990
So here goes the attack, it's reaching
out and it's gonna try and login.

506
00:24:00.990 --> 00:24:04.448
And what should happen is
after a handful of attempts,

507
00:24:04.448 --> 00:24:07.693
Fail2ban will detect it,
block it, and stop it.

508
00:24:07.693 --> 00:24:10.251
And right there, see,
the attack just stopped.

509
00:24:10.251 --> 00:24:17.832
And I get this message, could not connect
to ssh://172.16.0.237, connection refused.

510
00:24:17.832 --> 00:24:19.680
The server didn't answer back.

511
00:24:19.680 --> 00:24:23.960
And if I go look at my server real quick,
if I do a firewall-cmd--list-all,

512
00:24:23.960 --> 00:24:29.200
and I take a look at my firewall rules,

513
00:24:29.200 --> 00:24:32.070
I don't really see anything
different there, right?

514
00:24:32.070 --> 00:24:33.720
I don't see like specific IPs.

515
00:24:33.720 --> 00:24:36.000
It's fail2ban getting involved.

516
00:24:36.000 --> 00:24:40.230
And so if we go back and
look at like fail2ban status,

517
00:24:40.230 --> 00:24:44.720
if we use the fail2ban -client.

518
00:24:44.720 --> 00:24:49.230
And we pull up our list which
is what I was trying to do here.

519
00:24:49.230 --> 00:24:52.360
But if we go and we pull up our status,
we pull up the status for our site,

520
00:24:52.360 --> 00:24:53.140
we'll start to see that.

521
00:24:53.140 --> 00:24:59.470
So if I say fail2ban-client status,
I can see I have one jail, which is ssh.

522
00:24:59.470 --> 00:25:05.623
And if I add sshd to the end,
I can see that I've got a filter in place.

523
00:25:05.623 --> 00:25:08.150
I've got an action, currently banned 1.

524
00:25:08.150 --> 00:25:10.300
And here's the banned IP list.

525
00:25:10.300 --> 00:25:14.470
172.16.01.1, which in my
laptop is now banned.

526
00:25:14.470 --> 00:25:18.290
And I can't connect on any IP for
new connections.

527
00:25:18.290 --> 00:25:20.010
That's why I had to open
this other tab first.

528
00:25:20.010 --> 00:25:21.690
So I would have an existing connection.

529
00:25:21.690 --> 00:25:25.740
The firewall rule applies to the ones
that come in, in the future, right?

530
00:25:25.740 --> 00:25:28.280
So fail2ban just did its job.

531
00:25:28.280 --> 00:25:31.790
It blocked that access, and
now my system is protected.

532
00:25:31.790 --> 00:25:34.890
I've effectively killed off the ability
to do brute force attacks on SSH.

533
00:25:34.890 --> 00:25:37.060
And my other services are still weak,
right?

534
00:25:37.060 --> 00:25:38.880
I still need to secure the other services.

535
00:25:38.880 --> 00:25:41.824
So I need to look at what fail2ban can
protect, and then enable those for

536
00:25:41.824 --> 00:25:44.642
the other services to release
the ones that are publicly available.

537
00:25:44.642 --> 00:25:46.500
Those are the ones that
people could brute force.

538
00:25:46.500 --> 00:25:49.670
But, at this point, it's up, it's going.

539
00:25:49.670 --> 00:25:51.900
And, yeah, this is pretty much it.

540
00:25:51.900 --> 00:25:55.040
It's not that hard to get configured
as long as you remember to configure

541
00:25:55.040 --> 00:25:57.410
the jail.local file instead of jail.com.

542
00:25:57.410 --> 00:26:01.610
>> But Don, how can we avoid
accidentally locking ourselves out?

543
00:26:01.610 --> 00:26:05.000
>> Okay, so let's say I was really worried
about that and in real life I would be.

544
00:26:05.000 --> 00:26:06.880
>> I'm worried about it right now.

545
00:26:06.880 --> 00:26:09.647
>> You'd probably want
to white list your IP.

546
00:26:09.647 --> 00:26:12.993
Okay, and you can white list
IPs right in that jail.local.

547
00:26:12.993 --> 00:26:18.498
If I edit that, /etc/fail2ban/jail.local.

548
00:26:18.498 --> 00:26:23.840
When I go in there, under default,
you can add in an entry and

549
00:26:23.840 --> 00:26:27.840
you can just say ignoreip =, and

550
00:26:27.840 --> 00:26:32.200
then punch in whatever the IP is
that you're trying to protect.

551
00:26:32.200 --> 00:26:33.860
So if I wanna do 16.0.1,

552
00:26:33.860 --> 00:26:38.000
I'd punch that in and now that one's
gonna be ignored and white listed.

553
00:26:38.000 --> 00:26:39.470
So you can add in multiple IPs.

554
00:26:39.470 --> 00:26:43.400
You might have a network scanner on your
system and you want that network scanner

555
00:26:43.400 --> 00:26:45.840
to be able to do these types of checks and
not get banned.

556
00:26:45.840 --> 00:26:47.242
You can put that in.

557
00:26:47.242 --> 00:26:50.300
So that there might be trusted IPs and
those are ones you protect.

558
00:26:50.300 --> 00:26:54.290
So that's another thing we can
configure right inside of jail.local.

559
00:26:54.290 --> 00:26:56.180
>> Awesome episode as usual, Don.

560
00:26:56.180 --> 00:26:58.870
Auditing logins with fail2ban.

561
00:26:58.870 --> 00:27:01.250
Any last words before we move on?

562
00:27:01.250 --> 00:27:03.390
>> Just remember the fail2ban is,
to my knowledge,

563
00:27:03.390 --> 00:27:05.420
not installed by default
on any major distro.

564
00:27:05.420 --> 00:27:08.960
It's usually on specialized distros,
things like FreePBX.

565
00:27:08.960 --> 00:27:11.180
But it's a great service,
really simple idea.

566
00:27:11.180 --> 00:27:13.313
Doesn't create a lot of
overhead on your server.

567
00:27:13.313 --> 00:27:17.352
So it's a neat one that you can get
enabled for any Internet facing service.

568
00:27:17.352 --> 00:27:20.634
It's a great way to just kill out
brute force attacks outright.

569
00:27:20.634 --> 00:27:25.728
And with files out there like that 10,000
most common passwords, you'd be surprised

570
00:27:25.728 --> 00:27:29.790
how many times they get a positive hit
on that, and it's not a good thing.

571
00:27:29.790 --> 00:27:32.440
So definitely something
that is easy to implement,

572
00:27:32.440 --> 00:27:34.330
and improves the security of your server.

573
00:27:34.330 --> 00:27:36.960
>> Right on, and I say it often but
better be safe than sorry.

574
00:27:36.960 --> 00:27:39.880
And that's what this whole series of
Linux security techniques was about.

575
00:27:39.880 --> 00:27:43.490
So make sure you watch every single
episode, you'll be glad you did.

576
00:27:43.490 --> 00:27:45.060
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

577
00:27:45.060 --> 00:27:48.070
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

578

I'm Zach Memos.

579
00:27:48.990 --> 00:27:49.770
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

580
00:27:49.770 --> 00:27:52.490
>> And we will see you again very soon.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.330 --> 00:00:06.040
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.040 --> 00:00:08.408
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.408 --> 00:00:12.130
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.130 --> 00:00:12.647
>> Hello and

5
00:00:12.647 --> 00:00:16.398
thank you for choosing ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.398 --> 00:00:21.275
I'm your host Zach Memos, as we continue
on with Linux security techniques.

7
00:00:21.275 --> 00:00:23.581
LUKS Disk Encryption is our episode.

8
00:00:23.581 --> 00:00:26.479
And bringing us all the information
we need is Don Pezet.

9
00:00:26.479 --> 00:00:28.143
>> [LAUGH]
>> There he is.

10
00:00:28.143 --> 00:00:28.900
>> (laughter).
>> Hey, Don.

11
00:00:28.900 --> 00:00:29.667
How are you?
>> It's me.

12
00:00:29.667 --> 00:00:35.040
[LAUGH] All right, in this episode we are
going to be tackling LUKS Disk Encryption.

13
00:00:35.040 --> 00:00:38.680
>> Which is, you know, LUKS,
another acronym for us to add to the pile.

14
00:00:38.680 --> 00:00:43.670
Disk encryption is a increasingly
important need for organizations.

15
00:00:43.670 --> 00:00:46.740
And from a security perspective,
it's something we need to address for

16
00:00:46.740 --> 00:00:48.345
any kind of mobile devices.

17
00:00:48.345 --> 00:00:50.525
Devices that could walk out of a building.

18
00:00:50.525 --> 00:00:53.675
Even some physical servers,
we have that risk.

19
00:00:53.675 --> 00:00:57.395
There was the Los Alamos Laboratories
a few years back, ten years for now,

20
00:00:57.395 --> 00:00:59.925
when someone actually stole some
hard drives out of a server.

21
00:00:59.925 --> 00:01:02.925
They found them a few days later
hidden behind a photocopier.

22
00:01:02.925 --> 00:01:05.745
Well, you know the drives have
been duplicated at that point.

23
00:01:05.745 --> 00:01:09.520
That's the risk that we have when somebody
can gain physical access to our systems.

24
00:01:09.520 --> 00:01:14.258
And doing whole disk encryption is
a great way to protect us from that.

25
00:01:14.258 --> 00:01:17.580
And so, LUKS's implementation of that
is built right into a lot of Linux

26
00:01:17.580 --> 00:01:18.670
distros that are out there.

27
00:01:18.670 --> 00:01:21.450
And in this episode we're gonna
get a chance to see how it works,

28
00:01:21.450 --> 00:01:24.867
how it does the stuff that it does and how
we can implement it to secure our data.

29
00:01:24.867 --> 00:01:27.390
So, that's what we've got right
here on our agenda today.

30
00:01:27.390 --> 00:01:30.810
>> So Don, what do we need to know about
LUKS before we get started with it?

31
00:01:30.810 --> 00:01:34.439
Alright, first off, what it stands for
is kind of a handy thing.

32
00:01:34.439 --> 00:01:39.750
The LUKS, L-U-K-S, stands for
the Linux Unified Key Setup.

33
00:01:39.750 --> 00:01:44.095
Actually the full name is
Linux Unified Key Setup on Disk Format.

34
00:01:44.095 --> 00:01:44.597
>> Mmm.

35
00:01:44.597 --> 00:01:46.858
>> Which is a little bit
more than just L-U-K-S.

36
00:01:46.858 --> 00:01:48.494
The S is Setup on Disk Format.

37
00:01:48.494 --> 00:01:53.178
[CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> Not the most graceful acronym,

38
00:01:53.178 --> 00:01:55.980
certainly, but
what it does is reallyy effective.

39
00:01:55.980 --> 00:01:56.500
Right.

40
00:01:56.500 --> 00:01:58.750
When it comes to whole disk encryption,

41
00:01:58.750 --> 00:02:01.690
there are a lot of commercial
solutions that are out there.

42
00:02:01.690 --> 00:02:04.850
But in the open source world,
there's not all that many.

43
00:02:04.850 --> 00:02:06.450
And of the ones that are out there,

44
00:02:06.450 --> 00:02:10.380
there's even fewer that have been
under a formal security review.

45
00:02:10.380 --> 00:02:14.920
There's solutions like VeraCrypt, where
security teams have taken the time to pour

46
00:02:14.920 --> 00:02:18.900
through the code, and review it to make
sure that it's safe, LUKS is one of those.

47
00:02:18.900 --> 00:02:20.030
It's been reviewed.

48
00:02:20.030 --> 00:02:21.410
It has been tested.

49
00:02:21.410 --> 00:02:23.610
And a lot of companies
have their eyes on it.

50
00:02:23.610 --> 00:02:25.590
Red Hat has dumped a lot of money into it.

51
00:02:25.590 --> 00:02:27.540
Canonical has put money into it.

52
00:02:27.540 --> 00:02:29.060
And so it's got that review.

53
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:31.590
That means that LUKS is one of the better
solutions if you wanna encrypt

54
00:02:31.590 --> 00:02:32.880
an entire disk.

55
00:02:32.880 --> 00:02:35.340
The other thing is, it's Linux native.

56
00:02:35.340 --> 00:02:38.310
Some of the other solutions that
are out there focus more on the like

57
00:02:38.310 --> 00:02:39.840
Microsoft Windows side first.

58
00:02:39.840 --> 00:02:41.770
And Linux is a bit of an afterthought.

59
00:02:41.770 --> 00:02:45.440
Here, LUKS is designed specifically for
us, right?

60
00:02:45.440 --> 00:02:48.145
So that's the first thing that
we need to know about LUKS,

61
00:02:48.145 --> 00:02:51.863
the second thing is that it works based
on keys, right, the Linux unified key-

62
00:02:51.863 --> 00:02:52.508
>> Mm-hm.

63
00:02:52.508 --> 00:02:54.480
>> Is that the lock sends for.

64
00:02:54.480 --> 00:02:58.610
So, that key part is if
I encrypt the disk, and

65
00:02:58.610 --> 00:03:03.340
somebody wants to read and use that disk,
they're going to have to have the key.

66
00:03:03.340 --> 00:03:04.740
Well, if I encrypt my system disk,

67
00:03:04.740 --> 00:03:07.240
you can't even power the computer
on without having that key.

68
00:03:07.240 --> 00:03:09.560
You got to have a key present.

69
00:03:09.560 --> 00:03:12.770
And that key, it could be stored in
like a trusted platform module, a TPM,

70
00:03:12.770 --> 00:03:13.880
on the motherboard.

71
00:03:13.880 --> 00:03:16.240
And that way, if somebody removed
the hard drives, they wouldn't work, but

72
00:03:16.240 --> 00:03:19.110
as long as the hard drives were
in that system, it would work.

73
00:03:19.110 --> 00:03:21.990
That's not really effective with
a laptop where somebody could just steal

74
00:03:21.990 --> 00:03:22.890
the whole system.

75
00:03:22.890 --> 00:03:23.480
Right?

76
00:03:23.480 --> 00:03:26.910
So the other way is that we
have it as a manual entry key.

77
00:03:26.910 --> 00:03:30.100
A key you've got to type
in to unlock the disk.

78
00:03:30.100 --> 00:03:34.210
Now, when we work with a key like that,
if you have a system that

79
00:03:34.210 --> 00:03:37.110
more than one person uses, that can
cause a bit of a problem, all right?

80
00:03:37.110 --> 00:03:39.150
Let's say, I share my laptop with Zach.

81
00:03:39.150 --> 00:03:41.960
And so now I have to give him the key,
so he and I both have the key.

82
00:03:41.960 --> 00:03:44.315
And then one day, I decide you know what?

83
00:03:44.315 --> 00:03:46.365
I've had enough of Zach, I let him go.

84
00:03:46.365 --> 00:03:47.649
Right.

85
00:03:47.649 --> 00:03:48.259
>> [LAUGH]
>> We fire him, we get him out of here.

86
00:03:48.259 --> 00:03:50.110
>> He does that to me all the time.

87
00:03:50.110 --> 00:03:51.380
>> Well now, I got a problem.

88
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:53.520
He and I share a key, right?

89
00:03:53.520 --> 00:03:56.320
So he's still got a valid key,
cuz it's the same key I use.

90
00:03:56.320 --> 00:04:00.960
And I can't disable that key because
now I'll lose access to the system.

91
00:04:00.960 --> 00:04:01.893
So what do I have to do?

92
00:04:01.893 --> 00:04:06.180
I have to decrypt the whole disk and
then re-encrypt it with a new key and

93
00:04:06.180 --> 00:04:07.580
that's a pain.

94
00:04:07.580 --> 00:04:11.775
So, with LUKS, we can actually do multiple
keys that you can actually do eight keys,

95
00:04:11.775 --> 00:04:14.658
they're assigned a number and
it's zero through seven.

96
00:04:14.658 --> 00:04:17.200
So you have eight keys
that you can assign out.

97
00:04:17.200 --> 00:04:20.000
And that might be eight different people.

98
00:04:20.000 --> 00:04:22.440
It might be one person and
you keep rotation over time.

99
00:04:22.440 --> 00:04:25.280
And you change the different keys, so
you're not constantly reusing them.

100
00:04:25.280 --> 00:04:28.670
But there is a maximum of eight.

101
00:04:28.670 --> 00:04:31.765
And that means that if you've got a shared
system with more than eight users,

102
00:04:31.765 --> 00:04:33.650
LUKS is not gonna be a good solution for
you.

103
00:04:33.650 --> 00:04:36.110
You'll need to look for
some other solution that's out there.

104
00:04:36.110 --> 00:04:41.110
But, for a standard laptop or a desktop

00:27:01.964 --> 00:27:05.020
do we have to manually bump
this after each reboot?

552
00:27:06.080 --> 00:27:06.840
>> You would, right?

553
00:27:06.840 --> 00:27:12.708
So it, much like a television series
from the 80s, we got to reboot.

554
00:27:12.708 --> 00:27:14.336
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And so,

555
00:27:14.336 --> 00:27:18.048
every time I wanna access this disk,
I've got to provide the passphrase, right?

556
00:27:18.048 --> 00:27:19.720
If I had done this during the install and

557
00:27:19.720 --> 00:27:22.250
it was my root partition
that was encrypted.

558
00:27:22.250 --> 00:27:25.770
When I power on the system,
it's gonna prompt me for that passphrase.

559
00:27:25.770 --> 00:27:27.640
I got to provide it just
to be able to boot.

560
00:27:27.640 --> 00:27:29.600
But in my case, I did a data disk, right?

561
00:27:29.600 --> 00:27:32.400
A data disk that I could
technically boot without.

562
00:27:32.400 --> 00:27:35.690
If I booted without decrypting this,
Apache would be broken,

563
00:27:35.690 --> 00:27:37.740
but everything else would be fine.

564
00:27:37.740 --> 00:27:39.470
So, I need to provide that passphrase.

565
00:27:39.470 --> 00:27:41.736
Well, that means I have to
manually intervene, and

566
00:27:41.736 --> 00:27:44.631
that's not necessarily the greatest
thing in the world, right?

567
00:27:44.631 --> 00:27:48.210
We don't wanna have to manually get
involved with mounting these partitions.

568
00:27:48.210 --> 00:27:49.890
So you can automate it.

569
00:27:49.890 --> 00:27:53.460
But you've got to be really careful
about how you automate this.

570
00:27:53.460 --> 00:27:56.700
Because what's gonna happen is,
if you automate it you've got to store

571
00:27:56.700 --> 00:28:00.790
the password somewhere, and if you store
the password, now it's an attack factor.

572
00:28:00.790 --> 00:28:05.050
So what a lot of people will do is set up
a key store somewhere on their network.

573
00:28:05.050 --> 00:28:08.650
It says that when the machine boots
in a script, it's gonna reach out,

574
00:28:08.650 --> 00:28:11.560
query the key and then unlock
it with the key to bring it on.

575
00:28:11.560 --> 00:28:13.710
And if somebody steals the machine and

576
00:28:13.710 --> 00:28:17.247
leaves, they don't have access to that
key store so now it's safe, right?

577
00:28:18.260 --> 00:28:22.730
But you can actually put
the keys in your fstab file,

578
00:28:22.730 --> 00:28:26.520
in the file system table file and
it'll mount them automatically.

579
00:28:26.520 --> 00:28:29.140
That's not the greatest idea in the world.

580
00:28:29.140 --> 00:28:31.510
It doesn't work for your main partition.

581
00:28:31.510 --> 00:28:34.670
But it would work for
all of your data drives.

582
00:28:34.670 --> 00:28:37.250
And so, if I've got data drives,
that are encrypted,

583
00:28:37.250 --> 00:28:40.930
I can store their keys,
inside of my file system table.

584
00:28:40.930 --> 00:28:44.250
And that would be okay, because the file
system table will be encrypted.

585
00:28:44.250 --> 00:28:47.390
As part of the root drive as long as
I set that up during the install.

586
00:28:47.390 --> 00:28:52.820
So, to see how to do that, there's
actually two places we have to work with.

587
00:28:52.820 --> 00:28:55.070
We have the file system table, right?

588
00:28:55.070 --> 00:29:01.750
So if I were to go and take a look at
/etc/fstab, right, we can go in here,

589
00:29:01.750 --> 00:29:06.870
and we can add an entry to
mount the website, right?

590
00:29:06.870 --> 00:29:12.060
Well the website is actually
in /dev/mapper/website.

591
00:29:12.060 --> 00:29:18.050
And we mounted it to /website,
and it's file system was xfs,

592
00:29:18.050 --> 00:29:23.810
and I might just do defaults on this
one and get that kinda set up, right?

593
00:29:23.810 --> 00:29:26.942
Well, that is assuming
that the virtual device,

594
00:29:26.942 --> 00:29:30.640
that /dev/mapper/website, exists already.

595
00:29:30.640 --> 00:29:32.400
So, where does that come from?

596
00:29:32.400 --> 00:29:40.840
That actually comes from another
file which is /etc/crypttab.

597
00:29:40.840 --> 00:29:44.090
And, if I go inside of
the crypttab file so,

598
00:29:44.090 --> 00:29:47.120
instead of file system tab,
this is crypttab.

599
00:29:47.120 --> 00:29:48.030
It may not exist.

600
00:29:48.030 --> 00:29:48.840
In my case, it doesn't.

601
00:29:48.840 --> 00:29:52.190
So, there is no crypttab file
by default on my system.

602
00:29:52.190 --> 00:29:54.320
Because I didn't turn on
encryption during the install.

603
00:29:54.320 --> 00:29:56.220
Had I, this file would already exist.

604
00:29:56.220 --> 00:30:01.000
So, I'm gonna add an entry here for any
encrypted volumes, that I want to unlock.

605
00:30:01.000 --> 00:30:06.421
And so I want to unlock this other one,
so I'm gonna say website, whoops.

606
00:30:06.421 --> 00:30:10.070
There we go,
website is the name of the virtual device.

607
00:30:10.070 --> 00:30:14.821
And then I will tell it that it's in /dev,
/sdb1 and

608
00:30:14.821 --> 00:30:19.350
then here's the part
where I have a choice.

609
00:30:19.350 --> 00:30:24.295
If I stop right here when I boot
the system up, it'll go to automatically

610
00:30:24.295 --> 00:30:27.240
mount this and it'll prompt me for
the password, and I can type it.

611
00:30:27.240 --> 00:30:28.740
Okay, so
that's probably the most secure way.

612
00:30:29.850 --> 00:30:34.230
Or option two,
I could type the password in here.

613
00:30:34.230 --> 00:30:38.080
All right, and now it's here but
it stored in the crypttab file.

614
00:30:38.080 --> 00:30:41.810
And if somebody has access to my main
drive, then they might have access to this

615
00:30:41.810 --> 00:30:44.630
file and be able to find out
what that passphrase is, okay.

616
00:30:44.630 --> 00:30:45.910
So that's the risk there.

617
00:30:45.910 --> 00:30:48.880
Or three,
we can point to a network location.

618
00:30:48.880 --> 00:30:52.250
And that's where we have the ability
to start reaching out, and

619
00:30:52.250 --> 00:30:54.730
using a centralized network keystore,
all right.

620
00:30:54.730 --> 00:30:58.320
So I'll leave it blank, so
that it prompts me, right?

621
00:30:58.320 --> 00:31:02.294
So now when the system boots,
it will prompt me for this passphrase.

622
00:31:02.294 --> 00:31:07.477
And that will unlock, /dev, /mapper,
/website, and once that's unlocked,

623
00:31:07.477 --> 00:31:11.972
the file system table can get read,
and that will mount it to /website.

624
00:31:11.972 --> 00:31:13.820
So, that's how we kinda take care of that,
and

625
00:31:13.820 --> 00:31:17.420
get that so it'll fire up at boot time,
and be available for us.

626
00:31:17.420 --> 00:31:19.522
So, that's kinda the main way
of how we would handle that,

627
00:31:19.522 --> 00:31:21.580
if we want it to be
a little more automated.

628
00:31:21.580 --> 00:31:25.041
>> So what kind of on going
maintenance does LUKS require, Don?

629
00:31:25.041 --> 00:31:26.629
>> Well, as far as service maintenance,

630
00:31:26.629 --> 00:31:28.515
there's not a whole lot
you have to do with it.

631
00:31:28.515 --> 00:31:29.324
It kinda does its job.

632
00:31:29.324 --> 00:31:31.991
It just sits there and
encrypts and decrypts seamlessly.

633
00:31:31.991 --> 00:31:36.335
The end users, it's all transparent, they
don't really see it, and it does its job.

634
00:31:36.335 --> 00:31:39.672
The only real maintenance we have
to do is kinda key rotation,

635
00:31:39.672 --> 00:31:41.350
adding keys, removing keys.

636
00:31:41.350 --> 00:31:42.702
I have one key right now.

637
00:31:42.702 --> 00:31:45.480
The passphrase that I
assign when we set it up.

638
00:31:45.480 --> 00:31:48.730
So I might wanna add some more keys or
take some keys away.

639
00:31:48.730 --> 00:31:52.130
So, you've got a few
different things you can do.

640
00:31:52.130 --> 00:31:53.919
We can look at how many
keys we've got already.

641
00:31:53.919 --> 00:31:58.389
I can say cryptsetup luksDump.

642
00:31:58.389 --> 00:32:02.005
And the luksdump command gives
us information about a disk.

643
00:32:02.005 --> 00:32:04.821
And I can look at /dev/sdb1.

644
00:32:04.821 --> 00:32:08.770
Now if I just run this, luksDump
gives you way too much information.

645
00:32:08.770 --> 00:32:10.730
So I'm gonna filter that.

646
00:32:10.730 --> 00:32:14.614
I'm gonna grip for Key Slot.

647
00:32:14.614 --> 00:32:16.230
And there's a space in between Key Slot so

648
00:32:16.230 --> 00:32:17.995
I'm doing a backslash
to escape that space.

649
00:32:17.995 --> 00:32:19.870
But I'm just looking for the Key Slots.

650
00:32:19.870 --> 00:32:20.967
And when I run that,

651
00:32:20.967 --> 00:32:24.334
here I can see my eight key slots
numbered zero through seven.

652
00:32:24.334 --> 00:32:28.280
See how Key Slot of zero is enable and
all of the other ones is disabled.

653
00:32:28.280 --> 00:32:29.540
I haven't created any more keys.

654
00:32:29.540 --> 00:32:31.740
But this is where that
maximum of eight comes from.

655
00:32:31.740 --> 00:32:33.710
I can only have eight keys.

656
00:32:33.710 --> 00:32:37.253
So I can create new ones and add them
in and I can take away old ones and

657
00:32:37.253 --> 00:32:41.230
kind of rotate through and
get all that set up right through here.

658
00:32:41.230 --> 00:32:48.643
If I wanted to add I key,
I would say cryptsetup luksaddkey.

659
00:32:48.643 --> 00:32:49.354
There we go.

660
00:32:49.354 --> 00:32:51.466
I want to add a key and
then and from here,

661
00:32:51.466 --> 00:32:54.210
I would tell the device that
I wanted to add a key too.

662
00:32:54.210 --> 00:32:57.320
I wanna add it to /dev/sdb1, okay?

663
00:32:57.320 --> 00:33:00.710
And then I need to punch
in an existing key.

664
00:33:00.710 --> 00:33:04.220
One of the existing keys has to
be used just to ask the disk.

665
00:33:04.220 --> 00:33:06.670
And so
I'll punch in the key that I used earlier.

666
00:33:08.280 --> 00:33:11.924
And then I'll be able to
punch in a new key, right?

667
00:33:11.924 --> 00:33:14.930
And so here it is,
enter a new passphrase for the key slot.

668
00:33:14.930 --> 00:33:19.737
And so now I can come in and I can punch
in what I want this new key to be.

669
00:33:19.737 --> 00:33:23.820
I don't wanna use a dictionary word again,
let's see if I can't get around that.

670
00:33:26.060 --> 00:33:27.560
And I will, oops.

671
00:33:27.560 --> 00:33:30.840
I will try and
punch in a better password this time.

672
00:33:31.840 --> 00:33:32.830
And there we go.

673
00:33:32.830 --> 00:33:36.380
And so I punch in, and
now it's adding that second key, right.

674
00:33:36.380 --> 00:33:37.172
And I can do same thing.

675
00:33:37.172 --> 00:33:38.780
A third key, a fourth key, a fifth key.

676
00:33:38.780 --> 00:33:40.488
You just keep punching them in.

677
00:33:40.488 --> 00:33:41.880
And each one is getting added.

678
00:33:41.880 --> 00:33:43.940
So, see now I have two keys.

679
00:33:43.940 --> 00:33:46.590
And over time I might

680
00:33:46.590 --> 00:33:49.760
encounter a situation where I need
to remove somebody's key, right?

681
00:33:49.760 --> 00:33:52.710
So we released an employee,
or maybe it's just time.

682
00:33:52.710 --> 00:33:54.340
Time to change out a key.

683
00:33:54.340 --> 00:34:01.270
I can come in and say, instead of
luksaddkey, I can do a luksremovekey.

684
00:34:01.270 --> 00:34:03.720
And so I'll do that right here,
remove key.

685
00:34:03.720 --> 00:34:06.440
And then enter the passphrase
to be deleted.

686
00:34:06.440 --> 00:34:09.700
I punch in the key that I
want to take out, right?

687
00:34:09.700 --> 00:34:14.018
I'm gonna take out the second key and
when I do that,

688
00:34:14.018 --> 00:34:16.972
I'll punch in that key [INAUDIBLE].

689
00:34:16.972 --> 00:34:19.540
Now this assumes that we
know what that key is.

690
00:34:19.540 --> 00:34:22.160
If we don't there are ways
to override that.

691
00:34:22.160 --> 00:34:26.330
But assuming you know what that key is
you can punch the key in, it removes it.

692
00:34:26.330 --> 00:34:30.236
And now when I go and look,
key two is now disabled, right.

693
00:34:30.236 --> 00:34:33.347
So I can add and remove this keys to
enable people to be able to get in and

694
00:34:33.347 --> 00:34:34.160
use that system.

695
00:34:34.160 --> 00:34:37.730
So that's really the only ongoing
maintenance that we've got for it.

696
00:34:37.730 --> 00:34:40.926
But after that it kind of does its job and
it does it really well.

697
00:34:40.926 --> 00:34:44.740
So it's a great way to encrypt that data
and ensure that your data's safe even

698
00:34:44.740 --> 00:34:47.390
if someone manages to
physically steal those disks.

699
00:34:47.390 --> 00:34:50.570
>> Powerful Linux tool,
LUKS disk encryption.

700
00:34:50.570 --> 00:34:53.054
Don did a great job delivering
all that information.

701
00:34:53.054 --> 00:34:56.170
Any final thoughts on this, or no?

702
00:34:56.170 --> 00:34:58.470
>> Remember,
there is a ton more that goes into this.

703
00:34:58.470 --> 00:35:01.980
I've shown you the basics of what
we can use to LUKS up and going.

704
00:35:01.980 --> 00:35:07.330
I know we had some comments in the chat
room about storing keys on a YubiKey,

705
00:35:07.330 --> 00:35:09.470
or some kind of third party device.

706
00:35:09.470 --> 00:35:12.770
I don't know of any that have
direct support for LUKS, but

707
00:35:12.770 --> 00:35:16.240
a lot of them actually do have support for
just storing generic keys in there.

708
00:35:16.240 --> 00:35:18.610
And so this is really no different
than storing any other passwords.

709
00:35:18.610 --> 00:35:24.189
So you can leverage password vaults,
things like LastPass or KeePass, YubiKey.

710
00:35:24.189 --> 00:35:28.590
Anything that gives you general
encrypted storage of a key.

711
00:35:28.590 --> 00:35:31.860
You can do that, you just wouldn't be able
to dynamically retrieve it from that key.

712
00:35:31.860 --> 00:35:33.481
You plug it in and it just works.

713
00:35:33.481 --> 00:35:35.459
You have to get a little
more involved in that.

714
00:35:35.459 --> 00:35:38.653
We also had another question in the chat
room about, can we encrypt USB drives?

715
00:35:38.653 --> 00:35:40.278
The answer is yes, absolutely.

716
00:35:40.278 --> 00:35:41.080
>> I thought so, yeah.

717
00:35:41.080 --> 00:35:42.670
>> You can do it.

718
00:35:42.670 --> 00:35:45.280
They're a little harder
to mount at boot time

719
00:35:45.280 --> 00:35:47.710
because USB is detected
kind of strange and

720
00:35:47.710 --> 00:35:50.590
the naming can change depending on
what port you're plugged in and stuff.

721
00:35:50.590 --> 00:35:53.120
So they're harder to mount automatically.

722
00:35:53.120 --> 00:35:56.350
But as far as dynamically mounting them,
you plug it in and

723
00:35:56.350 --> 00:35:57.840
then you go in and mount it.

724
00:35:57.840 --> 00:36:02.770
That is just like any other disk,
it'll show up as a device in slash dev and

725
00:36:02.770 --> 00:36:06.310
as soon as you know that device name you
can mount it and then pop it right open.

726
00:36:06.310 --> 00:36:07.838
LUKS works great on this.

>> Yeah, fantastic, great job as
always Don and it was a lot of videos,

728

a lot of episodes in the Linux
security techniques,

729
00:36:14.840 --> 00:36:17.950
serious make sure you watch
every single one of them.

730
00:36:17.950 --> 00:36:19.630
Because you'd be very glad you did.

731
00:36:19.630 --> 00:36:21.684
And thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

732
00:36:21.684 --> 00:36:23.800
Remember, a good ITPRO is always learning.

733
00:36:23.800 --> 00:36:24.640
I'm Zack Memos.

734
00:36:24.640 --> 00:36:25.410
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

00:36:25.410 --> 00:36:30.789

In each episode, we've kind of focused on
a different area of Linux security, and

18

in this one,

19

And actually, I'm gonna kind of

20

do some data at rest and data in motion.

21
00:00:44.380 --> 00:00:47.920
You know that when we protect data,
we need to keep it secure, we need to make

22
00:00:47.920 --> 00:00:51.340
sure prying eyes can't get into it, and
the best way to do that is encryption.

23
00:00:51.340 --> 00:00:54.460
And when data at rest,
data is sitting there on our hard drive,

24
00:00:54.460 --> 00:00:57.120
it's nice to have it encrypted, because
if somebody gets into our computer,

25
00:00:57.120 --> 00:00:58.320
we don't want them to have access.

26
00:00:58.320 --> 00:00:58.865
>> Mm-hm.

27
00:00:58.865 --> 00:01:02.795
>> But when data is crossing the network,
we also want it to be encrypted,

28
00:01:02.795 --> 00:01:05.155
because somebody could intercept
that traffic on the network.

29
00:01:05.155 --> 00:01:08.505
And it's actually easier to
intercept data crossing the network.

30
00:01:08.505 --> 00:01:11.245
So there's a nice little technology
available that we can use.

31
00:01:11.245 --> 00:01:13.035
It kind of helps in both situations.

32
00:01:13.035 --> 00:01:16.174
And it's called GPG, or GNU Privacy Guard.

33
00:01:16.174 --> 00:01:23.380
And with GPG is an open source alternative
to an older technology called PGP.

34
00:01:23.380 --> 00:01:28.395
And PGP was the Pretty Good Privacy
is what it stood for.

35
00:01:28.395 --> 00:01:31.917
>> [LAUGH]
>> It was developed by a gentleman whose

00:01:31.917 --> 00:01:34.693
name has completely escaped me,

00:25:26.230 --> 00:25:30.240

542
00:25:41.830 --> 00:25:46.440
If I were to pull up

00:26:04.376 --> 00:26:06.911
I see binary data.

00:26:08.020 --> 00:26:09.495

00:26:09.495 --> 00:26:12.420
This is a cipher text, it's meaningless

551
00:26:12.420 --> 00:26:17.470
and if they change even one character

552
00:26:17.470 --> 00:26:21.750
This file can now be safely
stored on a USB key.

553
00:26:21.750 --> 00:26:27.845
It can be safely emailed to somebody,

00:26:27.845 --> 00:26:32.692
And unless somebody gets my private key,

00:26:32.692 --> 00:26:37.414
to brute force a private key, which really

00:26:37.414 --> 00:26:39.440
Then they are not going to

00:26:57.790 --> 00:27:01.183

if I'm running Windows or Linux or Mac,

00:27:05.849 --> 00:27:08.690

00:27:08.690 --> 00:27:10.534

570
00:27:13.490 --> 00:27:16.976
That's the real advantage of this, it's
one of the most flexible ways to encrypt

571
00:27:16.976 --> 00:27:19.010
the data and
it's encrypted your data at rest.

572
00:27:19.010 --> 00:27:20.700
It's encrypted on my hard drive.

573
00:27:20.700 --> 00:27:23.390
But if I email and stuff,
it stays encrypted the whole time.

574
00:27:23.390 --> 00:27:25.870
So, this can give us true

575
00:27:25.870 --> 00:27:29.700
And that's why GPG is so

576
00:27:29.700 --> 00:27:32.520
The only time it can't be encrypted

00:27:32.520 --> 00:27:35.110

00:27:35.110 --> 00:27:36.860
I can't read it like it is right now.

579
00:27:36.860 --> 00:27:40.030
So, I've taken care of data in rest and

580
00:27:40.030 --> 00:27:41.860
I haven't taken for a data in.

>> So the now the recipient can decrypt

00:27:46.715 --> 00:27:48.520

00:27:50.550 --> 00:27:53.010
So, as the recipient,

00:27:53.010 --> 00:27:56.830
I encrypt this file with your public

00:27:56.830 --> 00:28:01.430
Well, on your side here,

00:28:07.140 --> 00:28:09.160

00:28:15.920 --> 00:28:17.410
And so you need to punch that in.

592
00:28:17.410 --> 00:28:20.200
And when you do that, it will
automatically apply your private key.

593
00:28:20.200 --> 00:28:24.400
Well remember when I create to my
private key, I assigned a password.

594
00:28:24.400 --> 00:28:26.350
So I've got to apply my passphrase.

595
00:28:26.350 --> 00:28:29.104
If I leave my computer unlocked,
I know sitting down and

00:28:29.104 --> 00:28:31.000

00:28:31.000 --> 00:28:34.120
So they've got to provide that passphrase.

00:28:34.120 --> 00:28:38.950
And once they do, it applies the key and

599
00:28:38.950 --> 00:28:42.740
And now I've got that unencrypted

600
00:28:42.740 --> 00:28:45.560
So if these were backups and

00:28:45.560 --> 00:28:49.720

00:28:49.720 --> 00:28:52.100

00:28:52.100 --> 00:28:52.810
But meanwhile,

00:28:56.620 --> 00:28:58.040
And that's the real advantage of GPG.

606
00:28:58.040 --> 00:28:59.310
It's great technology.

It's really powerful.

GPG gives you end-to-end security, so

00:02:46.770 --> 00:02:50.640
