sha256sum.txt.asc that's
the one that's singed.

505
00:27:18.470 --> 00:27:21.173
The regular txt is not signed,
I can't verify that.

506
00:27:21.173 --> 00:27:25.180
But this one had the data and
then right after it had the signature.

507
00:27:25.180 --> 00:27:28.689
And that signature will tell me
whether the data's been modified and

508
00:27:28.689 --> 00:27:32.985
whether it's actually signed by the key
that I've already attained from the CentOS

509
00:27:32.985 --> 00:27:33.787
team, right?

510
00:27:33.787 --> 00:27:37.560
And so now, if the CentOS team gets
full-blown hacked a week from now, right?

511
00:27:37.560 --> 00:27:39.553
Hopefully that doesn't happen,
but let's say they do.

512
00:27:39.553 --> 00:27:41.167
I've already got their key.

513
00:27:41.167 --> 00:27:44.760
So I already know that I can verify
whether or not the data is legit.

514
00:27:44.760 --> 00:27:48.499
And when I run that,
it looks at it and I get.

515
00:27:48.499 --> 00:27:50.801
Good signature from CentOS 7,

516
00:27:50.801 --> 00:27:54.989
CentOS 7 official signing
key security at CentOS.org.

517
00:27:54.989 --> 00:27:55.962
I know that's good.

518
00:27:55.962 --> 00:27:59.231
Now, I did get a warning after it telling
me the key is not certified with a trusted

519
00:27:59.231 --> 00:28:02.037
signature and that's because I just
downloaded it from their site.

520
00:28:02.037 --> 00:28:05.195
If I'd gotten that from a centralized
key repository then I would trust it and

521
00:28:05.195 --> 00:28:06.800
I wouldn't get that warning.

522
00:28:06.800 --> 00:28:10.014
But in this case because I just downloaded
it it doesn't really know where I got

523
00:28:10.014 --> 00:28:10.704
that file from.

524
00:28:10.704 --> 00:28:15.143
So it's saying I could have got it from
a source that was untrustworthy but

525
00:28:15.143 --> 00:28:17.040
in my case I got it from CentOS.

526
00:28:17.040 --> 00:28:20.858
So I've got it its telling me
that its a good signature, and so

527
00:28:20.858 --> 00:28:25.630
I know that it's valid and now I can turn
around and I can use that file to verify

528
00:28:25.630 --> 00:28:30.568
my other files from there until I know
that's good, it's verified I'm good.

529
00:28:30.568 --> 00:28:36.428
I can do a SHA-256 sum --check,
SHA-256sum.txt.afc and

530
00:28:36.428 --> 00:28:40.398
I can use that file and
it's gonna go through and

531
00:28:40.398 --> 00:28:44.183
it's gonna check each of those signatures.

532
00:28:44.183 --> 00:28:48.380
I verify that this file was
signed by the CentOS team.

533
00:28:48.380 --> 00:28:52.269
And now I can use the signatures in that
file to verify that my ISOs are intact.

534
00:28:52.269 --> 00:28:55.209
And so this is gonna check and
make sure that we are doubly sure.

535
00:28:55.209 --> 00:28:57.244
So I am not doing all of them,
just the first one is enough.

536
00:28:57.244 --> 00:28:58.810
And I can see that it's good.

537
00:28:58.810 --> 00:29:00.959
I know that this testing this fine and
I am ready to go.

538
00:29:00.959 --> 00:29:03.764
And if I don't want their key any more,

539
00:29:03.764 --> 00:29:09.382
I can always to a GPG --delete-key
followed by the fingerprint of that key.

540
00:29:09.382 --> 00:29:13.248
And the fingerprint when you load it, it's
really just this little part right here.

541
00:29:13.248 --> 00:29:17.630
This F4, well it's what ever after
the slash for that public key.

542
00:29:17.630 --> 00:29:21.379
So I can take that oops, and
throw that in there, and

543
00:29:21.379 --> 00:29:23.720
then we can delete that key out.

544
00:29:23.720 --> 00:29:25.610
Whoops, let me do it there.

545
00:29:25.610 --> 00:29:27.990
And we can get rid of it or
you can keep it.

546
00:29:27.990 --> 00:29:30.428
The key is, they're really small,
they're not like take up a lot of space.

547
00:29:30.428 --> 00:29:32.490
And you wanna have the keys ahead of time.

548
00:29:32.490 --> 00:29:34.687
And that way if the servers
get compromised or whatever,

549
00:29:34.687 --> 00:29:37.640
you know you've got the proper key and
you can go in and test and work from it.

550
00:29:37.640 --> 00:29:41.240
So that's a much more difficult
way to verify the files.

551
00:29:41.240 --> 00:29:45.457
But if you wanna be absolutely sure
that everything's on the up and up,

552
00:29:45.457 --> 00:29:46.947
that's the way to do it.

553
00:29:46.947 --> 00:29:50.510
>> You can't be too careful,
awesome presentation as usual Don.

554
00:29:50.510 --> 00:29:54.846
MD5 and SHA checksums, any final thoughts?

555
00:29:54.846 --> 00:29:56.590
>> The main thing here is
just remember to do it.

556
00:29:56.590 --> 00:29:59.531
A lot of people get lazy or
they're in a rush, you download the file,

557
00:29:59.531 --> 00:30:02.547
you pull from some random mirror
you've never even heard of, right?

558
00:30:02.547 --> 00:30:05.293
These mirror servers are not
necessarily people you can trust.

559
00:30:05.293 --> 00:30:08.024
Hopefully they are, but
you don't know them,

560
00:30:08.024 --> 00:30:11.660
like I don't actually know any
of the IT employees at USF.

561
00:30:11.660 --> 00:30:15.480
I download stuff from their servers all
the time, I don't know their team, right?

562
00:30:15.480 --> 00:30:18.996
But I don't have to worry about whether
I trust them or not because I can

563
00:30:18.996 --> 00:30:22.590
always validate the files,
I can always verify that they're intact.

564
00:30:22.590 --> 00:30:23.850
So just remember to do it.

565
00:30:23.850 --> 00:30:28.415
If you don't do it then you
could be deploying compromised

566
00:30:28.415 --> 00:30:30.754
software right from day one.

567
00:30:30.754 --> 00:30:33.727
And you could have the most secure
network in the world but if you're

568
00:30:33.727 --> 00:30:37.434
deploying a compromised OS, or compromised
applications, you've kinda blown it

569
00:30:37.434 --> 00:30:40.950
out of the water and you facilitate it
by giving it administrative privileges.

570
00:30:40.950 --> 00:30:42.990
That's the kind of problem
that we're up against.

571
00:30:42.990 --> 00:30:44.376
>> Right, and you can't be too secure and

572
00:30:44.376 --> 00:30:47.069
that's why we're doing this entire
series of Linux Security Techniques.

573
00:30:47.069 --> 00:30:51.080
Make sure you watch all the episodes,
you'll be glad you did.

574
00:30:51.080 --> 00:30:52.494
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

575
00:30:52.494 --> 00:30:54.738
Remember a good IT Pro is always learning.

576
00:30:54.738 --> 00:30:56.000
I'm Zach Memos.

577
00:30:56.000 --> 00:30:56.563
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

578
00:30:56.563 --> 00:31:01.022
>> And we'll see you very soon.

579
00:31:01.022 --> 00:31:05.050
[MUSIC].

580
00:31:05.050 --> 00:31:08.449
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what we need to get started with SSH, how we get our server ready to accept SSH connections, what is wrong with default keys, generating new keys, how a client gets a public key, client connections, encrypted shell, building a secure tunnel, Telnet, and software using the tunnel.

1

4

5
00:00:11.750 --> 00:00:13.818

choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:13.818 --> 00:00:15.459

7
00:00:15.459 --> 00:00:20.282
I'm your host, Zach Memos as we continue
on with Linux security techniques and

8
00:00:20.282 --> 00:00:22.700

9
00:00:22.700 --> 00:00:26.460
The person bringing us all
the information we need is Don Pezet.

10
00:00:26.460 --> 00:00:28.931
Cuz he know's what he's gonna tell us,
he knows this stuff.

11
00:00:28.931 --> 00:00:30.298
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't know this stuff,

12

he knows this stuff.

13

>> Sometimes, sometimes I know
what I'm gonna talk about.

14
00:00:34.313 --> 00:00:37.870
[LAUGH] In this episode,
we're gonna be talking about using SSH,

15
00:00:37.870 --> 00:00:41.250
the secure shell protocol
to encrypt traffic.

16
00:00:41.250 --> 00:00:44.019
In the Unix world, a lot of what
was designed was designed back when

17
00:00:44.019 --> 00:00:47.193
the networks were safe, when you could
trust the networks that you were on.

18
00:00:47.193 --> 00:00:48.399
And so encryption and

19
00:00:48.399 --> 00:00:52.890
security was not at the forefront of
people's minds in the early days.

20
00:00:52.890 --> 00:00:55.508
And as time has gone on,
it's not like that anymore, right?

21
00:00:55.508 --> 00:00:56.623
>> No.
>> Things are in danger,

22
00:00:56.623 --> 00:00:57.469
we don't trust the networks.

23
00:00:57.469 --> 00:00:59.900
Even our own networks can't be trusted.

24
00:00:59.900 --> 00:01:02.750
If potentially, an attacker has
managed to get inside the network, or

25
00:01:02.750 --> 00:01:05.920
you have a malicious employee or
something like that.

26
00:01:05.920 --> 00:01:08.720
We need to protect our data in transit.

27
00:01:08.720 --> 00:01:10.960
So we've seen several protocols
creep up over the years to try and

28
00:01:10.960 --> 00:01:14.980
solve the problem, things like
Secure Socket Layer and stuff like that.

29
00:01:14.980 --> 00:01:19.000
But no one technology has
solved the problem as well

30
00:01:19.000 --> 00:01:22.350
as the one we're gonna talk about
in this episode, which is SSH.

31
00:01:22.350 --> 00:01:26.046
Secure Shell, is what is seems,
I almost said Secure Socket Layer.

32
00:01:26.046 --> 00:01:30.471
Secure Shell, SSH,
was designed to solve the telnet problem.

33
00:01:30.471 --> 00:01:33.154
That telnet is what most of
us as administrators used for

34
00:01:33.154 --> 00:01:36.250
a long time to build a remote in and
gain shell access to a server.

35
00:01:36.250 --> 00:01:39.350
And it sent everything over
the network in plain text,

36
00:01:39.350 --> 00:01:42.960
which is just not a good thing,
not anymore.

37
00:01:42.960 --> 00:01:46.683
So SSH solved that by applying
an encryption layer to it.

38
00:01:46.683 --> 00:01:50.583
So that all the data that was transmitted
over the network can be encrypted and

39
00:01:50.583 --> 00:01:51.123
secured.

40
00:01:51.123 --> 00:01:54.153
So we're gonna take a look at how we
can use that with not just telnet, but

41
00:01:54.153 --> 00:01:55.855
with other things here in this episode.

42
00:01:55.855 --> 00:01:57.733
We're gonna learn more about the protocol.

43
00:01:57.733 --> 00:02:01.361
And how we can leverage this to make sure
that our data is encrypted on the network,

44
00:02:01.361 --> 00:02:03.810
even if the underlying
protocol doesn't support it.

45
00:02:03.810 --> 00:02:05.920
We'll get a chance to see that
right here in this episode.

46
00:02:05.920 --> 00:02:09.800
>> And the question on all of our minds
is how do we get started with SSH?

47
00:02:09.800 --> 00:02:13.380
>> Well, fortunately you probably
already are started with it, right?

48
00:02:13.380 --> 00:02:18.124
SSH is so powerful, it does such a great
job at what it does that pretty much every

49
00:02:18.124 --> 00:02:21.746
distribution out there, packages SSH
already installed with your system.

50
00:02:21.746 --> 00:02:26.140
SSH is actually a part
of the OpenSSH project,

51
00:02:26.140 --> 00:02:28.958
which is managed by the BSD guys,
the OpenBSD guys.

52
00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.660
So if you've ever heard of OpenBSD,

53
00:02:30.660 --> 00:02:35.080
it's a distribution of BSD Unix
that is focused on security.

54
00:02:35.080 --> 00:02:37.330
Security is their first and
foremost thought.

55
00:02:37.330 --> 00:02:41.325
And so they created the OpenSSH project to
create an encryption layer that they could

56
00:02:41.325 --> 00:02:42.535
trust and was secure.

57
00:02:42.535 --> 00:02:45.375
And that got adopted by
darn near everybody.

58
00:02:45.375 --> 00:02:49.815
So if you've got a Linux distro,
a BSD distro,

59
00:02:49.815 --> 00:02:53.135
even Macs,
they've got SSH installed by default.

60
00:02:53.135 --> 00:02:55.585
It might not be open on the firewall,
but it's there, and it's running.

61
00:02:55.585 --> 00:02:58.240
So the odds are you've already got it.

62
00:02:58.240 --> 00:03:00.550
So we just need to kind of configure
it a little bit, tweak it.

63
00:03:00.550 --> 00:03:03.630
And in fact, we may not even need
to configure it much at all.

64
00:03:03.630 --> 00:03:06.360
There might be some certificate
authentication we need to configure.

65
00:03:06.360 --> 00:03:08.940
We might need to open up some firewall
rules, and these are things that we've all

66
00:03:08.940 --> 00:03:12.112
seen in previous episodes, so
we won't harp on it too much.

67
00:03:12.112 --> 00:03:16.820
But SSH uses port 22 or tcp port 22 so
that's got to be opened up.

68
00:03:16.820 --> 00:03:19.110
And there's some other
kind of security settings.

69
00:03:19.110 --> 00:03:23.600
If you didn't watch it, we did an episode
specifically on securing SSH, so

70
00:03:23.600 --> 00:03:25.820
definitely check that one out to
make sure you get it up and running.

71
00:03:25.820 --> 00:03:29.380
But as far as getting it installed,
typically, already there and

72
00:03:29.380 --> 00:03:30.780
already functional.

73
00:03:30.780 --> 00:03:33.970
>> So how do we get our server
RAID to accept SSH connections?

74
00:03:33.970 --> 00:03:36.060
>> All right, so
there's some of the basics, right,

75
00:03:36.060 --> 00:03:38.220
like getting the service
started if it isn't.

76
00:03:38.220 --> 00:03:40.878
But from a security
techniques perspective,

77
00:03:40.878 --> 00:03:44.860
I'm not usually all that happy with
the default configuration of SSH.

78
00:03:44.860 --> 00:03:46.049
There's a few things that I like to tweak.

79
00:03:46.049 --> 00:03:49.899
And I don't wanna spend a ton of time
on it cuz we did cover a lot of this in

80
00:03:49.899 --> 00:03:51.220
the securing SSH show.

81
00:03:51.220 --> 00:03:53.650
But one of the big things that I
like to do is restrict the version.

82
00:03:53.650 --> 00:03:56.160
So let me show you what I'm talking about.

83
00:03:56.160 --> 00:04:01.406
The SSH daemon stores
a configuration inside of /etc/ssh.

84
00:04:01.406 --> 00:04:04.400
And if you poke around that folder,
you'll notice a lot of stuff.

85
00:04:04.400 --> 00:04:08.210
The file that I'm looking for
is this guy right here sshd_config.

86
00:04:08.210 --> 00:04:11.260
Now be careful because

87
00:04:11.260 --> 00:04:16.670
there's a ssh_config which is
the ssh client and, whoops, sorry.

88
00:04:16.670 --> 00:04:20.250
And then, there's sshd_config,
that's the daemon.

89
00:04:20.250 --> 00:04:22.980
And if this is our server, and
we're trying to control connections to

90
00:04:22.980 --> 00:04:25.070
the server,
it's the daemon that we wanna configure.

91
00:04:25.070 --> 00:04:27.820
So we've got to make sure
that we get that one correct.

92
00:04:27.820 --> 00:04:34.620
And so, I'm gonna edit,
let's see, /etc/ssh/sshd_config.

93
00:04:34.620 --> 00:04:36.670
And when you go in here,
you'll see the server configuration.

94
00:04:36.670 --> 00:04:38.150
And I talk about this in the other show.

95
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:41.330
But the main thing that I wanna point out,
if you scroll through here,

96
00:04:41.330 --> 00:04:44.460
you'll find an entry
where it says protocol.

97
00:04:44.460 --> 00:04:48.900
And I should have just searched for
it cuz I probably passed it at this point.

98
00:04:48.900 --> 00:04:55.280
So let me do a quick search for protocol,
and actually, the entry is not in here.

99
00:04:55.280 --> 00:04:56.440
Interesting, all right.

100
00:04:56.440 --> 00:04:59.620
Well, I will add it except that
explains why I didn't see it.

101
00:04:59.620 --> 00:05:03.950
So what I usually do is somewhere around
the port number section right here,

102
00:05:03.950 --> 00:05:08.980
you can add an extra line that says
what protocols you wanna listen to.

103
00:05:08.980 --> 00:05:12.990
And you can say Protocol 1 and
it'll just listen for SSH version 1.

104
00:05:12.990 --> 00:05:16.214
Or you can say 1 space 2 and
it'll listen for connections for

105
00:05:16.214 --> 00:05:18.090
SSH version 1 and version 2.

106
00:05:18.090 --> 00:05:21.590
But SSH version 1 is not
considered secure anymore.

107
00:05:21.590 --> 00:05:22.850
It's not considered strong enough.

108
00:05:22.850 --> 00:05:24.600
The encryption it uses is too weak.

109
00:05:24.600 --> 00:05:28.291
So we typically want to
force protocol version 2.

110
00:05:28.291 --> 00:05:31.569
All right, that's gonna require
SSH version 2 connections and

111
00:05:31.569 --> 00:05:33.050
not allow version 1.

112
00:05:33.050 --> 00:05:35.500
Now, I'm on
a Red Hat Enterprise Linux System, and

113
00:05:35.500 --> 00:05:37.170
this option wasn't in here by default.

114
00:05:37.170 --> 00:05:41.060
So they may have actually set theirs
to default to version 2, I don't know.

115
00:05:41.060 --> 00:05:44.980
But if you're on DB or Ubuntu or other
distros, you just need to double check and

116
00:05:44.980 --> 00:05:47.560
make sure that you're not
listening on one anymore.

117
00:05:47.560 --> 00:05:49.180
Just don't even bother listening on one,

118
00:05:49.180 --> 00:05:51.120
because the encryption is
just not considered safe.

119
00:05:51.120 --> 00:05:55.310
So that's one thing that we definitely
want to double check before we get there.

120
00:05:55.310 --> 00:05:58.980
Now the other thing is,
if we kind of poke around in this file,

121
00:05:58.980 --> 00:06:01.790
do you see how right beneath it,
there's these host keys?

122
00:06:01.790 --> 00:06:04.820
And this is telling where
I can find the public key,

123
00:06:04.820 --> 00:06:08.830
private key pairs that are gonna
be used for doing the encryption.

124
00:06:08.830 --> 00:06:16.080
And as I look at these, I've got RSA,
ECDSA, Ed25519, all these different ones.

125
00:06:16.080 --> 00:06:18.060
These are the keys that
it's gonna look for

126
00:06:18.060 --> 00:06:20.590
when the system starts to do encryption.

127
00:06:20.590 --> 00:06:26.170
And when I get out and I look inside of
/etc/ssh, that's where all those keys are.

128
00:06:26.170 --> 00:06:28.301
And we'll probably wanna throw those
away and generate new ones anyway.

129
00:06:28.301 --> 00:06:31.630
And that'd be kind of another step of our
configuration as we get moving forward.

130
00:06:32.760 --> 00:06:35.250
>> So what's wrong with the default keys?

131
00:06:35.250 --> 00:06:37.462
>> Well the default keys work, right?

132
00:06:37.462 --> 00:06:38.495
Technically, SSH is up and running.

133
00:06:38.495 --> 00:06:39.552
The keys are right there.

134
00:06:39.552 --> 00:06:40.900
They work.

135
00:06:40.900 --> 00:06:44.142
The problem is, when you install a distro,

136
00:06:44.142 --> 00:06:48.040
you're kind of trusting that
they set up these keys right.

137
00:06:48.040 --> 00:06:50.120
Okay now,
I'm running Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

138
00:06:50.120 --> 00:06:52.159
So I guarantee you,
these keys will generate it right.

139
00:06:52.159 --> 00:06:54.469
>> Right.
>> Which means I did the install,

140
00:06:54.469 --> 00:06:55.880
it fired up the system.

141
00:06:55.880 --> 00:06:57.116
It completed the install.

142
00:06:57.116 --> 00:06:59.701
It rebooted with full hardware support and

143
00:06:59.701 --> 00:07:04.010
then it generated the SSH keys
unique to my system, all right.

144
00:07:04.010 --> 00:07:07.870
But, that doesn't always happen
with other distributions.

145
00:07:07.870 --> 00:07:11.130
Distributions that aren't security
focused have a couple of mistakes they

00:30:08.170 --> 00:30:10.370
I'm just going to run the tunnel and
that's it.

592
00:30:10.370 --> 00:30:14.906
So again running over this ssh- f,- f
makes it go in the background then my

593
00:30:14.906 --> 00:30:20.018
username and the host I want to connect
to, -L, because I'm doing a port mapping,

594
00:30:20.018 --> 00:30:23.701
and the port mapping is gonna
map a local port which I picked.

595
00:30:23.701 --> 00:30:27.200
I picked 65023,
again you can pick whatever you wanted.

596
00:30:27.200 --> 00:30:32.650
The host this mapping exists for and
then the remote port on that host.

597
00:30:32.650 --> 00:30:34.430
The remote host is gonna be 23.

598
00:30:34.430 --> 00:30:39.000
And then a -N to say don't run any
commands, just build a tunnel.

599
00:30:39.000 --> 00:30:41.880
And when I run that it's gonna
prompt me for my password.

600
00:30:41.880 --> 00:30:46.625
I'll provide my password and
then it disappears, where'd it go?

601
00:30:46.625 --> 00:30:50.820
Well it went in the background, but
I now have a nice secure tunnel.

602
00:30:50.820 --> 00:30:53.260
An encrypted tunnel between me and
that server.

603
00:30:53.260 --> 00:30:58.390
That has an entry on my side at 65023 and
an exit on their side on port 23 and

604
00:30:58.390 --> 00:31:00.580
now I can flow traffic over it.

605
00:31:00.580 --> 00:31:04.140
>> So Don how does software
know to use the tunnel?

606
00:31:04.140 --> 00:31:05.193
>> Right, and
that's kinda the tricky part right?

607
00:31:05.193 --> 00:31:07.205
>> Yeah.
>> Because remember I said telnet is not

608
00:31:07.205 --> 00:31:08.767
even gonna know that this happened.

609
00:31:08.767 --> 00:31:14.032
If I type telnet 172.16.0.128,
you just know about tunnel.

610
00:31:14.032 --> 00:31:17.570
It's gonna ignore the tunnel and
go straight to that server, right?

611
00:31:17.570 --> 00:31:22.953
So instead,
what I need to do is say Telnet 127.0.0.1.

612
00:31:22.953 --> 00:31:24.995
I am Telnetting into myself.

613
00:31:24.995 --> 00:31:26.322
While i'm not running Telnet.

614
00:31:26.322 --> 00:31:28.040
So that's gonna fail.

615
00:31:28.040 --> 00:31:32.590
But I'm gonna specify a port number,
65023.

616
00:31:32.590 --> 00:31:37.224
I'm gonna Telnet into
myself on port 65023,

617
00:31:37.224 --> 00:31:40.574
which is the entrance to the tunnel.

618
00:31:40.574 --> 00:31:45.266
It'll enter the tunnel, cross encrypted
all over the network to the server, and

619
00:31:45.266 --> 00:31:49.899
it'll exit on port 23, where it'll find
the Telnet server on the other side.

620
00:31:49.899 --> 00:31:55.219
And when I run that I get a login
prompt and a password prompt and

621
00:31:55.219 --> 00:31:59.324
I log in and
Telnet is working just like normal.

622
00:31:59.324 --> 00:32:01.404
Telnet has no idea it's being encrypted.

623
00:32:01.404 --> 00:32:04.950
In fact, telnet thinks we just
remoted into ourselves on custom port.

624
00:32:04.950 --> 00:32:05.470
>> Wow.

625
00:32:05.470 --> 00:32:07.330
>> It has no idea the tunnel's even there.

626
00:32:07.330 --> 00:32:10.591
But now the data is encrypted,
sent across the line to the other side,

627
00:32:10.591 --> 00:32:14.140
decrypted at the other side, and
dropped off on the telnet server.

628
00:32:14.140 --> 00:32:16.216
I just took a crappy old protocol.

629
00:32:16.216 --> 00:32:18.025
>> [LAUGH]
>> With multiple encryption and

630
00:32:18.025 --> 00:32:21.175
now it's fully encrypted
using ECDSA certificate.

631
00:32:21.175 --> 00:32:22.357
It's really strong, so

632
00:32:22.357 --> 00:32:26.120
strong encryption on an ancient
protocol that's completely unaware.

633
00:32:26.120 --> 00:32:29.040
You can do this with any protocol,
anything.

634
00:32:29.040 --> 00:32:30.707
You can run X Windows over this stuff.

635
00:32:30.707 --> 00:32:32.666
You can do VNC.

636
00:32:32.666 --> 00:32:37.600
You can do FTP, even UDP type stuff.

637
00:32:37.600 --> 00:32:41.080
Syslog that doesn't do encryption,
you can send syslog this way.

638
00:32:41.080 --> 00:32:43.870
And now all your syslog data is
being encrypted across the network.

639
00:32:43.870 --> 00:32:45.900
That's a really good use for this.

640
00:32:45.900 --> 00:32:48.510
All of this being done via SSH.

641
00:32:48.510 --> 00:32:53.700
It's an incredibly powerful protocol, and
really helps you create on-demand VPNS.

642
00:32:53.700 --> 00:32:56.580
Things that allow you to have
that security of knowing

643
00:32:56.580 --> 00:32:59.150
that anybody intercepting your
traffic will not be able to read it

644
00:32:59.150 --> 00:33:00.500
unless they have your private key.

645
00:33:00.500 --> 00:33:03.340
>> Fantastic info as usual, Don.

646
00:33:03.340 --> 00:33:08.780
Data encryption with SSH, love this
episode, anything else you'd like to add?

647
00:33:08.780 --> 00:33:11.250
>> Some of you might be asking,
now, Don, you created a tunnel.

648

You telnet it,

00:33:13.665 --> 00:33:14.826
And I don't blame you, right?

650
00:33:14.826 --> 00:33:17.410
If you trust me, then,
hey, yeah, it's encrypted.

651
00:33:17.410 --> 00:33:18.116
>> We trust you, Don.

652
00:33:18.116 --> 00:33:21.106
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But if you don't, right,

653
00:33:21.106 --> 00:33:23.430
if you don't trust me, then great.

00:33:23.430 --> 00:33:25.245

655
00:33:25.245 --> 00:33:26.920

656
00:33:26.920 --> 00:33:28.208

657
00:33:28.208 --> 00:33:31.303
I'm gonna save it towards the end of
the series where we talk about some of

00:33:31.303 --> 00:33:34.588
the penetration tools that we can use or

659
00:33:34.588 --> 00:33:40.201
And take a look in there for
how we can validate network encryption.

660
00:33:40.201 --> 00:33:41.690
We'll have an episode for that.

661
00:33:41.690 --> 00:33:46.900
And I'll show you how we can
use tcpdump and Wireshark,

662
00:33:46.900 --> 00:33:49.360
which are two packet capture tools.

663
00:33:49.360 --> 00:33:52.220
And we can actually capture
the traffic on the network and

664
00:33:52.220 --> 00:33:54.090

665
00:33:54.090 --> 00:33:55.520
And that's really important.

666
00:33:55.520 --> 00:33:59.160
Cuz you may have gone through all these
steps and think it's being encrypted, and

667
00:33:59.160 --> 00:34:02.990

668
00:34:02.990 --> 00:34:05.250
And you don't' really know unless

669
00:34:05.250 --> 00:34:08.190
So look for those tools where we

670
00:34:08.190 --> 00:34:12.340
And we'll see how we can validate and
ensure that this information is

671
00:34:12.340 --> 00:34:15.480
actually being encrypted when

672
00:34:15.480 --> 00:34:17.243
Definitely, what was that
Ronald Regan always said?

673
00:34:17.243 --> 00:34:19.270
The trust but verified.

674
00:34:19.270 --> 00:34:19.994
>> Yes.

675
00:34:19.994 --> 00:34:24.870
>> We need to make sure that we

676
00:34:24.870 --> 00:34:28.162
But that we verify so

677
00:34:28.162 --> 00:34:30.780
You wanna be the one to find the problem,

00:34:30.780 --> 00:34:31.720
>> Great stuff, Don.

00:34:31.720 --> 00:34:33.973
And just because you're paranoid

24

So that's what we've got
lined up in this episode.

25
00:01:03.072 --> 00:01:07.442
>> And you know Don, although most of us
probably know some of what SELinux is all

26
00:01:07.442 --> 00:01:08.955
about, what is SELinux?

27
00:01:08.955 --> 00:01:11.617
>> [LAUGH] This is probably
a good idea to start there.

28
00:01:11.617 --> 00:01:16.630
[LAUGH] So SELinux stands for
Security Enhanced Linux.

29
00:01:16.630 --> 00:01:20.098
In the olden days, when Linux was created,

30
00:01:20.098 --> 00:01:23.673
the world was a much
more trustworthy place.

31
00:01:23.673 --> 00:01:25.998
That you could run a service
as the root user, and

32
00:01:25.998 --> 00:01:29.530
the service could access to your whole
hard drive and it was fine, right?

33
00:01:29.530 --> 00:01:31.590
It was okay, whatever, who cares?

34
00:01:31.590 --> 00:01:34.560
But now, it's gotten to the point
where a hacker can break in and

35
00:01:34.560 --> 00:01:35.670
compromise a service.

36
00:01:35.670 --> 00:01:39.281
And if they can compromise one service,
and it's running as root, or it has access

37
00:01:39.281 --> 00:01:42.749
to the whole hard drive, then the hacker
now has access to the whole hard drive.

38
00:01:42.749 --> 00:01:43.710
>> The whole thing.

39
00:01:43.710 --> 00:01:48.590
>> And we can't trust all the individual
services to be nice and secured anymore.

40
00:01:48.590 --> 00:01:54.400
So what SELinux does is, it steps in as
a subsystem, as a sublayer of the kernel.

41
00:01:54.400 --> 00:01:58.090
And it says, whenever a service runs,
we're gonna constrain it.

42
00:01:58.090 --> 00:02:01.050
We're gonna restrict what
it's allowed to access.

43
00:02:01.050 --> 00:02:05.250
So if I have a web server, for example,
it's gonna have a folder on the hard drive

44
00:02:05.250 --> 00:02:09.010
where the webpages are stored, and the web
server needs to access that folder.

45
00:02:09.010 --> 00:02:10.650
But does it need to
access my home directory?

46
00:02:10.650 --> 00:02:15.298
No, so SELinux kicks in and says,
I'm gonna block any of that access.

47
00:02:15.298 --> 00:02:17.504
And it creates these walls,
these boundaries, and

48
00:02:17.504 --> 00:02:20.220
it keeps each of these services
into their own respective area.

49
00:02:20.220 --> 00:02:22.464
So by doing that, if a hacker get's in,

50
00:02:22.464 --> 00:02:26.360
they'll only get access to the areas
of that particular service has.

51
00:02:26.360 --> 00:02:29.156
So if I've got a server
pulling more than one duty,

52
00:02:29.156 --> 00:02:33.057
maybe it's a web server and
the database server, and the file server,

53
00:02:33.057 --> 00:02:36.335
you see this in like some small and
medium businesses a lot.

54
00:02:36.335 --> 00:02:39.261
Well, one service get compromised and
the other stay safe.

55
00:02:39.261 --> 00:02:42.622
Now SELinux is an optional component,
you don't have to have,

56
00:02:42.622 --> 00:02:44.624
you can turn it of like I said earlier.

57
00:02:44.624 --> 00:02:49.590
But if you're running a distro like
Redhat, RTL, Redhat Enterprise Linux.

58
00:02:49.590 --> 00:02:51.900
If you're running CentOS,
if you're running Fedora.

59
00:02:51.900 --> 00:02:55.790
They've all got SELinux installed and
enabled by default.

60
00:02:55.790 --> 00:02:59.210
If you're running Ubuntu or
Debian, it's an optional package.

61
00:02:59.210 --> 00:03:02.700
You can install SELinux and enable it,
and get up and running the same way.

62
00:03:02.700 --> 00:03:04.730
So it's available on
all of those platforms.

63
00:03:04.730 --> 00:03:07.257
It really is a great technology,
definitely one that you want.

64
00:03:07.257 --> 00:03:09.580
So if you don't already have it on your
service, you should put it on there.

65
00:03:09.580 --> 00:03:11.957
But don't just go blindly turning it on,
cuz boy,

66
00:03:11.957 --> 00:03:14.630
it can wreak havoc if you
don't know what you're doing.

67
00:03:14.630 --> 00:03:17.311
And that's why so
many tutorials start with disable SELinux,

68
00:03:17.311 --> 00:03:19.902
cuz they don't take the time
to figure what they're doing.

69
00:03:19.902 --> 00:03:25.243
>> So Don, what this SELinux do when
it detects inappropriate access?

70
00:03:25.243 --> 00:03:26.565
>> Well,
that part's kinda up to us, right?

71
00:03:26.565 --> 00:03:28.535
So there's actually three modes for
SELinux, and

72
00:03:28.535 --> 00:03:30.725
hopefully, the mode that you're
in is what's called enforcing.

73
00:03:30.725 --> 00:03:32.565
In the enforcing mode, it blocks it.

74
00:03:32.565 --> 00:03:35.230
If it sees inappropriate access,
it stops it.

75
00:03:35.230 --> 00:03:38.530
If a web server process is
trying to access my home folder,

76
00:03:38.530 --> 00:03:41.100
it's stop it and
it's logs it to an audit log.

77
00:03:41.100 --> 00:03:42.808
And that way I know that it happened and
I can go and

78
00:03:42.808 --> 00:03:44.029
find out what the heck is going on.

79
00:03:44.029 --> 00:03:44.950
Cuz we need to be aware, right?

80
00:03:44.950 --> 00:03:46.798
>> Right.
>> But whats important is that it's stop

81
00:03:46.798 --> 00:03:48.460
it, that's the enforcing mode.

82
00:03:48.460 --> 00:03:50.155
There's another mode called disabled.

83
00:03:50.155 --> 00:03:52.600
[LAUGH] In disabled mode, it does nothing.

84
00:03:52.600 --> 00:03:54.310
It's say, whatever had it, right?

85
00:03:54.310 --> 00:03:57.690
But there is a third mode,
which is called permissive.

86
00:03:57.690 --> 00:04:01.310
And permissive is a strange one, because
what it does is it sees the inappropriate

87
00:04:01.310 --> 00:04:05.790
access, it lets it happen and
it logs it, right?

88
00:04:05.790 --> 00:04:08.180
So it's more like it detects
the inappropriate access.

89
00:04:08.180 --> 00:04:10.160
It doesn't actually do anything about it.

90
00:04:10.160 --> 00:04:13.280
Now you might ask yourself,
why in the heck would I use that?

91
00:04:13.280 --> 00:04:15.210
And you really use it when
you're troubleshooting.

92
00:04:15.210 --> 00:04:18.680
When I'm trying to figure out why SELinux
is stopping something from working,

93
00:04:18.680 --> 00:04:20.190
I can put it in permissive mode.

94
00:04:20.190 --> 00:04:22.380
I can run my application and
see what's going on.

95
00:04:22.380 --> 00:04:26.040
And then, I can look in the audit logs and
see where it tripped the SELinux alarm.

96
00:04:26.040 --> 00:04:27.167
>> More like when you play detective.

97
00:04:27.167 --> 00:04:28.773
You're trying to figure
out whose doing this or

98
00:04:28.773 --> 00:04:30.510
who is sending you these
inappropriate messages.

99
00:04:30.510 --> 00:04:31.032
>> Right.
And

100
00:04:31.032 --> 00:04:33.435
it's very similar to like a IDS,
IPS, right?

101
00:04:33.435 --> 00:04:35.890
IDS, Intrusion Detection System.

102
00:04:35.890 --> 00:04:37.580
IPS, Intrusion Prevention System.

103
00:04:37.580 --> 00:04:40.540
Preventing versus detecting
are two different things.

104
00:04:40.540 --> 00:04:41.957
>> Right.
>> And permissive mode and

105
00:04:41.957 --> 00:04:46.123
enforcing mode are detection and
prevention, that's what they do, so

106
00:04:46.123 --> 00:04:47.160
we pick the mode.

107
00:04:47.160 --> 00:04:50.939
Now on a Red Hat, CentOS,
or Fedora system,

108
00:04:50.939 --> 00:04:55.727
SELinux is installed enabled and
enforcing by default.

109
00:04:55.727 --> 00:04:59.490
So it's in there actively blocking things,
that's usually what we want.

110
00:04:59.490 --> 00:05:03.153
But if you install it on Debian or
Ubuntu, or one of the other distros,

111
00:05:03.153 --> 00:05:05.961
then it's typically in
permissive mode by default.

112
00:05:05.961 --> 00:05:09.141
And that way you can get it configured
first before going to enforcing,

113
00:05:09.141 --> 00:05:11.530
cuz otherwise you can
accidentally block yourself.

114
00:05:11.530 --> 00:05:13.549
So you'll definitely wanna check and
that and

115
00:05:13.549 --> 00:05:15.800
make sure you get in the right mode for
SELinux.

116
00:05:15.800 --> 00:05:19.880
>> So Don, how do we get started
in with configuring SELinux?

117
00:05:19.880 --> 00:05:22.441
>> All right, well the first thing is
we can just verify that we've even

118
00:05:22.441 --> 00:05:23.070
got it, right?

119
00:05:23.070 --> 00:05:24.295
Cuz we need get it installed.

120
00:05:24.295 --> 00:05:27.810
And it's got its own SELinux
package that you can get installed.

121
00:05:27.810 --> 00:05:30.900
The easiest way is just a simple command
here, I'll just run it real quick.

122
00:05:30.900 --> 00:05:34.098
I'm on a server running
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.4, and

123
00:05:34.098 --> 00:05:36.140
I'm just gonna run sestatus, right?

124
00:05:36.140 --> 00:05:38.775
So that's the Security-Enhanced Linux
status, and

125
00:05:38.775 --> 00:05:41.360
it will tell you whether
you've even got it, right?

126
00:05:41.360 --> 00:05:43.011

effectively created exceptions that say

409
00:23:06.680 --> 00:23:09.286
this custom service now
has access to that folder.

410
00:23:09.286 --> 00:23:12.540
And I didn't realize I was in the website
folder when I created these guys,

411
00:23:12.540 --> 00:23:14.790
so I probably need to
delete those out of there.

412
00:23:14.790 --> 00:23:17.547
No point in having those lying around,

413
00:23:17.547 --> 00:23:20.895
since I'm done with them anyway,
there we go.

414
00:23:20.895 --> 00:23:25.086
But now when I look at these guys it
doesn't matter to me that they've got

415
00:23:25.086 --> 00:23:27.919
the wrong context because
the policy allows it.

416
00:23:27.919 --> 00:23:31.468
So you can take a service that you've
never seen before, never used,

417
00:23:31.468 --> 00:23:35.512
have no idea what its context is, and
you can run through this process, right?

418
00:23:35.512 --> 00:23:40.863
Go into permissive mode, run the service,
use it's features, and then take the audit

419
00:23:40.863 --> 00:23:46.090
log, convert it to a policy, import the
policy, and then switch back to enforcing.

420
00:23:46.090 --> 00:23:50.590
And when you're done, your custom
service will now work perfectly fine.

421
00:23:50.590 --> 00:23:53.509
Meanwhile, SELinux is still enabled and
still doing its job, and

422
00:23:53.509 --> 00:23:55.344
your custom service is now partitioned.

423
00:23:55.344 --> 00:23:59.037
It's being held to the folders that
it needs access to do its job.

424
00:23:59.037 --> 00:24:03.282
Then you can take this policy file, and
we do all this on a lab computer, right?

425
00:24:03.282 --> 00:24:08.003
I can take this policy file, the .pp file,
Copy it to my production servers and

426
00:24:08.003 --> 00:24:09.063
import it there.

427
00:24:09.063 --> 00:24:11.684
So I didn't have to install
all the policy, core utils and

428
00:24:11.684 --> 00:24:13.890
all that stuff on my production servers.

429
00:24:13.890 --> 00:24:17.270
I just needed to generate the policy on my
lab server and move it into production.

430
00:24:17.270 --> 00:24:19.730
So a great way to deal
with custom services.

431
00:24:19.730 --> 00:24:21.110
>> SELinux, I am sold.

432
00:24:21.110 --> 00:24:23.250
Is there anything else it's capable of?

433
00:24:23.250 --> 00:24:26.580
I'm really focused on files for
this, and for most of you guys,

434
00:24:26.580 --> 00:24:28.832
that's what will happen
as you focus on files.

435
00:24:28.832 --> 00:24:34.090
But SELinux applies to other things too,
like processes and port numbers as well.

436
00:24:34.090 --> 00:24:35.910
My web server is running on port 80.

437
00:24:35.910 --> 00:24:44.170
If I were to look at the /etc/
httpd/comp/httpd.com file.

438
00:24:44.170 --> 00:24:46.050
In here somewhere is a listen command.

439
00:24:46.050 --> 00:24:47.150
Here is it, listen.

440
00:24:47.150 --> 00:24:48.570
It's listening on port 80.

441
00:24:48.570 --> 00:24:51.633
Well, what if I wanted to run
my server on a nonstandard port?

442
00:24:51.633 --> 00:24:56.503
Maybe I want to run my web server on 8080,
or 1024, or whatever, SELinux is saying,

443
00:24:56.503 --> 00:25:00.720
you know what, the web server's not
allowed to listen on those other ports.

444
00:25:00.720 --> 00:25:04.460
This must be a hacker trying to bypass
a firewall or something, so it stops it.

445
00:25:04.460 --> 00:25:08.480
So, we can actually manage
ports with SELinux as well.

446
00:25:08.480 --> 00:25:09.560
It's a lot less common, but

447
00:25:09.560 --> 00:25:13.040
if you ever run into it,
let me show you how that would be done.

448
00:25:13.040 --> 00:25:15.440
The command you'll run is SEmanage.

449
00:25:15.440 --> 00:25:19.550
That's the command I used a moment ago
to create our custom policies I'll say

450
00:25:19.550 --> 00:25:26.980
SEmanage port- a, and
you can add a context type to a port.

451
00:25:26.980 --> 00:25:28.560
In fact, you can kinda look
at what you've already got.

452
00:25:28.560 --> 00:25:31.780
If you say SEmanage port- l,

453
00:25:31.780 --> 00:25:37.440
it'll list out the ports that are already
approved, and I can find port 80 in here.

454
00:25:37.440 --> 00:25:40.070
I probably should have greped it,
because now I'm never gonna find it.

455
00:25:40.070 --> 00:25:41.048
In fact, let me do that.

456
00:25:41.048 --> 00:25:42.930
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'll grep that and

457
00:25:42.930 --> 00:25:44.260
then we'll just look for 80.

458
00:25:44.260 --> 00:25:44.840
Right?

459
00:25:44.840 --> 00:25:46.480
And so, that's gonna come up and

00:25:46.480 --> 00:25:51.280
right here, I've got HTTP port T,

461
00:25:51.280 --> 00:25:55.400
And it's allowing these,oops,
these port numbers.

462
00:25:55.400 --> 00:25:57.720
And 8080 is not in that list.

463
00:25:57.720 --> 00:25:59.184
8080 is not in that list.

464
00:25:59.184 --> 00:26:02.317
So if I move my we server to port 8080,
it's not gonna work,

00:26:02.317 --> 00:26:04.260
SELinux is gonna block it.

00:26:04.260 --> 00:26:11.510
And so I can come in and I can assign this

467
00:26:11.510 --> 00:26:16.875
I can say SEmanage port -a,
so I'm adding a context.

468
00:26:16.875 --> 00:26:19.430
-t for the context type.

469
00:26:19.430 --> 00:26:24.900
Mine's http port t, which again I got
from that list just a second ago.

470
00:26:24.900 --> 00:26:28.190
And then -p, I'm attaching it to a port.

471
00:26:28.190 --> 00:26:34.200
And it's gonna be tcp 8080, or
whatever port number it is you wanna use.

472
00:26:34.200 --> 00:26:35.670
And when I do that.

473
00:26:35.670 --> 00:26:39.430
It says already defined,
that's an interesting one.

474
00:26:39.430 --> 00:26:43.570
So I must already have some other context
type, I did dash a to add a context if

475
00:26:43.570 --> 00:26:46.320
it already has one,
I technically need to replace the context.

476
00:26:46.320 --> 00:26:48.610
But here we will just
take another port number,

477
00:26:48.610 --> 00:26:51.657
I must already had assigned to something,
I'll do 8888.

478
00:26:51.657 --> 00:26:56.459
So now I've attached 8888 to it and
if I go and

479
00:26:56.459 --> 00:27:00.923
pull my listing and I'll grep for 8888.

480
00:27:00.923 --> 00:27:07.450
I can now see that it's been added to
the HTTP underscore port underscore

481
00:27:07.450 --> 00:27:13.016
T list 80 and 81 are still there,
8888 is also there.

482
00:27:13.016 --> 00:27:18.514
So now it's been added and
I can I'm kind of curious what's 8080.

483
00:27:18.514 --> 00:27:20.053
HTTP_cache_port.

484
00:27:20.053 --> 00:27:21.980
Apparently that's being
used by another service.

485
00:27:21.980 --> 00:27:26.580
So I would have to remove that contact
before I could attach another one.

486
00:27:26.580 --> 00:27:29.890
But 8888 now is authorized and
right there.

487
00:27:29.890 --> 00:27:33.530
So if you start moving services to
other ports we do this with SSH

488
00:27:33.530 --> 00:27:37.690
where a lot of people change SSH's
default port SELinux will block it.

489
00:27:37.690 --> 00:27:40.020
And I've seen a lot of people where
they're scratching their heads they can't

490
00:27:40.020 --> 00:27:43.360
figure it out like, I've opened it in
the firewall I've allowed the secs

00:27:43.360 --> 00:27:46.250
I've changed it in ssh configuration and
it just won't work.

492
00:27:46.250 --> 00:27:49.900
And it turns out that it's SELinux all
along that's been stopping that access.

493
00:27:49.900 --> 00:27:51.660
So that's managing ports.

494
00:27:51.660 --> 00:27:54.180
Remember SELinux is very powerful.

495
00:27:54.180 --> 00:27:55.670
Doesn't manage just files?

496
00:27:55.670 --> 00:27:58.500
It, also, manages ports, and

497
00:27:58.500 --> 00:28:01.210
it can even manage things like users and
groups and other things too.

498
00:28:01.210 --> 00:28:02.600
It can really do some crazy stuff.

499
00:28:02.600 --> 00:28:05.100
But, usually we're focused
more on the file system,

500
00:28:05.100 --> 00:28:07.660
that's typically what we protect with it.

501
00:28:07.660 --> 00:28:12.060
>> So securing services with SELinux this
is part two make sure you see part one.

00:28:12.060 --> 00:28:14.770
Don anything else you wanna

>> The main thing is just don't
be intimidated by SELinux it's

504
00:28:17.480 --> 00:28:20.080
really powerful it will really
save your bacon if somebody ever

505
00:28:20.080 --> 00:28:23.180
breaks into your server it really
minimizes the damage they can do.

506
00:28:23.180 --> 00:28:27.292
So incredibly useful stuff,
very powerful, do not disable it.

So, if you care about security
You will leave SELinux enabled.

1

I'm your host, Zach Memos as we continue
on with Linux security techniques In this

5
00:00:21.802 --> 00:00:23.737
episode, we're going to jail.

6
00:00:23.737 --> 00:00:27.423
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're gonna chroot, jails.

7
00:00:27.423 --> 00:00:29.012
And who's gonna bring us that information.

8

9

hard time today as [LAUGH]

00:00:33.922 --> 00:00:36.128
>> We're gonna do, ten years right?

12

>> We're gonna have to see how many
jail jokes we can work into this one.

13
00:00:38.925 --> 00:00:43.891
But we are tackling chroot jails,
and chroot, it's just short for

14
00:00:43.891 --> 00:00:49.380
Change Root, is a utility we can use,
or it's a process we can use to change

15
00:00:49.380 --> 00:00:54.920
the way the final system looks to
a service or a user or an application.

16
00:00:54.920 --> 00:00:59.190
It's a way that we can isolate
something from the rest of our system.

17
00:00:59.190 --> 00:01:03.840
If you've got a system that has tons
of users that are connecting into it,

18
00:01:03.840 --> 00:01:07.080
one user in theory could bump into
another and start to cause problems.

19
00:01:07.080 --> 00:01:09.802
With chroot jails, we jail our users.

20
00:01:09.802 --> 00:01:13.091
We isolate them, we separate them so
they can't even see each other.

21
00:01:13.091 --> 00:01:15.150
They don't even know
somebody else is there.

22
00:01:15.150 --> 00:01:18.681
And I keep saying users but
often times you do this with services.

23
00:01:18.681 --> 00:01:21.952
Imagine I've got a database server and
a web server and

24
00:01:21.952 --> 00:01:25.161
they're both running on the same platform,
right?

25
00:01:25.161 --> 00:01:30.510
So I've got one operating system
running MariaDB and Apache.

26
00:01:30.510 --> 00:01:34.519
While a hacker could break into Apache,
and then leapfrog right over and

27
00:01:34.519 --> 00:01:37.091
compromise MariaDB from the inside, right?

28
00:01:37.091 --> 00:01:39.080
They're already past
the firewall at that point.

29
00:01:39.080 --> 00:01:39.972
That would be a problem.

30
00:01:39.972 --> 00:01:43.098
But if I jail them and
I isolate and separate them,

31
00:01:43.098 --> 00:01:48.510
the attacker could break into Apache and
then they don't see anything else, right?

32
00:01:48.510 --> 00:01:50.857
That MariaDB server might as well
be on a separate system as far as

33
00:01:50.857 --> 00:01:52.010
they're concerned.

34
00:01:52.010 --> 00:01:53.473
That's what chroot jails let us do.

35
00:01:53.473 --> 00:01:57.822
We isolate process to minimize
the impact of a compromise and

36
00:01:57.822 --> 00:02:02.020
the hide our system or
protect the rest of our system.

37
00:02:02.020 --> 00:02:03.609
So it's a powerful technology and

38
00:02:03.609 --> 00:02:07.295
it's one that you'll definitely want to
leverage out there in the real world.

39
00:02:07.295 --> 00:02:10.411
Like everything out there there's more
than one way to solve a problem and

40
00:02:10.411 --> 00:02:13.830
this is one of the potential ways that you
might protect the system specially when

41
00:02:13.830 --> 00:02:15.253
this is exposed to the Internet.

42
00:02:15.253 --> 00:02:18.980
>> So it's like a virtual side barrier
[LAUGH] You just kinda broke down

43
00:02:18.980 --> 00:02:22.110
what chroot is but
can you get to define it even further,

44
00:02:22.110 --> 00:02:24.345
let's know a little bit more about it?

45
00:02:24.345 --> 00:02:28.234
>> Yeah, one thing I run into from
a lot of users is that they confuse

46
00:02:28.234 --> 00:02:32.643
with chroot like, how is this
different than virtualization, right?

47
00:02:32.643 --> 00:02:36.070
If I do virtualization,
I have one laptop in front of me.

48
00:02:36.070 --> 00:02:38.216
And I'm running VMware workstation on it.

49
00:02:38.216 --> 00:02:43.155
And so I can create five different
Linux VMs, one running MariaDB,

50
00:02:43.155 --> 00:02:45.660
one running Apache and so on.

51
00:02:45.660 --> 00:02:47.883
And they're isolated and
separate aren't they?

52
00:02:47.883 --> 00:02:51.561
Okay, well that sounds like what I just
described a moment ago, the thing is,

53
00:02:51.561 --> 00:02:54.256
when you virtualize,
you're virtualizing hardware.

54
00:02:54.256 --> 00:02:59.340
You're creating a fake processor, fake
memory, fake disk, fake network adapter.

55
00:02:59.340 --> 00:03:02.122
And the Virtual Machines have
to talk to that fake equipment.

56
00:03:02.122 --> 00:03:05.697
Now in the olden days,
the older hypervisors that we used were

57
00:03:05.697 --> 00:03:09.980
called type 2 hypervisors,
did all this conversion stuff in software.

58
00:03:09.980 --> 00:03:11.241
So their performance was garbage.

59
00:03:11.241 --> 00:03:14.950
But in the newer days,
our type 1 hypervisors,

60
00:03:14.950 --> 00:03:17.400
they do this stuff in hardware.

61
00:03:17.400 --> 00:03:20.612
We have virtualization extensions in
our processors to speed things up,

62
00:03:20.612 --> 00:03:21.662
make it go a lot faster.

63
00:03:21.662 --> 00:03:24.490
So we get really good
performance out of it, but

64
00:03:24.490 --> 00:03:27.610
it's still an extra layer of complexity.

65
00:03:27.610 --> 00:03:33.891
If I'm running CentOS 7 on my laptop, and
I create five CentOS 7 Virtual Machines,

66
00:03:33.891 --> 00:03:37.992
then I've actually got six
CentOS 7 kernels running,

67
00:03:37.992 --> 00:03:42.024
six complete copies of
the operating system running.

68
00:03:42.024 --> 00:03:45.175
And then yeah I got MariaDB on one and
I've got Apache on another.

69
00:03:45.175 --> 00:03:48.399
But there's a huge amount of
duplication between them and

70
00:03:48.399 --> 00:03:51.080
that's eating up system resources.

71
00:03:51.080 --> 00:03:53.813
With a chroot jail what we do is we say,
you know,

72
00:03:53.813 --> 00:03:58.165
what I don't need a virtual network
card or a virtual processor or whatever.

73
00:03:58.165 --> 00:04:02.780
This stuff can all run in together right
here on my one installation I just want

74
00:04:02.780 --> 00:04:04.910
to separate them and isolate them.

75
00:04:04.910 --> 00:04:08.535
And so with chroot we don't
virtualize anything except for

76
00:04:08.535 --> 00:04:10.574
what the file system looks like.

77
00:04:10.574 --> 00:04:13.350
So everybody sees the same processor.

78
00:04:13.350 --> 00:04:14.982
Everybody sees the same memory.

79
00:04:14.982 --> 00:04:19.074
And they're acting at bare metal speed
because they're literally running on

80
00:04:19.074 --> 00:04:19.950
the bare metal.

81
00:04:19.950 --> 00:04:22.061
This is not virtualized at all.

82
00:04:22.061 --> 00:04:24.604
But when they look at the file system,

83
00:04:24.604 --> 00:04:28.272
they see a different file
system than everybody else.

84
00:04:28.272 --> 00:04:33.266
We control what they see we're changing
the root of their file system.

85
00:04:33.266 --> 00:04:37.355
You normally, like here on my machine,
if I browse to slash, the root folder and

86
00:04:37.355 --> 00:04:40.801
I take a look at what's in there,
it will search the stuff, right?

87
00:04:40.801 --> 00:04:45.810
You got /bin, /dev, /home and
all these other things, right?

88
00:04:45.810 --> 00:04:47.738
I see the whole filing system but

89
00:04:47.738 --> 00:04:51.532
with chroot we can show them
something completely different.

90
00:04:51.532 --> 00:04:54.500
I don't have to show them the actual root.

91
00:04:54.500 --> 00:04:57.702
I can take a folder like /var/www,

92
00:04:57.702 --> 00:05:03.390
where Apache lives,
I can tell it that this was the root.

93
00:05:03.390 --> 00:05:07.030
All it would see, if it went to slash,
it would just see a CGI bin folder and

94
00:05:07.030 --> 00:05:08.035
HTML folder ant that's it.

95
00:05:08.035 --> 00:05:12.609
It wouldn't see anything else and there'd
be no way to escape the jail to get out of

96
00:05:12.609 --> 00:05:17.072
it into the rest of the file system is now
isolated and partitioned to this area.

97
00:05:17.072 --> 00:05:20.405
And that's a great way to kind
of compartmentalize things

98
00:05:20.405 --> 00:05:22.723
without the burden of virtualization.

99
00:05:22.723 --> 00:05:26.043
And I'll tell you right now, right here in
the first five minutes of this episode,

100
00:05:26.043 --> 00:05:27.192
virtualization is easier.

101
00:05:27.192 --> 00:05:29.975
It's a heck of a lot
easier than chroot jail.

102
00:05:29.975 --> 00:05:34.533
All right, but
chroot jails are a lot more efficient.

103
00:05:34.533 --> 00:05:37.774
You'll get better performance out of
a system if you're just jailing your

104
00:05:37.774 --> 00:05:40.914
applications as opposed to actually
creating a virtual infrastructure

105
00:05:40.914 --> 00:05:41.810
around it.

106
00:05:41.810 --> 00:05:46.250
Now, there are a few other technologies
out there that we'll talk about in another

107
00:05:46.250 --> 00:05:49.311
episode like container technologies,
LXC and Docker.

108
00:05:49.311 --> 00:05:51.110
They're kind of in-between.

109

00:28:36.420 --> 00:28:38.862
If they come in here and
start creating files,

561
00:28:38.862 --> 00:28:43.220
I don't even have the touch command, do I?

562
00:28:43.220 --> 00:28:46.340
Nope, so I can't even create a file
here cuz I didn't give them any

563
00:28:46.340 --> 00:28:47.570
utilities to create a file.

564
00:28:47.570 --> 00:28:51.010
In fact, right now, they're gonna have
the shell built-ins, these commands.

565
00:28:51.010 --> 00:28:54.140
And then they'll have ls, that's
the only other thing I put in there.

566
00:28:54.140 --> 00:28:59.522
I guess maybe I could echo something,

567
00:28:59.522 --> 00:29:03.740
echo test data, file.txt.

568
00:29:03.740 --> 00:29:05.448
You could maybe do that.

569
00:29:05.448 --> 00:29:08.560
Shoot, I don't have permission on my own
folder, cuz I left it all owned by root.

570
00:29:09.595 --> 00:29:13.520
[LAUGH] But I would need to go back in the
regular file system and grant that access.

571
00:29:13.520 --> 00:29:15.580
But it is the same file system.

572
00:29:15.580 --> 00:29:22.725
So for example, if I were to get out, so
now I've exited out of the ssh session.

573
00:29:22.725 --> 00:29:30.453
As a regular user here, I could go
into /jail/service1/home/service1.

574
00:29:30.453 --> 00:29:34.705
And I could create a file called test.txt,
right?

575
00:29:34.705 --> 00:29:40.620
And I could change the permissions
on it to give full write access

576
00:29:40.620 --> 00:29:43.810
to that file, so that anybody can
get in there and change that file.

577
00:29:43.810 --> 00:29:49.890
And now, if I ssh back in, I get in,

578
00:29:49.890 --> 00:29:52.530
and there is that text.txt file, right?

579
00:29:52.530 --> 00:29:56.049
And if I had a text editor, I could
edit it, or change it, or whatever.

580
00:29:56.049 --> 00:29:58.381
I guess I could echo some data.

581
00:29:58.381 --> 00:30:04.743
test data, and
append it to text.txt, there we go.

582
00:30:04.743 --> 00:30:07.956
And so now I've appended
the little data onto that file.

583
00:30:07.956 --> 00:30:13.580
And if I get back out to my file
system here, I can take a look at it.

584
00:30:13.580 --> 00:30:16.312
And there's that test data
that got stuck onto it.

585
00:30:16.312 --> 00:30:19.550
So now we've got where they can
just do exactly what we want.

586
00:30:19.550 --> 00:30:21.640
That's the real power of a chroot jail.

587
00:30:21.640 --> 00:30:24.100
chroot jails are very powerful.

588
00:30:24.100 --> 00:30:27.100
And before virtualization was mainstream,

589
00:30:27.100 --> 00:30:31.588
this was really the best way to control
and isolate access inside of the system.

590
00:30:31.588 --> 00:30:33.200
It's still used today.

591
00:30:33.200 --> 00:30:35.570
You see a lot of systems
that make use of it even for

592
00:30:35.570 --> 00:30:38.480
simple things just like changing
where somebody's home directory is.

593
00:30:38.480 --> 00:30:41.070
There are other solutions
that you can make use of,

594
00:30:41.070 --> 00:30:45.330
that kind of are taking the place of
chroot and starting to minimize it today.

595
00:30:45.330 --> 00:30:46.470
But it's still out there.

596
00:30:46.470 --> 00:30:48.740
And it's a great technology to learn,
cuz you may still be using it.

597
00:30:49.830 --> 00:30:52.000
>> Well, there you have it, chroot jails.

598
00:30:52.000 --> 00:30:54.890
Lots of great information there,
and a great tool to use.

599
00:30:54.890 --> 00:30:56.910
Any last words on that?

600
00:30:56.910 --> 00:30:59.570
>> Just remember that the hard
part here is the dependencies.

601
00:30:59.570 --> 00:31:02.900
Figuring out what all needs to go into
the jail along with your application,

602
00:31:02.900 --> 00:31:04.380
to get it to work,
that's kind of a challenge.

603
00:31:05.540 --> 00:31:07.190
I was trying to get applications to work.

604
00:31:07.190 --> 00:31:10.154
If I was just doing SFTP,
this show would have been a lot shorter.

605
00:31:10.154 --> 00:31:14.100
I would have just done the chroot
directory in SSH, and left it at that.

606
00:31:14.100 --> 00:31:17.470
SFTP does everything else through SSH,
and you're done.

607
00:31:17.470 --> 00:31:20.410
So sometimes it can be really hard,
sometimes it could be really easy.

608
00:31:20.410 --> 00:31:22.380
I wanted to show you guys
a more difficult one,

609
00:31:22.380 --> 00:31:26.000
just so you guys get an idea of what it
would be like kind of worst case scenario.

610
00:31:26.000 --> 00:31:28.673
But it's a neat thing,
it just takes take time.

611
00:31:28.673 --> 00:31:30.370
It takes time to get it done right.

612
00:31:30.370 --> 00:31:32.090
Look for
documentation out there on the internet.

613
00:31:32.090 --> 00:31:35.960
Find people who have already put that
time in, to save you some effort.

614
00:31:35.960 --> 00:31:39.220
But definitely something that's
rewarding once it's in place.

615
00:31:39.220 --> 00:31:40.820
>> Awesome, great job done.

616
00:31:40.820 --> 00:31:43.280
chroot jails are good jails to have,
I guess.

617
00:31:43.280 --> 00:31:46.330
Linux Security Techniques has a lot
of episodes in this video series.

618
00:31:46.330 --> 00:31:48.990
Make sure you watch all of them,
you'll be glad you did.

619
00:31:48.990 --> 00:31:51.850
And thank you for
watching ITProTV, I'm Zach Memos.

620
00:31:51.850 --> 00:31:52.620
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

621
00:31:52.620 --> 00:31:56.102
>> And we will see you again very soon.

622
00:31:56.102 --> 00:32:01.939
[MUSIC]

623
00:32:01.939 --> 00:32:05.741
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover what LXC is, some of the background of LXC, how it differs from CHROOT, what it takes to get LXC up & running, how we create a container, how we install applications into the container, and how we remove a container when we no longer need it.
episodes.title: LXC Containers

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.536

6

7
00:00:20.720 --> 00:00:23.670

8

15

>> Saying Linux container containers,

22

there right now.

23
00:01:01.530 --> 00:01:04.771
But I wanted to tackle Linux containers
LXC, because it is really built for

24
00:01:04.771 --> 00:01:06.140
the Linux world in mind.

25
00:01:06.140 --> 00:01:10.550
Docker technically is too, but
LXE is one that's built into most distros.

26
00:01:10.550 --> 00:01:16.040
It's really easy to deploy and
it allows us to isolate applications

27
00:01:16.040 --> 00:01:17.980
in a way that's relatively pain free.

28
00:01:17.980 --> 00:01:19.160
If you've been watching
all of our episodes,

29
00:01:19.160 --> 00:01:22.240
you might have watched
our chroot jails episode.

30
00:01:22.240 --> 00:01:22.810
>> Yes.

31
00:01:22.810 --> 00:01:25.225
>> And working with chroot, it's not fun.

32
00:01:25.225 --> 00:01:27.420
[LAUGH] It's a lot of work.

33
00:01:27.420 --> 00:01:29.500
A lot of dependency tracking and so on.

34

35
00:01:32.240 --> 00:01:34.890
We can isolate applications
very easily and

36
00:01:34.890 --> 00:01:37.080
do it all from within
a single operating system.

37
00:01:37.080 --> 00:01:40.195
So that's what we're gonna be learning
right here in this episode on

38
00:01:40.195 --> 00:01:41.050
LXC containers.

39
00:01:41.050 --> 00:01:42.088
>> That's right.
And in fact,

40
00:01:42.088 --> 00:01:45.351
in that previous episode you mentioned
that you in fact like the containers

41
00:01:45.351 --> 00:01:46.070
a bit more.

42
00:01:46.070 --> 00:01:49.320
>> Absolutely.
>> It's like the in between of those.

43
00:01:49.320 --> 00:01:50.049
You started just now, but

44
00:01:50.049 --> 00:01:51.818
give us a little more background
on the LXC containers please.

45
00:01:51.818 --> 00:01:57.080
>> Sure, so virtualization hasn't
always been where it is today.

46
00:01:57.080 --> 00:02:00.170
In today's world,
enterprises virtualize constantly.

47
00:02:00.170 --> 00:02:04.930
And almost all of our systems are deployed
as virtual machines that are running on

48
00:02:04.930 --> 00:02:09.510
top of KVM or Zen, running on top
of VM Ware, or Hyper-V or whatever.

49
00:02:09.510 --> 00:02:13.010
But, before virtualization
really caught on,

50
00:02:13.010 --> 00:02:16.910
everything was run as separate processes
on a single operating system, and

51
00:02:16.910 --> 00:02:18.640
you got really great
performance out of that, right.

52
00:02:18.640 --> 00:02:22.020
These processes are running right on top
of the barrier metal and they ran great,

53
00:02:22.020 --> 00:02:25.040
you stick them in a virtual machine,
they run not so great.

54
00:02:25.040 --> 00:02:28.840
You start having other concerns,
things kind of start to take a hit there.

55
00:02:28.840 --> 00:02:32.930
Well, Linux containers
are kind of an in between.

56
00:02:32.930 --> 00:02:36.250
In between virtualization and
running natively.

57
00:02:36.250 --> 00:02:38.750
When you run something natively,
it has direct access to the hard drive,

58
00:02:38.750 --> 00:02:42.960
direct access to the network adaptors, the
processor, all through the kernel, right?

59
00:02:42.960 --> 00:02:46.560
So, it's all via the kernel, but
it gets us access to te hardware and

60
00:02:46.560 --> 00:02:47.300
it runs very fast.

61
00:02:47.300 --> 00:02:50.855
You stick it in a virtual machine,
it's talking to a virtual kernel,

62
00:02:50.855 --> 00:02:52.844
which is talking to virtual hardware,

63
00:02:52.844 --> 00:02:56.500
which then a real kernel has to
intercept and send to real hardware.

64
00:02:56.500 --> 00:02:59.060
And those middlemen,
that hurts performance.

65
00:02:59.060 --> 00:03:00.660
And the older Hypervisors,

66
00:03:00.660 --> 00:03:03.710
the old type two Hypervisors they
did a pretty poor job of it.

67
00:03:03.710 --> 00:03:06.900
And so in the 1990s and
even in early 2000s.

68
00:03:06.900 --> 00:03:08.240
>> That be the olden days.

69
00:03:08.240 --> 00:03:09.680
>> The olden days in IT.

70
00:03:09.680 --> 00:03:13.330
Those were really holding
virtualization just to testing and

71
00:03:13.330 --> 00:03:14.880
development environments.

72
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:17.780
And only now in the 2000s

73
00:03:17.780 --> 00:03:20.580
do we have type 1 hypervisors
that actually run much faster.

74
00:03:20.580 --> 00:03:22.450
They use hardware acceleration.

75
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:25.090
There's still this 2nd kernel
that we're talking to.

76
00:03:25.090 --> 00:03:28.260
And this underlying virtual hardware,
a conversion has happened.

77
00:03:28.260 --> 00:03:30.530
It's much, much faster,
but it's still there.

78
00:03:30.530 --> 00:03:35.470
And so you get near bare metal performance
when you run applications inside of

79
00:03:35.470 --> 00:03:36.760
a virtual machine.

80
00:03:36.760 --> 00:03:38.550
You do get nice isolation, though.

81
00:03:38.550 --> 00:03:41.440
If I have ten VMs and
somebody breaks into one of them,

82
00:03:41.440 --> 00:03:44.640
the other nine are safe,
unless they find a way to break into them.

83
00:03:44.640 --> 00:03:46.430
They're ten separate machines.

84
00:03:46.430 --> 00:03:49.720
So you get isolation and
a little bit of a hit on performance.

85
00:03:49.720 --> 00:03:54.450
What LXC does is it lets
us create containers that

86
00:03:54.450 --> 00:03:57.730
are all sharing one kernel.

87
00:03:57.730 --> 00:04:04.251
If I have a CentOS 7 machine and
I spin up ten CentOS 7 Virtual machines.

88
00:04:04.251 --> 00:04:05.987
Well now I've got 11 kernels running.

89
00:04:05.987 --> 00:04:09.114
Thought the ten in the VM's and the one
underneath, we've got 11 kernels running.

90
00:04:09.114 --> 00:04:12.995
And 11 copies of most operating system
libraries that are all loaded into memory.

91
00:04:12.995 --> 00:04:15.093
It's very inefficient, I'm wasting space.

92
00:04:15.093 --> 00:04:17.325
It's easy to do, but I'm wasting space.

93
00:04:17.325 --> 00:04:20.636
And the advantage of a VM
is usually convenient.

94
00:04:20.636 --> 00:04:25.503
With LXC it says look, we're all gonna use
the same kernel, we're all gonna use a lot

95
00:04:25.503 --> 00:04:29.222
of the same components, so
why not let one common kernel run, and

96
00:04:29.222 --> 00:04:32.200
we'll share it across
all these containers.

97
00:04:32.200 --> 00:04:33.830
And you can stick your
application on the container.

98
00:04:33.830 --> 00:04:36.890
The application can load all sorts
of other stuff that it needs, but

99
00:04:36.890 --> 00:04:39.460
it's still sharing that one kernel.

100
00:04:39.460 --> 00:04:43.640
So it's like it's virtualized,
they're isolated from each other, but

101
00:04:43.640 --> 00:04:47.150
at the same time, they're sharing
some underlined resources so

102
00:04:47.150 --> 00:04:50.460
that they don't have to do anything
crazy when talking to hardware.

103
00:04:50.460 --> 00:04:51.370
When they talk to hardware,

104
00:04:51.370 --> 00:04:54.570
they go to the shared kernel, which then
gives them direct access to hardware.

105
00:04:54.570 --> 00:04:57.190
So we get great performance, and

106
00:04:57.190 --> 00:05:00.580
we get great isolation, and
it really does work well.

107
00:05:00.580 --> 00:05:05.330
The negative of LXC is that
because there's a shared kernel,

108
00:05:05.330 --> 00:05:08.850
if you've got a Linux host,
you've gotta have Linux containers.

109
00:05:08.850 --> 00:05:10.290
It's all built around Linux.

110
00:05:10.290 --> 00:05:11.900
Thus the name LXC.

111
00:05:11.900 --> 00:05:15.340
If I was running VMware,
I could have a Linux host, and

112
00:05:15.340 --> 00:05:18.310
I could run a Windows guest
VM if I wanted, right?

113
00:05:18.310 --> 00:05:21.862
You can have completely different OSes
cuz the hardware is being abstracted.

114
00:05:21.862 --> 00:05:24.159
With LXC the hardware is not abstracted,

115
00:05:24.159 --> 00:05:27.620
people are reaching right
into touch that file system.

116
00:05:27.620 --> 00:05:29.390
Then and that's a good thing, right?

117
00:05:29.390 --> 00:05:31.711
The history of this, when LXC was created,

118
00:05:31.711 --> 00:05:34.974
it was designed to give us
isolation without the need for VMs,

119
00:05:34.974 --> 00:05:38.515
cuz VMs weren't at the performance
point where they needed to be.

120
00:05:38.515 --> 00:05:42.531
Now, LXC has kind of changed direction and
their goal is to, not so

121
00:05:42.531 --> 00:05:47.504
much create this isolation environment,
but create a consistent environment.

122
00:05:47.504 --> 00:05:50.030
So a developer can create
an application in test.

123
00:05:50.030 --> 00:05:53.620
And then deploy in production, and as long
as it's an LXC container is on both ends,

124
00:05:53.620 --> 00:05:55.610
the deployment will look the same.

125
00:05:55.610 --> 00:05:58.050
And so
they've seen a lot of development in that.

126
00:05:58.050 --> 00:06:03.100
Right now, most of the development in LXC
is happening from Canonical or Ubuntu.

127
00:06:03.100 --> 00:06:05.420
They're the ones who are dumping
the most money into it.

128
00:06:05.420 --> 00:06:09.620
Red Hat used to invest in Alexi, but
recently they've switched to Docker, and

129
00:06:09.620 --> 00:06:11.490
said we're going to back Docker.

130
00:06:11.490 --> 00:06:15.741
Well, if you're running CentOS, or
Fedora, you could still use LXC, RHEL,

131
00:06:15.741 --> 00:06:17.910
doesn't include LXC support anymore.

132
00:06:17.910 --> 00:06:19.460
So, they actually bumped it out.

133
00:06:19.460 --> 00:06:21.540
But if you've got Ubuntu,
or Debian, it's there.

134
00:06:21.540 --> 00:06:24.900
Here in the show,
I'm going to use CentOS 7 to fire this up.

135
00:06:24.900 --> 00:06:26.660
It is still widely supported.

136
00:06:26.660 --> 00:06:27.750
It's still being developed.

137
00:06:27.750 --> 00:06:28.750
It's still very active.

138
00:06:28.750 --> 00:06:34.030
And it's still a great solution, but
Docker is kinda taking over this space.

139
00:06:34.030 --> 00:06:37.990
The problem is, LXC was designed
to solve a security problem.

140
00:06:37.990 --> 00:06:40.940
Docker was designed to solve
a programmer's problem,

141
00:06:40.940 --> 00:06:42.420
a developer's problem.

142
00:06:42.420 --> 00:06:46.050
From a security perspective,
Docker actually has some weaknesses in it.

143
00:06:46.050 --> 00:06:48.961
I prefer LXC as a more complete solution.

144
00:06:48.961 --> 00:06:52.629
So, in this episode we're going to walk
through that process of getting LXC

145
00:06:52.629 --> 00:06:56.414
installed, creating some containers,
throwing some applications in those

146
00:06:56.414 --> 00:06:59.912
containers and kinda seeing what that
process looks like to create these

147
00:06:59.912 --> 00:07:03.080
isolated environments and
get them up and going on our systems.

148
00:07:03.080 --> 00:07:06.250
>> So, John, you've already,
kind of touched on this, but further,

149
00:07:06.250 --> 00:07:07.831
how does this differ from CH Root?

150
00:07:07.831 --> 00:07:10.920
>> All right, CH Root
>> When we did that,

151
00:07:10.920 --> 00:07:12.900
you have a common kernel, right?

152
00:07:12.900 --> 00:07:15.900
You access the system,
you put it into a jail.

153
00:07:15.900 --> 00:07:18.460
And the jail is running that same
common kernel as the underlying OS.

154
00:07:18.460 --> 00:07:20.760
So, so far,
this sounds just like a container.

155
00:07:20.760 --> 00:07:23.690
The big difference is
that with a chroot jail,

156
00:07:23.690 --> 00:07:26.690
you're really just hiding the file system,
right?

157
00:07:26.690 --> 00:07:28.820
The file system is being restricted for
you.

158
00:07:28.820 --> 00:07:31.710
You see a different subset
of the file system.

159
00:07:31.710 --> 00:07:35.260
>> But the processes that are running
in memory, the other activities,

160
00:07:35.260 --> 00:07:40.670
the TCP ports and stuff like that, those
are all shared, even across the jails.

161
00:07:40.670 --> 00:07:43.130
So it's really just a filesystem jail.

162
00:07:43.130 --> 00:07:44.590
With LXC,

623
00:30:00.860 --> 00:30:04.489

00:30:04.489 --> 00:30:07.941

00:30:07.941 --> 00:30:09.652

00:30:26.940 --> 00:30:29.410

00:00:41.320 --> 00:00:46.740
It's a little add-on that can be stuck

19
00:00:46.740 --> 00:00:49.150
And allow us to filter access to it.

20
00:00:49.150 --> 00:00:52.960

26
00:01:14.778 --> 00:01:17.840
It was the first real chance

27
00:01:17.840 --> 00:01:20.350
And while it refer to

29

And that's why there's still a use for
them today.

36
00:01:47.700 --> 00:01:49.790
If you know they're there and
if you know to take advantage of it.

37
00:01:49.790 --> 00:01:52.955
So in this episode we're gonna

46
00:02:11.500 --> 00:02:16.720
And I will tell you guys, when I deploy

So I go to Amazon Web Services EC2,

48
00:02:18.850 --> 00:02:22.890

49
00:02:22.890 --> 00:02:26.770

50
00:02:26.770 --> 00:02:28.470
I like to have a little

something that we can make and

it's kind of built in.

53
00:02:33.170 --> 00:02:35.870
So that's what we're gonna look

54
00:02:35.870 --> 00:02:38.780
>> Well now I'm definitely intrigued,
can you get a little bit

55
00:02:38.780 --> 00:02:41.730
deeper about the TCP Wrappers,
what are they and how we can use them?

56
00:02:41.730 --> 00:02:44.060
>> Sure, so basically the idea, and

57
00:02:44.060 --> 00:02:47.110
remember this all came about before
software firewalls is really a thing.

58
00:02:48.200 --> 00:02:50.020
Was that people had services.

59
00:02:50.020 --> 00:02:54.390
So you had things like SSH and
Telnet and FTP and whatever.

60
00:02:54.390 --> 00:02:57.350
And they all needed
a way to filter traffic.

61
00:02:57.350 --> 00:02:59.200
It was kind of left up
to them to develop it.

62
00:02:59.200 --> 00:03:01.970
Well, most of the people who
are developing software like that aren't

63
00:03:01.970 --> 00:03:02.780
security focused.

64
00:03:02.780 --> 00:03:03.920
They're more feature focused.

65
00:03:03.920 --> 00:03:04.840
So they just weren't doing it.

66
00:03:04.840 --> 00:03:06.760
There really wasn't something in place.

67
00:03:06.760 --> 00:03:10.167
So they came up with this kind of
standard solution, TCP Wrappers.

68
00:03:10.167 --> 00:03:13.109
They created a library called LibWrap, and

69
00:03:13.109 --> 00:03:17.253
the wrapper library could easily
be tacked on to any service.

70
00:03:17.253 --> 00:03:21.600
And then any connection coming into
that service could be quickly filtered.

71
00:03:21.600 --> 00:03:26.120
And so services like SSH and
xinetd, that powers TelNet,

72
00:03:26.120 --> 00:03:31.810
vsftpd, they added that support to be
able to leverage the TCP Wrappers.

73
00:03:31.810 --> 00:03:36.460
And so once that's done, we then have some
control files we can define to specify

74
00:03:36.460 --> 00:03:40.260
what IP addresses or what users can
come in, which ones are denied.

75
00:03:40.260 --> 00:03:43.760
And it basically becomes
a software firewall just for

76
00:03:43.760 --> 00:03:45.590
that one particular service.

77
00:03:45.590 --> 00:03:47.290
It leaves the rest of the system alone.

78
00:03:47.290 --> 00:03:51.810
And if services choose to ignore libwrap
and not use it, they can do that, right?

79
00:03:51.810 --> 00:03:54.150
They don't have to use it,
in fact many services don't.

80
00:03:54.150 --> 00:03:57.636
So in those scenarios it was really
designed to be an easy solution for

81
00:03:57.636 --> 00:03:58.246
security.

82
00:03:58.246 --> 00:04:02.036
And today we have software firewalls
that can kind of fit that mold, but

83
00:04:02.036 --> 00:04:04.130
in the olden days we didn't have that.

84
00:04:04.130 --> 00:04:07.310
And so libwrap became that solution.

85
00:04:07.310 --> 00:04:12.880
It's supported today in every Linux
distro that I've touched I haven't yet

86
00:04:12.880 --> 00:04:16.060
to encounter a distro that didn't
have support for TCP Wrappers.

87
00:04:16.060 --> 00:04:19.860
It's baked in and it's actually supported
in a lot of other Linux based Os'

88
00:04:19.860 --> 00:04:22.050
like OSD and then platforms like that too.

89
00:04:22.050 --> 00:04:26.160
So it's really prevalent and it's one
that we kind of count on being there.

90
00:04:26.160 --> 00:04:29.690
So you'll see it and it's just something
we can use to help increase that security.

91
00:04:29.690 --> 00:04:32.420
>> So how do we know if
a service supports TCP Wrappers?

92
00:04:32.420 --> 00:04:33.542
>> That's really where we need to start.

93
00:04:33.542 --> 00:04:36.150
Because if I'm trying
to secure a service and

94
00:04:36.150 --> 00:04:40.414
it doesn't support the TCP Wrappers
then this whole thing is pointless.

95
00:04:40.414 --> 00:04:42.570
And I'll have to use a software firewall.

96
00:04:42.570 --> 00:04:46.350
So for example, I need to find out if

97
00:04:46.350 --> 00:04:51.660
they're using the libwrap DLL,
if they're pulling that library file in.

98
00:04:51.660 --> 00:04:55.610
If they're doing that,
then they support the TCP Wrappers, right?

99
00:04:55.610 --> 00:04:56.750
So I mentioned SSH.

100
00:04:56.750 --> 00:04:58.200
That's how I normally use this.

101
00:04:58.200 --> 00:05:00.970
If I wanna verify,
I can use a utility called ldd.

102
00:05:00.970 --> 00:05:04.360
ldd shows you the dependencies
that a program has.

103
00:05:04.360 --> 00:05:05.810
And I can run ldd.

104
00:05:05.810 --> 00:05:07.950
And I can point it at SSH.

105
00:05:07.950 --> 00:05:12.070
Now if I don't know where SSH is,
I can do a, which sshd,

106
00:05:12.070 --> 00:05:15.870
and it'll tell me where on my
hard drive that daemon resides.

107
00:05:15.870 --> 00:05:20.110
So if I'm testing Apache,
or SSH, or whatever,

108
00:05:20.110 --> 00:05:23.200
I can come in and I can do this,
and I can find where they reside.

109
00:05:23.200 --> 00:05:28.815
So maybe I also have a database server,
actually let me sudo this real quick.

110
00:05:28.815 --> 00:05:31.550
I'm gonna bump up to a root-shell so

111
00:05:31.550 --> 00:05:33.680
I don't have to bump
into to many permissions.

112
00:05:33.680 --> 00:05:36.135
And I'll install mariadb.

113
00:05:36.135 --> 00:05:38.740
Oops, shoot I wanted mariadb server.

114
00:05:38.740 --> 00:05:44.050
That's what I wanted so
let's add that mariadb.server.

115
00:05:44.050 --> 00:05:44.680
There we go.

116
00:05:44.680 --> 00:05:46.170
So I'm gonna install mariadb as well.

117
00:05:46.170 --> 00:05:48.920
So I'll have SSAs, but
I'll also have mariadb.

118
00:05:48.920 --> 00:05:51.970
And I can come in here, and

119
00:05:51.970 --> 00:05:56.595
I can take a look at, whether or
not they support that service.

120
00:05:56.595 --> 00:05:58.710
>> Mm-hm.
>> So I can say like which sshd,

121
00:05:58.710 --> 00:06:00.960
and it will find it on my hard drive.

122
00:06:00.960 --> 00:06:06.950
And then, I can say ldd /sbin/sshd,
that's where mine is, right?

123
00:06:06.950 --> 00:06:12.550
And when I do that, it'll show me all
the libraries that sshd depends on.

124
00:06:12.550 --> 00:06:14.110
And there's quite a few, so

125
00:06:14.110 --> 00:06:18.850
I normally grip this oops,
to save me a little bit of time.

126
00:06:18.850 --> 00:06:21.580
Let me get out of that, there we go.

127
00:06:21.580 --> 00:06:26.170
And so
I'm going to re run that ldd/sbim/sshd and

128
00:06:26.170 --> 00:06:30.680
I'm going to grip for libwrap and
I'm going to look for that.

129
00:06:30.680 --> 00:06:31.520
And there it is.

130
00:06:31.520 --> 00:06:36.780
So sure enough sshd includes libwrap so
