131
00:06:37.860 --> 00:06:45.560
But if I installed something like mysql or
mariadb, and I can find it.

132
00:06:45.560 --> 00:06:49.074
Let's see it, mariadb-server, and oops.

133
00:06:49.074 --> 00:06:55.085
Actually, I am not finding it, so it's
tucked away somewhere [LAUGH] In mysqld or

134
00:06:55.085 --> 00:06:57.180
there you go, /bin/mysql.

135
00:06:57.180 --> 00:07:02.381
So I can come in and
I can say ldd /bin/mysql and

136
00:07:02.381 --> 00:07:06.810
I can look and I can try and spot libwrap.

137
00:07:06.810 --> 00:07:14.010
And if I grip this one for
libwrap I get nothing, right?

138
00:07:14.010 --> 00:07:17.580
So it doesn't have support for
libwrap built into it.

139
00:07:17.580 --> 00:07:19.500
I will not be able to use
TCP Wrappers with that one.

140
00:07:19.500 --> 00:07:23.390
So it's important that you
check that first, all right?

141
00:07:23.390 --> 00:07:25.710
Well, I use TCP Wrappers to secure SSH.

142
00:07:25.710 --> 00:07:28.980
That's where I use it, and
SSH has that support so that's good.

143
00:07:28.980 --> 00:07:32.580
VSFTPD is another one so
if you've got an FTP server set up.

144
00:07:32.580 --> 00:07:35.580
If you're doing SFTP
that's done through SSH so

145
00:07:35.580 --> 00:07:37.690
we can use TCP Wrappers there as well.

146
00:07:37.690 --> 00:07:42.280
Some of the other ones that are out there,
RPC Bind which is used as part of

147
00:07:43.780 --> 00:07:46.720
Samba, so
we can use that to control access there.

148
00:07:46.720 --> 00:07:49.844
So there's several different services that
are available that actually have this kind

149
00:07:49.844 --> 00:07:51.033
of built into it, so just check.

150
00:07:51.033 --> 00:07:53.965
Use LDD, and if you see a libwrap,
then you'll know it's supported.

151
00:07:53.965 --> 00:07:55.537
And you'll be able to
use the TCP Wrappers.

152
00:07:55.537 --> 00:07:57.971
>> So how do we enable TCP Wrappers for
a service?

153
00:07:57.971 --> 00:08:01.043
All right,
well technically it's already enabled.

154
00:08:01.043 --> 00:08:01.612
>> Right.

155
00:08:01.612 --> 00:08:05.780
>> When they include that library,
they're now using the wrappers.

156
00:08:05.780 --> 00:08:07.750
The thing is the wrappers just
aren't configured, right.

157
00:08:07.750 --> 00:08:09.340
So let me show you how
the configuration works.

158
00:08:09.340 --> 00:08:09.900
>> Okay.

159
00:08:09.900 --> 00:08:15.150
>> If you go into /etc and you look
at all the files that are in there,

160
00:08:15.150 --> 00:08:20.900
you're gonna find two files,
hosts.allow and host.deny.

161
00:08:20.900 --> 00:08:27.392
Those two files are what powers
the TCP wrappers, if I can say it.

162
00:08:27.392 --> 00:08:29.330
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hosts.allow,

163
00:08:29.330 --> 00:08:33.020
like the name implies, these are people
that are allowed to use a service.

164
00:08:33.020 --> 00:08:36.150
And hosts.deny, these are people that are
denied from using the service, all right.

165
00:08:36.150 --> 00:08:39.160
So these two files are gonna
build up that list.

166
00:08:39.160 --> 00:08:45.100
And by default, if I take a look
at hosts.allow, it's empty.

167
00:08:45.100 --> 00:08:46.850
Well not technically, I mean,
it's got the comments, right.

168
00:08:46.850 --> 00:08:49.310
Everything here has a hash tag at
the very beginning, a pound symbol,

169
00:08:49.310 --> 00:08:51.100
so they're all commented out, right.

170
00:08:51.100 --> 00:08:53.710
So nobody is allowed.

171
00:08:53.710 --> 00:08:59.940
And if I look at hosts.deny, same thing,
it's all commented out, nobody's denied.

172
00:08:59.940 --> 00:09:05.010
The way these files are applied,
the allow file is processed first, and

173
00:09:05.010 --> 00:09:07.898

00:25:45.390 --> 00:25:48.250

00:25:48.250 --> 00:25:48.810

00:25:48.810 --> 00:25:51.564
And there's actually,

00:25:55.580 --> 00:25:57.070

00:26:04.915 --> 00:26:08.380
%a says, put in their IP address.

00:26:08.380 --> 00:26:11.370

00:26:11.370 --> 00:26:13.910
I can use the date command

00:26:20.010 --> 00:26:21.035

00:26:28.400 --> 00:26:30.386

00:26:30.386 --> 00:26:34.170
You could do,
let's do some of the other ones, %u.

00:26:34.170 --> 00:26:36.236

00:26:36.236 --> 00:26:39.000
If it's something that is not logged in,

00:26:39.000 --> 00:26:42.104

00:26:42.104 --> 00:26:48.260

00:26:48.260 --> 00:26:52.450

00:26:52.450 --> 00:26:54.730

00:26:54.730 --> 00:26:57.325

00:27:13.709 --> 00:27:15.260

I say when they log in, go and run this

00:27:19.773 --> 00:27:22.845
Now, if I wanna be a really tricky,
like on a deny,

00:27:22.845 --> 00:27:26.930
they might be trying to log in and

00:27:26.930 --> 00:27:29.820

30
00:01:22.221 --> 00:01:23.550

00:01:28.380 --> 00:01:31.575

00:01:38.170 --> 00:01:42.120

37
00:01:42.120 --> 00:01:44.860

00:01:44.860 --> 00:01:48.550

00:01:48.550 --> 00:01:52.147

00:02:51.890 --> 00:02:55.390

>> Well, the easiest way,

00:02:57.870 --> 00:02:59.360

Having firewall-cmd,

68
00:03:23.759 --> 00:03:26.900

00:03:55.984 --> 00:03:58.650

00:05:18.320 --> 00:05:22.370

00:05:22.370 --> 00:05:25.580

00:05:25.580 --> 00:05:28.440

00:05:31.070 --> 00:05:33.820

00:05:35.880 --> 00:05:37.310

00:06:01.890 --> 00:06:05.980

00:06:05.980 --> 00:06:09.310

00:06:09.310 --> 00:06:11.728

00:07:49.222 --> 00:07:50.926

00:07:50.926 --> 00:07:57.533
So firewall-cmd--get zones, that just lets

00:08:07.092 --> 00:08:11.182

00:08:33.420 --> 00:08:37.380
This is important, because as we go

00:08:51.570 --> 00:08:53.955

But if you've got more than one interface,

00:09:02.033 --> 00:09:04.050

00:09:04.050 --> 00:09:07.880

00:09:07.880 --> 00:09:11.230

00:09:11.230 --> 00:09:14.410

00:09:14.410 --> 00:09:17.068

00:09:17.068 --> 00:09:20.630

00:09:20.630 --> 00:09:23.810

00:09:23.810 --> 00:09:27.940

00:09:27.940 --> 00:09:29.690

00:09:29.690 --> 00:09:32.300
without having to run separate

00:09:32.300 --> 00:09:34.611
We can really get some power there.

If I don't like the public zone, right?

00:09:57.769 --> 00:10:01.818

00:10:01.818 --> 00:10:07.574
And if I pull up my,
let me just do a firewall-

00:10:07.574 --> 00:10:12.440
cmd -- get- default zone, there.

00:10:12.440 --> 00:10:14.470
I could see my default is now internal,

00:10:14.470 --> 00:10:17.070
So I've overridden that default

00:10:17.070 --> 00:10:19.760
But really a name is just a name.

00:10:19.760 --> 00:10:21.991
If it's called public, it doesn't

It's in that zone.

If I had other interfaces, they would

00:11:27.741 --> 00:11:29.326
I could have four, five, a hundred,

And so I might need to shift them off to

they're active and they're up and going.

So right now, I can create rules on that

Creating rules on another

00:14:26.660 --> 00:14:30.550

00:14:30.550 --> 00:14:32.810

00:28:16.901 --> 00:28:19.333
configuration, or at least it should be.

534
00:28:19.333 --> 00:28:24.155
And if I pull up my list again,
I'll do a --list-all,

535
00:28:24.155 --> 00:28:27.880
everything should look
the way that I want.

536
00:28:27.880 --> 00:28:31.598
I just have ssh, http, and https, and

537
00:28:31.598 --> 00:28:37.870
now I can go through and
do a firewall-cmd --reload.

538
00:28:37.870 --> 00:28:40.800
And this is gonna let me test to make sure

539
00:28:40.800 --> 00:28:43.070
that the configuration is
the same after the reload.

540
00:28:43.070 --> 00:28:44.272
I would do this after-hours,

541
00:28:44.272 --> 00:28:47.478
in some kind of off-time when it
was okay to restart that firewall.

542
00:28:47.478 --> 00:28:50.560
Now that it's done, I can see the
configuration is done the way that I want.

543
00:28:50.560 --> 00:28:56.312
So as far as adding rules,
the key thing is to remember here --zone=.

544
00:28:56.312 --> 00:28:59.385
You've got to specify the zone,
otherwise it goes to the default zone.

545
00:28:59.385 --> 00:29:02.930
Then --add-service followed by a name,

546
00:29:02.930 --> 00:29:08.580
that'll get that entry put in there,
and then --permanent.

547
00:29:08.580 --> 00:29:10.446
Run the command with it
to save it to disk, and

548
00:29:10.446 --> 00:29:11.931
run without it to save it to memory.

549
00:29:11.931 --> 00:29:16.727
So we wanna do those twice so
we don't have to restart our firewall and

550
00:29:16.727 --> 00:29:18.308
get that put in place.

551
00:29:18.308 --> 00:29:20.706
But once that's done,
we've got the entries in place.

552
00:29:20.706 --> 00:29:26.020
It's up and it's going and now I'm
allowing traffic to pass that firewall.

553
00:29:26.020 --> 00:29:30.060
>> Now here's another boomerang, what
if I wanna manage non-standard traffic?

554
00:29:30.060 --> 00:29:33.067
>> Okay, so I just showed you
an example of the name, http.

555
00:29:33.067 --> 00:29:36.960
That's standard traffic,
it knew it, it had a name for it.

556
00:29:36.960 --> 00:29:39.218
But a lot of times we're dealing
with non-standard traffic.

557
00:29:39.218 --> 00:29:43.250
Traffic that either doesn't have
a name the system knows about or

558
00:29:43.250 --> 00:29:46.000
is just using a port,
maybe we've changed the port, right?

559
00:29:46.000 --> 00:29:50.950
Maybe I'm using SSH, but I run it on
port 2222 instead to try and hide it.

560
00:29:50.950 --> 00:29:53.790
It's not very effective,
but maybe I do that.

561
00:29:53.790 --> 00:29:57.140
So now I wanna allow that traffic through,
but I can't use those names, and

562
00:29:57.140 --> 00:29:58.290
that's fine.

563
00:29:58.290 --> 00:30:02.470
When you create a rule, the syntax for
it's actually really powerful.

564
00:30:02.470 --> 00:30:05.248
We can match by a ton of things,
I'm matching here by a name,

565
00:30:05.248 --> 00:30:06.360
by a service name.

566
00:30:06.360 --> 00:30:10.390
But you can match by a port number,
by an IP address, a source IP or

567
00:30:10.390 --> 00:30:13.390
a destination IP, these are all
things that we can match with.

568
00:30:13.390 --> 00:30:16.920
So if it's a non-standard service, I just
need to understand how that service works.

569
00:30:19.870 --> 00:30:22.580
Well, I guess it depends on how
much effort I wanna put forth also,

570
00:30:22.580 --> 00:30:24.970
cuz there's two kind of
ways I can handle this.

571
00:30:24.970 --> 00:30:28.416
The easy way, let's say that I'm
allowing SSH, but it's on port 2222.

572
00:30:28.416 --> 00:30:34.700
So I just wanna allow TCP Port 2222 to
come in and pass through the system.

573
00:30:34.700 --> 00:30:36.533
I don't wanna do anything too crazy,
just get it working.

574
00:30:36.533 --> 00:30:42.295
I could come through and
I could say firewall-cmd --zone=public

575
00:30:42.295 --> 00:30:46.673
is the zone I'm using,
whichever zone you're on.

576
00:30:46.673 --> 00:30:50.000
And then I'll do --permanent so
that I have this one.

577
00:30:50.000 --> 00:30:57.200
And then I'm gonna say --add-port, instead
of add-service, I'm doing add-port.

578
00:30:57.200 --> 00:31:03.130
And then I'll say = 2222/tcp.

579
00:31:03.130 --> 00:31:06.820
If it was a udp I'd have to say /udp,
or I could leave it off and

580
00:31:06.820 --> 00:31:09.170
just say port 2222 and it would do both.

581
00:31:09.170 --> 00:31:12.212
But I'm gonna specify it that way,
and that's gonna add that entry.

582
00:31:12.212 --> 00:31:17.800
And I'm adding it not based on a name,
just on a number, right?

583
00:31:17.800 --> 00:31:19.890
On that port number so
now that traffic will come in.

584
00:31:19.890 --> 00:31:23.590
The firewall doesn't actually care
whether that's SSH traffic or not, right?

585
00:31:23.590 --> 00:31:24.824
It's not doing deep packet inspection.

586
00:31:24.824 --> 00:31:30.383
So it's just basically gonna look at that
and if it sees anything that matches it,

587
00:31:30.383 --> 00:31:35.961
here it is, ports 2222/tcp will now be
allowed to pass through this system.

588
00:31:36.990 --> 00:31:40.680
Now, that's the least amount of
effort to get this kinda put in.

589
00:31:40.680 --> 00:31:44.990
If I wanna put forth a little more effort,
I could create a name.

590
00:31:44.990 --> 00:31:50.387
Or I could override the SSH name
to have 2222 instead of 22.

591
00:31:50.387 --> 00:31:52.553
So when you install FirewallD, or

592
00:31:52.553 --> 00:31:57.345
it's usually installed by default,
if you poke around on the file system.

593
00:31:57.345 --> 00:32:03.822
If you into /etc/firewalld, Right, that's
where firewalld's configuration is stored.

594
00:32:03.822 --> 00:32:05.977
See how I've got
firewalld.conf right here, and

595
00:32:05.977 --> 00:32:08.220
all these other different entries in here.

596
00:32:08.220 --> 00:32:12.590
But you'll see services, and
if you go inside of that services folder,

597
00:32:13.610 --> 00:32:18.220
what you'll find is nothing, it's empty.

598
00:32:18.220 --> 00:32:22.710
Well, this is a spot where we
can put in custom services and

599
00:32:22.710 --> 00:32:27.655
I can give them a name or I can
override services that already exist.

600
00:32:27.655 --> 00:32:31.703
I could create,
it's a little XML file in here, and

601
00:32:31.703 --> 00:32:35.944
if I create an XML file in here and
define that service.

602
00:32:35.944 --> 00:32:38.640
Then it can have a name and
it can be stored right here.

603
00:32:38.640 --> 00:32:41.360
And sometimes that's useful for
really complex services.

604
00:32:41.360 --> 00:32:46.690
Things like FTP, where it uses ports 21
and port 20, it's not just a single port.

605
00:32:46.690 --> 00:32:49.555
And there's a relationship between
those ports, we can define that.

606
00:32:49.555 --> 00:32:53.365
So it's got a way that we can do that if
we wanna put forth a little more effort.

607
00:32:53.365 --> 00:32:55.469
And if you pull up
the firewalld documentation,

608
00:32:55.469 --> 00:32:57.327
they give you the syntax for
that XML file.

609
00:32:57.327 --> 00:32:59.416
And actually the sample ones are stored,

610
00:32:59.416 --> 00:33:02.347
I'm trying to remember where
the sample ones are stored.

611
00:33:02.347 --> 00:33:05.430
They're stored somewhere [LAUGH].

612
00:33:05.430 --> 00:33:07.716
So buried somewhere in our file system,
I think it's in /lib/firewalld or

613
00:33:07.716 --> 00:33:08.625
something like that.

614
00:33:08.625 --> 00:33:11.395
But you can find some examples there,
but it is in the documentation,

615
00:33:11.395 --> 00:33:12.600
you can see how to build that out.

616
00:33:12.600 --> 00:33:16.800
So if this is something I'm gonna be doing
frequently, then I can build that XML

617
00:33:16.800 --> 00:33:20.246
file, and whenever I deploy a new server
i can make that a part of my build image.

618
00:33:20.246 --> 00:33:26.270
So that's in
/etc/firewalld/services/donsserver.xml,

619
00:33:26.270 --> 00:33:28.325
or whatever my custom service is called,

620
00:33:28.325 --> 00:33:30.910
and that way it'll be loaded and
the system will recognize it.

621
00:33:30.910 --> 00:33:34.900
So that's a kind of a another
key piece of getting firewalld

622
00:33:34.900 --> 00:33:37.038
working the way that we need it to work.

623
00:33:37.038 --> 00:33:40.470
>> Fantastic, well we've been looking
at network security with Firewall D,

624
00:33:40.470 --> 00:33:42.080
heard a lot of great stuff.

625
00:33:42.080 --> 00:33:43.660
Don, you did a wonderful job.

626
00:33:43.660 --> 00:33:45.679
You wanna add anything before we move on?

627
00:33:45.679 --> 00:33:47.140
>> Just a little bit.

628
00:33:47.140 --> 00:33:51.060
In this episode I really just kind of hit
the tip of the iceberg with firewalld.

629
00:33:51.060 --> 00:33:54.130
It is very powerful,
it can do a heck of a lot of stuff.

630
00:33:54.130 --> 00:33:55.460
I wanted to get you guys
familiar with it and

631
00:33:55.460 --> 00:33:57.440
understand how we can use it
to filter traffic, right?

632
00:33:57.440 --> 00:34:00.090
It's a basic security technique for
hardening a server, so

633
00:34:00.090 --> 00:34:02.670
that's what I've shown you, but
do know there's a lot more.

634
00:34:02.670 --> 00:34:07.340
For example, if you are an instant
response person and you get notified.

635
00:34:07.340 --> 00:34:10.627
Somebody tells you, hey Don, it looks
like this server's been compromised,

636
00:34:10.627 --> 00:34:11.619
somebody's in there.

637
00:34:11.619 --> 00:34:14.887
Well, we know one of the rules is that
you don't wanna turn that server off,

638
00:34:14.887 --> 00:34:17.098
cuz you need what's in RAM
to be able to protect it.

639
00:34:17.098 --> 00:34:20.673
But, at the same time, we need to stop
an attacker from getting in, and so

640
00:34:20.673 --> 00:34:22.240
we can use firewalld to do that.

641
00:34:22.240 --> 00:34:26.240
It's got what's called a panic mode,
and let me just show you real quick.

642
00:34:26.240 --> 00:34:31.566
If I go over here to this system,
and I run firewall-cmd

643
00:34:31.566 --> 00:34:35.540
--panic-on, I can turn on panic mode.

644
00:34:35.540 --> 00:34:39.033
Now, I'm SSHed in, so
this is gonna be interesting.

645
00:34:39.033 --> 00:34:41.843
>> [LAUGH]
>> But when I turn on panic, it stops.

646
00:34:43.105 --> 00:34:46.497
>> I just immediately disabled
all network communications,

647
00:34:46.497 --> 00:34:48.540
including my SSH session, right?

648
00:34:48.540 --> 00:34:50.910
So I'm now kicked out of this server,
effectively.

649
00:34:50.910 --> 00:34:55.876
But what I've done is, by immediately
stopping all network communications,

650
00:34:55.876 --> 00:34:59.148
I can now start my forensic
analysis on the machine.

651
00:34:59.148 --> 00:35:01.260
I know that the hacker has been severed,
they've been cut out.

652
00:35:01.260 --> 00:35:03.940
Now there could be problems there,
like if I'm trying to intercept network

653
00:35:03.940 --> 00:35:06.340
sessions or other things,
I might have just damaged data there.

654
00:35:06.340 --> 00:35:08.320
But it's neat to have that functionality.

655
00:35:08.320 --> 00:35:12.730
And then we can do the same command,
firewall-cmd --panic-off, and

656
00:35:12.730 --> 00:35:14.810
then it turns that mode back off again.

657
00:35:14.810 --> 00:35:19.220
Or you can do, I think it's --query-panic
to find out which mode you're in.

658
00:35:19.220 --> 00:35:23.090
It's usually pretty obvious which mode
you're in, but that's one example.

659
00:35:23.090 --> 00:35:26.250
We can do authorizing traffic based
on source and destination IP,

660
00:35:26.250 --> 00:35:27.920
I think I mentioned that earlier.

661
00:35:27.920 --> 00:35:31.682
There's other triggers you can do,
you can do time-based rules that say

662
00:35:31.682 --> 00:35:34.421
this traffic's allowed
between these times of day.

663
00:35:34.421 --> 00:35:38.731
You can do really, really advanced stuff
with firewall-cmd, it's a very powerful,

664
00:35:38.731 --> 00:35:39.499
or firewalld.

665
00:35:39.499 --> 00:35:42.296
It is very powerful, so
definitely take advantage of it.

666
00:35:42.296 --> 00:35:45.517
And if you're still running IP tables,
one of the questions I get is,

00:35:45.517 --> 00:35:47.056

00:35:47.056 --> 00:35:52.555
And the short answer is,
it's something you'll want to do,

00:35:52.555 --> 00:35:55.210
not something you need to do.

670
00:35:55.210 --> 00:35:57.655
IP tables is very powerful too,
it does a lot of stuff.

671
00:35:57.655 --> 00:36:00.140
It's not as flexible as firewalld though,
so

672
00:36:00.140 --> 00:36:02.865
the sooner you get moved over to it,
the better off you'll be.

00:36:02.865 --> 00:36:06.890
>> Great information as always,

674
00:36:06.890 --> 00:36:10.540
This is Linux security techniques, and

675
00:36:10.540 --> 00:36:13.540
And please watch them all,
because you'll be very happy that you did,

676
00:36:13.540 --> 00:36:14.641
Don does a wonderful job.

677
00:36:14.641 --> 00:36:19.978
And thank you for watching ITPRO.TV,
remember a good IT pro is always learning.

678
00:36:19.978 --> 00:36:20.706
I'm Zach Memos.

00:36:20.706 --> 00:36:21.658
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

680
00:36:21.658 --> 00:36:23.062

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what tools we can use to see if our firewall is working properly, how we can see what ports are open on our system, how netstat works, what 'SS' is, how we can see what the firewall is allowing, how we can test which ports are actually closed, how we use nmap to scan for open ports, what port states mean, and other scan types.

>> A lot times it does take a while.

527
00:23:40.880 --> 00:23:43.324
I guess I [INAUDIBLE] one IP and
it went fast enough.

528
00:23:43.324 --> 00:23:46.870
Remember that we're checking ports and
There's 65,535 ports.

529
00:23:46.870 --> 00:23:48.866
It could take a while to scan them.

530
00:23:48.866 --> 00:23:51.310
Shoot, actually I
remembered why it ran fast.

531
00:23:51.310 --> 00:23:52.963
With the default like this.
When I just run Nmap and

532
00:23:52.963 --> 00:23:57.760
I point to an NIP like this, it's
actually just getting the top 100 ports.

533
00:23:57.760 --> 00:23:59.480
That's why it ran so fast.

534
00:23:59.480 --> 00:24:02.360
It's just checking the top 100,
the common services.

535
00:24:02.360 --> 00:24:06.070
And so it scans and it finds those, and
it even found some that weren't so common.

536
00:24:06.070 --> 00:24:07.810
So it actually went a little bit further.

537
00:24:07.810 --> 00:24:10.440
I can see it got that 2222 too,
which is not a common port.

538
00:24:10.440 --> 00:24:16.050
That was something I made up, but
it picked up that I have SSH, HTTP and

539
00:24:16.050 --> 00:24:21.950
HTTPS that are ports that it's listening
on and then 2222 is also there.

540
00:24:21.950 --> 00:24:26.500
So it's showing that those ports were
there and then it saw them, right?

541
00:24:26.500 --> 00:24:28.850
Now I don't see SMTP, I don't see port 25.

542
00:24:28.850 --> 00:24:33.070
I know my server was listening on port
25 but the firewall is blocking it and

543
00:24:33.070 --> 00:24:37.270
I can see that it didn't even turn
up here in the list of open ports.

544
00:24:37.270 --> 00:24:39.990
I was not able to connect,
so that's a good sign.

545
00:24:39.990 --> 00:24:42.080
It means my firewall is working.

546
00:24:42.080 --> 00:24:44.910
Now I don't normally just run
Nmap by itself like this.

547
00:24:44.910 --> 00:24:48.180
I normally come through and
limit the ports or specify a port range.

548
00:24:48.180 --> 00:24:49.370
So if you run that command again and

549
00:24:49.370 --> 00:24:52.880
you add a -p,
you can tell it the ports you wanna scan.

550
00:24:52.880 --> 00:24:55.080
So for example,
if I wanna scan ports one through 1024.

551
00:24:55.080 --> 00:24:59.270
Those are the registered
ports right the regulates.

552
00:24:59.270 --> 00:25:06.320
So I'm saying sudo nmap-p 1-1024 and
then the IP I wanna scan.

553
00:25:06.320 --> 00:25:10.030
Now it's gonna check those 1,000 ports and
this'll probably take a little bit longer.

554
00:25:10.030 --> 00:25:13.970
So it's gonna scan through and
it's gonna 1024 ports, there it goes.

555
00:25:13.970 --> 00:25:17.500
And I get back, well,
almost the same information.

556
00:25:17.500 --> 00:25:18.990
I didn't get 2222, right?

557
00:25:20.170 --> 00:25:22.000
Because that was above my limit.

558
00:25:22.000 --> 00:25:23.360
My limit was 1024.

559
00:25:23.360 --> 00:25:25.375
But I could even tell it to go crazy.

560
00:25:25.375 --> 00:25:30.995
I could tell it to do all 65,535 ports,
scan the whole thing, right?

561
00:25:30.995 --> 00:25:33.520
And now I'm gonna get
a good view of that server.

562
00:25:33.520 --> 00:25:35.050
I'm gonna see anything that's open.

563
00:25:35.050 --> 00:25:38.820
And this is typically what I'll do,
because I wanna know,

564
00:25:38.820 --> 00:25:42.340
if you have a malware that
gets installed on a server and

565
00:25:42.340 --> 00:25:45.700
puts in a backdoor, the backdoor
port will normally be a high number.

566
00:25:45.700 --> 00:25:49.850
Usually it will be over 40,000 cuz they
wanted to avoid standard scans like this,

567
00:25:49.850 --> 00:25:52.370
and they wanna avoid bumping into
other software that might be running.

568
00:25:52.370 --> 00:25:53.830
Cuz they're trying to hide themselves.

569
00:25:53.830 --> 00:25:57.490
So you do really need to scan all the
ports, and so this is typically what I'll

570
00:25:57.490 --> 00:26:01.890
do and this scan will take longer, because
it's having to check all 65,000 of those.

571
00:26:01.890 --> 00:26:05.400
So it'll probably take about a minute as
it runs through and it does that scan, but

572
00:26:05.400 --> 00:26:08.630
then it'll give me that full view
back of what's open on the system.

573
00:26:08.630 --> 00:26:11.570
>> Don, what do the port states mean?

574
00:26:11.570 --> 00:26:14.470
>> Okay, yep, so while we're waiting
on this, this is actually a good time.

575
00:26:14.470 --> 00:26:17.240
You've got the port state here and
see how we've got open and closed?

576
00:26:17.240 --> 00:26:20.875
There's actually six different
states that you might see.

577
00:26:20.875 --> 00:26:24.970
Open means hey,
that port is accepting connections and

578
00:26:24.970 --> 00:26:27.135
there's software answering
us on the other side.

579
00:26:27.135 --> 00:26:31.245
So when I ran Nmap,
it actually tried to do a TCP connection.

580
00:26:31.245 --> 00:26:35.682
So it actually connected to the port,
and tried to throw some traffic at it.

581
00:26:35.682 --> 00:26:37.732
And software on the other
side responded back, so

582
00:26:37.732 --> 00:26:39.822
it knows that it's open and
it's functional.

583
00:26:39.822 --> 00:26:41.142
That's one that's exposed.

584
00:26:41.142 --> 00:26:42.362
That's a risk.

585
00:26:42.362 --> 00:26:43.722
It may be an accepted risk.

586
00:26:43.722 --> 00:26:46.732
We want that web server to make
port 80 available, or whatever.

587
00:26:46.732 --> 00:26:49.052
But it's telling me that it's open.

588
00:26:49.052 --> 00:26:53.910
Closed means the firewall was
letting the traffic through, but

589
00:26:53.910 --> 00:26:57.220
there was nothing on the other
side to respond to it.

590
00:26:57.220 --> 00:27:00.960
And in this case, it's HTTPS
that came back as closed for me.

591
00:27:00.960 --> 00:27:03.240
I just fired up Apache, right?

592
00:27:03.240 --> 00:27:05.630
I just did a quick default kind of thing,
and threw it together.

593
00:27:05.630 --> 00:27:07.751
Well, Apache is gonna
give me two problems.

594
00:27:07.751 --> 00:27:10.399
Problem number one,
is it's probably not set up for SSL, so

595
00:27:10.399 --> 00:27:12.258
it's probably not answering on 443.

596
00:27:12.258 --> 00:27:13.990
So that's problem number one.

597
00:27:13.990 --> 00:27:16.590
Well problem number two,
it doesn't have a valid certificate and so

598
00:27:16.590 --> 00:27:18.460
that's gonna cause
connection issues there too.

599
00:27:18.460 --> 00:27:21.330
So it's telling me though that it
managed to get through the firewall but

600
00:27:21.330 --> 00:27:24.000
that nothing answered on the other side.

601
00:27:24.000 --> 00:27:28.475
There's actually two other responses we
might see here, which are filtered and

602
00:27:28.475 --> 00:27:29.880
unfiltered.

603
00:27:29.880 --> 00:27:33.990
Filtered is when we get a message back
from the firewall telling us we were

604
00:27:33.990 --> 00:27:36.310
blocked, we were actively
blocked going to the firewall.

605
00:27:36.310 --> 00:27:37.560
So if you see the word filtered,

606
00:27:37.560 --> 00:27:41.020
it means the firewall actively
stopped us and told us.

607
00:27:41.020 --> 00:27:45.130
If you see unfiltered, it means the
firewall actively told us that we could

608
00:27:45.130 --> 00:27:48.110
get through but we may not have gotten
a response from the other side.

609
00:27:48.110 --> 00:27:49.661
If we got a response from
the software on the other side,

610
00:27:49.661 --> 00:27:51.140
we would have gotten an open statement.

611
00:27:51.140 --> 00:27:55.380
So unfiltered is very,
very similar to closed.

612
00:27:55.380 --> 00:28:00.280
Then there's a couple of states for when
Nmap just can't figure out what happened,

613
00:28:00.280 --> 00:28:06.040
where it will say things like
ope/unfiltered or I'm sorry,

614
00:28:06.040 --> 00:28:10.900
it's open/filtered or closed/unfiltered.

615
00:28:10.900 --> 00:28:13.330
Where it can't determine
what the actual state is.

616
00:28:13.330 --> 00:28:16.870
It says, I talked to it,
I got a response back but

617
00:28:16.870 --> 00:28:18.090
the responses doesn't make any sense.

618
00:28:18.090 --> 00:28:21.350
It looks like a block, but
it could be response from that software.

619
00:28:21.350 --> 00:28:24.610
And you see this when you're using
like TCP wrappers to block something,

620
00:28:24.610 --> 00:28:27.000
you got through the firewall,
you didn't get to the actual software but

621
00:28:27.000 --> 00:28:28.310
TCP wrappers blocked us.

622
00:28:28.310 --> 00:28:31.870
It's a weird message, and so
you get this kind of combo state.

623
00:28:31.870 --> 00:28:36.710
So there's actually four different states,
but with those combo ones, you end up with

624
00:28:36.710 --> 00:28:40.900
six total different combinations
that you could get in response.

625
00:28:40.900 --> 00:28:44.150
Now, my full scan just finished,
and I can see here, fortunately,

626
00:28:44.150 --> 00:28:46.665
that I actually don't have
anything else here in this list.

627
00:28:46.665 --> 00:28:47.670
It did a pretty good scan.

628
00:28:47.670 --> 00:28:52.900
I got the information back and
now I can tell this is what's configured.

629
00:28:52.900 --> 00:28:54.440
I don't have Telnet open.

630
00:28:54.440 --> 00:28:58.200
I don't have SMPT open, and I know that
the firewall's working properly and

631
00:28:58.200 --> 00:28:59.580
securing that.

632
00:28:59.580 --> 00:29:03.580
>> So we're getting closer to the end
of time, the end of time as we know it.

633
00:29:03.580 --> 00:29:06.100
Are there any other scan types?

634
00:29:06.100 --> 00:29:08.210
>> There are a couple of other
scan types that you might use.

635
00:29:08.210 --> 00:29:09.590
This was using a TCP connect.

636
00:29:11.020 --> 00:29:13.437
What about UDP?
Didn't scale for it.

637
00:29:13.437 --> 00:29:14.840
Yup, so that didn't happen.

638
00:29:14.840 --> 00:29:18.920
So if I wanna do that, if I wanna do a UDP
scan as well, I need to change this.

639
00:29:18.920 --> 00:29:24.450
And if you wanna modify the scan,
use -s followed by another letter, right?

640
00:29:24.450 --> 00:29:28.230
The -s is lower case, the next
letter I type is gonna be capital.

641
00:29:28.230 --> 00:29:31.100
And that letter's gonna determine
what kind of scan that I did.

642
00:29:31.100 --> 00:29:32.610
The default scan is TCP connect.

643
00:29:32.610 --> 00:29:34.210
That's -s with a capital T.

644
00:29:34.210 --> 00:29:38.360
So you don't really have to type
that one cuz that's the default, but

645
00:29:38.360 --> 00:29:43.100
if I wanna do UDP, it would be -s with
a capital U and then it will scan.

646
00:29:43.100 --> 00:29:44.770
And let me just shrink
that port number down.

647
00:29:44.770 --> 00:29:46.900
Actually, here.
I'll just leave the ports off.

648
00:29:46.900 --> 00:29:48.690
So we'll do a smaller scan on that one.

649
00:29:48.690 --> 00:29:51.160
And now it's gonna look at the server and
it's gonna look for

650
00:29:51.160 --> 00:29:53.000
those UDP ports that might be open.

651
00:29:53.000 --> 00:29:55.200
And that's important
because I'm running syslog.

652
00:29:55.200 --> 00:30:00.360
Syslog is on port 514 but it's UDP,
so see how it didn't show up up here?

653
00:30:00.360 --> 00:30:03.871
But it will show up on this UDP scan,
or at least I hope it does.

654
00:30:03.871 --> 00:30:06.740
[LAUGH] I guess I should have
limited the ports down to just 514.

655
00:30:06.740 --> 00:30:09.070
But it will scan and it'll come back.

656
00:30:09.070 --> 00:30:11.350
In fact, I'm getting impatient so
let me redo this.

657
00:30:11.350 --> 00:30:13.140
And I'll just say -p -514.

658
00:30:13.140 --> 00:30:15.088
I'm just gonna scan that one port.

659
00:30:15.088 --> 00:30:17.460
And it's gonna look at it,
and there it goes, I get it.

660
00:30:17.460 --> 00:30:20.480
Notice I'm not filtered,
it just says closed syslog.

661
00:30:20.480 --> 00:30:23.720
I must not have configured
our syslog on this one.

662
00:30:23.720 --> 00:30:25.270
But it shows that it's there.

663
00:30:25.270 --> 00:30:26.490
See how it found it.

664
00:30:26.490 --> 00:30:30.880
So it's letting me know that it is there,
it's just not responding back to me.

665
00:30:30.880 --> 00:30:34.520
So in our syslog, you actually have to
define who's allowed to connect and

666
00:30:34.520 --> 00:30:37.120
I'm not in that list, so
I'm getting the closed message.

667
00:30:37.120 --> 00:30:38.996
I'm not getting filtered by the firewall,

668
00:30:38.996 --> 00:30:41.080
I'm getting closed by
syslog on the other side.

669
00:30:41.080 --> 00:30:44.821
And another type of scan we can do,
those TCP connects,

670
00:30:44.821 --> 00:30:47.470
some systems detect those, right?

671
00:30:47.470 --> 00:30:49.690
Cisco firewalls do deep
packets inspection and

672
00:30:49.690 --> 00:30:51.870
they can actually see what we're doing and
stop it.

673
00:30:51.870 --> 00:30:55.059
So you can do what's called
the stealth sin connect instead and

674
00:30:55.059 --> 00:30:59.350
stealth sin connects can sometimes find
connections that a normal connect can't.

675
00:30:59.350 --> 00:31:04.340
And so for that, you would do a dash
lower case s followed by capital S.

676
00:31:04.340 --> 00:31:05.990
And that says do a stealth sin.

677
00:31:05.990 --> 00:31:09.900
And with this, it's not actually
trying to talk to the software.

678
00:31:09.900 --> 00:31:12.090
It's just doing the TCP handshake.

679
00:31:12.090 --> 00:31:14.370
The syn, ack right?

680
00:31:14.370 --> 00:31:17.360
You send a syn message,
the other side sends a syn ack and

681
00:31:17.360 --> 00:31:18.550
then you send an ack back right.

682
00:31:18.550 --> 00:31:20.150
That's the handshake, and
then you stop right there.

683
00:31:20.150 --> 00:31:21.350
So there's no malicious payload.

684
00:31:21.350 --> 00:31:22.870
It's just a handshake
that anybody would do.

685
00:31:22.870 --> 00:31:24.410
And a lot of times,

686
00:31:24.410 --> 00:31:28.260
that can detect things that
next-generation firewalls are blocking.

687
00:31:28.260 --> 00:31:30.310
So, it's another good scan to run.

688
00:31:30.310 --> 00:31:34.730
In my case, it didn't turn up anything
different, but it can pop things up, too.

689
00:31:34.730 --> 00:31:37.370
So that's another scan that
you might want to be aware of.

690
00:31:37.370 --> 00:31:43.060
And then one last one, before any scan,
it does this host is up check.

691
00:31:43.060 --> 00:31:46.910
It sends a ping to make sure the host is
up and if the ping fails, it gives up and

692
00:31:46.910 --> 00:31:47.905
it never scans the ports.

693
00:31:47.905 --> 00:31:51.680
Well, a lot of people
block pings today and so

694
00:31:51.680 --> 00:31:54.250
if that happens, we need to
force it to run the ping anyway.

695
00:31:54.250 --> 00:31:59.927
And so the way you do that
is you add a dash capital P,

696
00:31:59.927 --> 00:32:04.020
capital N and
that disables ping probes, right?

697
00:32:04.020 --> 00:32:05.880
So you're saying I don't
wanna do the ping probe.

698
00:32:05.880 --> 00:32:08.130
Just get in there and
scan the port already.

699
00:32:08.130 --> 00:32:12.886
And by doing that, sometimes that can
avoid not running a scan on a system that

700
00:32:12.886 --> 00:32:14.920
is actively blocking.

701
00:32:14.920 --> 00:32:17.961
So, I'm just gonna do a scan on 514 again.

702
00:32:17.961 --> 00:32:21.460
I'll make that UDP and
so we're gonna scan and

703
00:32:21.460 --> 00:32:25.680
this time it will skip the ping probe and
go right to reaching out and

704
00:32:25.680 --> 00:32:29.110
testing whether or not it can get to
that port and communicate that way.

705
00:32:29.110 --> 00:32:31.560
And it's taking a little longer this time.

706
00:32:31.560 --> 00:32:35.381
But that helps to avoid in those
situations where ping is being blocked by

707
00:32:35.381 --> 00:32:36.079
a fire wall.

708
00:32:36.079 --> 00:32:38.545
>> So the phrase for
today is disable ping probes.

709
00:32:38.545 --> 00:32:42.111
>> [LAUGH]
>> Verifying firewall configurations,

710
00:32:42.111 --> 00:32:44.041
awesome episode, great job Don.

711
00:32:44.041 --> 00:32:45.790
Anything else you wanna add?

712
00:32:45.790 --> 00:32:46.918
>> That's the main stuff here.

713
00:32:46.918 --> 00:32:49.052
The key thing though is make
this part of your policy.

714
00:32:49.052 --> 00:32:50.943
You need to routinely scan your servers.

715
00:32:50.943 --> 00:32:54.470
And if all of a sudden you see
a new port pop up in the list,

716
00:32:54.470 --> 00:32:56.360
that's a great way to spot
that you've been compromised.

717
00:32:56.360 --> 00:32:56.900
>> Right.

718
00:32:56.900 --> 00:33:00.000
>> Or to spot that somebody
made an unauthorized change or

719
00:33:00.000 --> 00:33:01.790
left something open in troubleshooting.

720
00:33:01.790 --> 00:33:03.080
Something is wrong.

721
00:33:03.080 --> 00:33:05.790
You should only get back
the ports that you expect.

722
00:33:05.790 --> 00:33:07.540
So build this intp your process.

723
00:33:07.540 --> 00:33:08.380
Do this routinely.

724
00:33:08.380 --> 00:33:11.130
Scan your servers daily,
weekly, monthly, something.

725
00:33:11.130 --> 00:33:12.800
You just need to be watching them.

726
00:33:12.800 --> 00:33:15.090
And you can scan an entire network.

727
00:33:15.090 --> 00:33:19.770
I never did it here, but I could've
put in the IP as 172.16.0.0\24 and

728
00:33:19.770 --> 00:33:22.400
now it'll scan the whole subnet.

729
00:33:22.400 --> 00:33:24.800
And so you can run one command and

730
00:33:24.800 --> 00:33:27.210
you scan all the ports
across your entire network.

731
00:33:27.210 --> 00:33:30.000
It'll take hours to run, but
when it's done you get a really good

732
00:33:30.000 --> 00:33:33.130
set of data back and you can understand
what is open on your network.

733
00:33:33.130 --> 00:33:33.710
>> Thanks, Don.

734
00:33:33.710 --> 00:33:34.810
You can never be too safe.

735
00:33:34.810 --> 00:33:37.700
Linux security techniques,
watch every single episode,

736
00:33:37.700 --> 00:33:39.610
you'll be very glad you did.

737
00:33:39.610 --> 00:33:41.150
And thank you for watching IT PRO TV,

738

remember a good IT Pro is always learning,
I'm Zack Memos.

>> And I'm Don Pezet.

00:23:39.220 --> 00:23:42.620
So if I start scrolling down,

00:23:44.080 --> 00:23:52.180
And I'm not finding it, lots of TCP, lots

00:23:52.180 --> 00:23:54.761
All right and we can apply filters and

00:23:54.761 --> 00:23:59.430
things if I really wanted to like here,

00:23:59.430 --> 00:24:03.773
So you can do these filters

00:24:03.773 --> 00:24:08.233
I can come in put a filter

00:24:12.680 --> 00:24:14.520
Nothing comes back, right?

00:24:14.520 --> 00:24:17.600
If I look for where the port equals 65023.

503
00:24:17.600 --> 00:24:20.548
Nothing, nothing comes back, right?

504
00:24:20.548 --> 00:24:23.570
The reason is all of that is encrypted.

505
00:24:23.570 --> 00:24:25.330
It's encrypted on the network and
we can't see it.

506
00:24:25.330 --> 00:24:28.720
It's all stuck inside of that SSH tunnel.

507
00:24:28.720 --> 00:24:34.030
The SSH tunnel is hiding everything,
so all I see is that SSH traffic.

508
00:24:34.030 --> 00:24:39.040
And if I pick an SSH packet and I try
that trick, I go up here to analyze and

509
00:24:39.040 --> 00:24:42.100
I go to follow TCP stream,
its going to reassemble it for me.

510
00:24:42.100 --> 00:24:44.910
And there's my data in plain text.

00:24:44.910 --> 00:24:46.180

00:24:46.180 --> 00:24:48.100

00:24:48.100 --> 00:24:51.060

How about you?

00:24:56.370 --> 00:24:58.760
And then it responded with here's

00:24:58.760 --> 00:25:00.090
And then they agreed.

00:25:00.090 --> 00:25:05.870
They chose, I can see right down here,

00:25:05.870 --> 00:25:07.160
Which is good, that's the strong one.

00:25:07.160 --> 00:25:09.360
That's what I've got set up on my server.

00:25:09.360 --> 00:25:13.804
And then after that handshake, after they

00:25:13.804 --> 00:25:15.172
look at everything else.

00:25:15.172 --> 00:25:16.589
It's just a mess.

525
00:25:16.589 --> 00:25:20.640
It's just a jumbled mess that

526
00:25:20.640 --> 00:25:23.060
This is all ciphertext.

00:25:23.060 --> 00:25:25.640
I might have pressed one

00:25:25.640 --> 00:25:29.510
it sent this whole block

529
00:25:29.510 --> 00:25:31.550
There's no way to figure

530
00:25:31.550 --> 00:25:35.160
And all the data that came back,

531
00:25:35.160 --> 00:25:39.540
This is, because I know what I did, this

532
00:25:39.540 --> 00:25:41.690
But if I was an attacker,

533
00:25:41.690 --> 00:25:42.370
So I don't know what this is.

534
00:25:42.370 --> 00:25:46.630
I know that I got a wall of data, but it
could have been a picture for all I know.

535
00:25:46.630 --> 00:25:48.190
Better yet, the D message applet.

536
00:25:48.190 --> 00:25:52.100
And then somewhere down further towards
the bottom will be where I did the SUDO

537
00:25:52.100 --> 00:25:55.640
command to then run journalCTL,
probably right here, okay?

538
00:25:55.640 --> 00:25:59.030
See all this red, so that's probably
me SUDOing to run journalCTL.

539
00:25:59.030 --> 00:26:03.370
And then it ran, and
I was presented with another wall of text.

540
00:26:03.370 --> 00:26:06.550
Now, that wall of text was paginated, so

541
00:26:06.550 --> 00:26:08.300
See these little red blips here?

542
00:26:08.300 --> 00:26:10.840
That's likely me pressing Enter
to move to the next page.

543
00:26:10.840 --> 00:26:12.210
Or I think I hit the spacebar.

544
00:26:12.210 --> 00:26:14.600
Again, I can't tell cuz
it's all encrypted.

545
00:26:14.600 --> 00:26:19.480
And the whole point of this exercise is
that I can look at this and now I know,

546
00:26:19.480 --> 00:26:23.120
I know for a fact,
that data was encrypted.

547
00:26:23.120 --> 00:26:25.720
You could build a tunnel up and
then do something stupid.

548
00:26:25.720 --> 00:26:28.460
I actually watched
a YouTube video forever ago

549
00:26:28.460 --> 00:26:30.680
where a guy was showing how
to build these tunnels.

550
00:26:30.680 --> 00:26:33.925
And he built up a tunnel,
he got it set up, right?

551
00:26:33.925 --> 00:26:35.968
So he built the tunnel kinda
the same way that I just did.

552
00:26:35.968 --> 00:26:39.429
He got it set up and he said all right,
so now, we've got that tunnel up, and

553
00:26:39.429 --> 00:26:42.156
now we can telmet into that server and
it'll be encrypted.

554
00:26:42.156 --> 00:26:43.549
And what did he do?

555
00:26:43.549 --> 00:26:48.610
He telmeted into the IP of
that other server, like that.

556
00:26:48.610 --> 00:26:50.660
Well, it doesn't matter
if you have a tunnel up.

557
00:26:50.660 --> 00:26:53.280
If you don't tell it to use the tunnel,
it goes right around it.

558
00:26:53.280 --> 00:26:54.870
And that's exactly what he did.

559
00:26:54.870 --> 00:26:57.720
And because he never showed
it actually being encrypted,

560
00:26:57.720 --> 00:27:00.360
he never noticed that his
data was still not encrypted.

561
00:27:00.360 --> 00:27:03.230
It's an easy mistake to make
if you don't pay attention.

562
00:27:03.230 --> 00:27:08.200
And if we use a utility like Wireshark
we can see, we can tell, yes,

563
00:27:08.200 --> 00:27:09.490
that data was encrypted, and

564
00:27:09.490 --> 00:27:13.290
now I know if an attacker gets it, they're
not gonna be able to interpret that data.

565
00:27:13.290 --> 00:27:15.620
>> Well, Don, we're running out of time,
but I have another question for you.

566
00:27:15.620 --> 00:27:18.610
What if we wanna monitor
actual sessions on the server?

567
00:27:18.610 --> 00:27:21.450
>> All right, so here, I'm really
monitoring sessions on my laptop, right?

568
00:27:21.450 --> 00:27:23.290
>> Right.
>> So my laptop reaching out to a server.

569
00:27:23.290 --> 00:27:25.260
So I'm testing my encryption.

570
00:27:25.260 --> 00:27:28.500
But if I wanted to see somebody's
actual session, right?

571
00:27:28.500 --> 00:27:31.300
Maybe have a website and I've got
Internet users that are connecting, and

572
00:27:31.300 --> 00:27:35.760
I wanna verify that one of them is
actually collecting that data, right?

573
00:27:35.760 --> 00:27:38.830
What I really need, or not collecting,
but encrypting that data.

574
00:27:38.830 --> 00:27:42.190
I could take my laptop,
I could go into the data center, and

575
00:27:42.190 --> 00:27:44.910
if I have switches from Cisco,
or Junyper, HP,

576
00:27:44.910 --> 00:27:48.110
a lot of those switches support
what's called port mirroring.

577
00:27:48.110 --> 00:27:50.940
And I could mirror the traffic
from one of those ports,

578
00:27:50.940 --> 00:27:54.340
the server port, over to my laptop, right?

579
00:27:54.340 --> 00:27:57.680
Or I could, Cisco calls it span,
the switch port analyzer.

580
00:27:57.680 --> 00:27:59.220
Everybody else calls it port mirroring.

581
00:27:59.220 --> 00:28:00.200
That's the easiest way to do it.

582
00:28:00.200 --> 00:28:04.040
If you're in the data center, you can take
your own device that's set up as a capture

00:28:04.040 --> 00:28:08.070
device like mine is, and then plug into
the network, do port mirroring on that

584
00:28:08.070 --> 00:28:10.870
port, and now you're collecting
all the data from that server.

585
00:28:10.870 --> 00:28:13.950
And you can analyze it in your GUI
tools just like I'm doing right here.

586
00:28:13.950 --> 00:28:16.380
And that makes life a lot easier.

587
00:28:16.380 --> 00:28:18.650
>> So
maybe this will be a teaser question,

00:28:18.650 --> 00:28:21.840
but couldn't we just run
Wireshark out of the server?

00:28:21.840 --> 00:28:23.510
Well, so you could, right?

590
00:28:23.510 --> 00:28:25.650
So everything that I just

00:28:25.650 --> 00:28:28.160
and I did it using Wireshark
which is really nice.

592
00:28:28.160 --> 00:28:31.290
I could just install Wireshark on
the server and capture the same data.

593
00:28:31.290 --> 00:28:35.400
The problem is Wireshark is
really built around a GUI, right?

594
00:28:35.400 --> 00:28:37.040
And most of our servers don't have a GUI.

595
00:28:37.040 --> 00:28:40.770
So you can install the Wireshark command
line tools, collect the data and

596
00:28:40.770 --> 00:28:43.150
then copy the data to your
workstation to interpret it.

597
00:28:43.150 --> 00:28:45.440
But it's really not a good idea
to run Wireshark on a server,

598
00:28:45.440 --> 00:28:46.350
it's got too many dependencies.

599
00:28:46.350 --> 00:28:48.950
It's got a lot of stuff that would
increase your security footprint.

600
00:28:48.950 --> 00:28:51.640
So ideally, we don't wanna do that, right?

601
00:28:51.640 --> 00:28:55.030
There is another tool we can use though,

602
00:28:55.030 --> 00:28:58.260
And I wanna show you guys TCPDUMP,

603
00:28:58.260 --> 00:29:01.160
it's likely already on your server.

604
00:29:01.160 --> 00:29:04.060
So that's what I would normally use

605
00:29:04.060 --> 00:29:06.780
But like you said, Zach,
I'm kinda out of time on this episode.

00:29:06.780 --> 00:29:08.250

00:29:08.250 --> 00:29:10.610
And in part two,

608
00:29:10.610 --> 00:29:12.940
how we can collect data

609
00:29:12.940 --> 00:29:16.140
And then we don't have to worry
about port mirroring, or SPAN, or

610
00:29:16.140 --> 00:29:16.870
any of the crazy stuff.

611
00:29:16.870 --> 00:29:18.830
We don't have to be in the data
center with the server.

612
00:29:18.830 --> 00:29:20.520
We can just use tcpdump to grab the data,

613
00:29:20.520 --> 00:29:24.500
and then copy it down to our own machine
where we can analyze it at our leisure.

614
00:29:24.500 --> 00:29:26.510
It's a great utility,
definitely one you want to see.

615
00:29:26.510 --> 00:29:27.458
>> That's a great tease.

616
00:29:27.458 --> 00:29:31.460
You're gonna wanna catch Verifying
Network Data Encryption, Part Two.

617
00:29:31.460 --> 00:29:32.490
This has been Part One.

618
00:29:32.490 --> 00:29:35.580
Anything you want to leave
people with before we go?

619
00:29:35.580 --> 00:29:37.980
>> The main lesson here is trust but
verify, right?

620
00:29:37.980 --> 00:29:39.460
Trust that your encryption works,

621
00:29:39.460 --> 00:29:41.540
but you need to verify that
it's actually being used.

622
00:29:41.540 --> 00:29:45.040
Cuz simple mistakes on your part could
lead to the encryption being there and

623
00:29:45.040 --> 00:29:46.750
you're just not using it, right?

624
00:29:46.750 --> 00:29:49.040
We definitely want to verify that and
make sure we got it in place.

625
00:29:49.040 --> 00:29:50.310
Always double-check your work.

626
00:29:50.310 --> 00:29:51.779
>> Absolutely, you can never too safe.

627
00:29:51.779 --> 00:29:56.210
And that's why we've done this
series of Linux security techniques.

628
00:29:56.210 --> 00:29:59.740
So make sure you watch and
every episode, it's good for you.

629
00:29:59.740 --> 00:30:01.340
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

630
00:30:01.340 --> 00:30:03.800
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

631
00:30:03.800 --> 00:30:04.860
I'm Zach Memos.

632
00:30:04.860 --> 00:30:05.450
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

633
00:30:05.450 --> 00:30:08.170
>> And we will see you very soon.

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

>> Right, and so in that show, I was

00:01:22.310 --> 00:01:24.085
which runs great, it's nice.

But I said we should run it on a server,

its graphical user interface in place.

31

The command line tools can
be used to capture data, but

32
00:01:33.240 --> 00:01:35.470
even then,
it's got a pretty large footprint.

33
00:01:35.470 --> 00:01:40.220
So fortunately, on our servers,

34
00:01:40.220 --> 00:01:42.580
And TCP Dump, like its name implies,

35
00:01:42.580 --> 00:01:45.960

36
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:49.850
It dumps all the network data and
lets you see it, right?

37
00:01:49.850 --> 00:01:51.450
It's a packet capture utility.

38
00:01:51.450 --> 00:01:53.890
It is not a protocol analyzer.

39
00:01:53.890 --> 00:01:56.220
It will not interpret the data for you.

40
00:01:56.220 --> 00:01:57.870
But it will let you collect it.

41
00:01:57.870 --> 00:02:00.050
And so if you've got a remote server or
like me,

42

00:02:02.030 --> 00:02:03.520

00:02:03.520 --> 00:02:06.010
And I wanna monitor some of that data.

45
00:02:06.010 --> 00:02:10.600
I can remote into the server, and I can

46
00:02:10.600 --> 00:02:13.420
It can reach out, it can grab the data,

47
00:02:13.420 --> 00:02:16.070

48
00:02:16.070 --> 00:02:19.592

50
00:02:22.387 --> 00:02:23.864

it's been around a long time.

51
00:02:23.864 --> 00:02:27.659
